reviewText: The Motorola is a micro USB rapid charger. Would have loved if the cable was longer or interchangeable, but it is an OK product.

We have several iHome products, which we use to charge iPods, boost their sound, and as a base so they can be used as near permanent alarm clocks.  I've always been pleased with their quality and performance.But this model is a more cheaply made plastic shell and, since it works only on batteries, is an inferior power option.  All you really get is a slight sound boost for when you travel, but the past few hotels we've stayed at have featured alarm clocks with iPod ports, so do you really need it?

Takes good photos and has good white balance. Mechanical buttons and dials are preferable to a badly implemented touch screen.  Light, small and slim enough to fit in your pocket at 0.8". Starts up quickly, and can take 10 frapes per second if needed. Sweep panorama and assorted 'scene' selections are helpful.  5x zoom is OK on a camera this tiny. Takes nice shots from limited macro to portrait to landscape and full HD video. Moderate low-light performance - but better than you might expect.It is not a top line camera of course - but performs very well copmpared to cameras in the $190 price range and had 16 megapixels so you can crop a little.  If you are a pixel-peeper, look elsewhere.  For the casual shooter - one that wants something portable and convenient - this is not a bad choice and will get you quality enlargements if needed.  Under good conditions - you can get very nice images indeed.

I for the life of me have no idea what the point of putting a camera into a mouse is. The camera in the mouse works well enough and the quality is good for a 2MP camera, but I don't know why you would ever need such a thing. It was basically plug and play with both Windows 7 and Google Chrome OS with no issues or complaints. The mouse tracks well and precision is good.

The Sabrent Ultra Slim 2.5 inch SATA to USB 3.0 External Aluminum Screwless enclosure is really easy to use.  "Screwless" means that you pinch two small tabs on one end and the lid lifts off.  Insert any 2.5" hard drive, close the lid, and it clicks into place ready-to-go.  There is a tiny LED that flickers with activity so you know the hard drive inside is working, and the supplied cable connects your hard drive to any USB port.  It is USB 3.0 compatible so can produce USB 3 speeds.The aluminum finish is pretty sturdy, but don't mistake 'metal' for 'ruggedized':  you still want to use some care transporting the drive:  the form factor is so thin that I don't think a hard drive would survive a solid, hard drop.  The only other drawback to this enclosure is that the supplied USB cable doesn't completely seat itself into the plug on the drive:  it sticks up just a bit, which is weird but not exactly a showstopper.If you want a simple, tool-free way to turn an old laptop hard drive into a portable one, this Sabrent Ultra Slim is a great choice.
The 3 pack is great so even if you mess one up with bubbles, you have another without having to reorder.  I was able to get the first one on almost perfect, so I still have 2 for future use.
Solid connection.Great price. Big improvement over stock product.Buy it now.No much else to say.Excellant product .
summary: no brainer. solid fit.  big improvement over stock or store bought connectors

reviewText: Perfectly fit my att iPhone 5 sim and allowed me to put it into a Galaxy SIII. Snug fit, zero connection problems.
I installed this item into my blu ray player and it worked wonderfully. It was easy to set up with decent instructions.

This protector cover clips on the NEX-5N LCD screen. The side panels pop out when the top lid opened. Sometime they don't pop out and need to be opened manually. The cover added some protection to the LCD screen and increased some thickness to the camera. But it doesn't bother me too much. When used with NEX-5N the touchscreen become a little bit awkward but not too bad. The cover can block sunlight when you take pictures outdoor and provide clearer view on the objects.

Great looking, super slim mouse at a phenomenal price. The blue LED tracking system is über cool and works great on every surface I've tried it on.The DPI button is a really nice feature (alters the pointer tracking sensitivity / rate for detail work) since this will be used on a Mac for digital art. Button clicks are solid and predictable and the wheel is smooth. Fit and finish overall is very good and looks like a far more expensive device.The ONLY reason I held back a star is that the power management seems to be flaky, when OSX (Mountain Lion) sleeps, the mouse is inoperative upon wake and the receiver dongle needs to be unplugged/reseated to re-detect it and get it going again. A minor nuisance and possibly a ML issue. Did not test on a Windows machine because I can't pry it out of the hands of the user (my wife).All in all a very good wireless mouse and will probably buy a few more while they're available.

The iRAD 230 from Cobra, in theory, sounds like a great idea by integrating a radar detection device with a Smartphone App.I thought "this is so cool" forgetting a main component is actually using my smartphone for this idea to work.  I already have a detector hanging on the windshield, and don't want to also attach my cell phone to be able to view it for the two to work together.  Then I'd have two dangling wires, because it's impossible to use my cell without charging it at the same time as both Bluetooth and GPS functionality must be turned on your phone to work with the iRAD 230; for me, these are battery drainers (especially GPS).I decided to use it as the passenger to see how it worked.  I feel like trying to use it while driving would present a problem for me, as when an alert from a prior user would pop up, I would need to press whether I have seen this or if I am not sure.  The app started to remind me of a free app I have occasionally used in the past that is very similar but based solely on the "community" of drivers currently on the road. With that app, you report various road conditions, police sightings, hazards, etc.  As a passenger, using that app comes in handy.  The iRAD app, while looking nice and having various user settings, didn't seem as useful as the other free app called Waze.  And as this is also "community based" it is relying on other people for data, I wasn't getting many alerts, and the ones I did get were out-dated. Obviously more people need to be using the app for this to be effective and helpful.Pros: the app easily paired with my Bluetooth and GPS - and it alerts you to turn them on if they are off.  It also easily pairs with the detector (the one light on the iRAD will change from red to blue) and the suction cup mounts works fine holding the detector in place.I have only done in City driving while using the iRAD, so I do want to check out its Highway capabilities when I get the chance, if a road trip comes up.

I also own this lens' older brother, the 70-200 f2.8. While the quality of the images produced by that lens is nothing short of amazing, this is also a very good lens, that almost matches the 70-200 f2.8.
I am not sure a person can actually "Love" a charger.  But I am 100% happy with this item, so I'll give it all the stars I can!Easy to use, transport and adapt.  Certainly need it!

Cost too much for what it delivered. Satellite radio is a good idea but the  cost of the radio and the Satellite radio subscription seemed a bit too costly. Reception was spotty as I moved around the city. I ended up having to buy a special head antenna to improve reception.

This is a very cheaply made cable and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. The one I received only has intermittent connection with the device I was using it on. Spend a bit more and get a better quality one.

This unit came without instructions or a box, it was just wrapped loose so I wasn't sure I got it all. But when I hooked it up it worked fine. Great little unit to add a few HDMI ports where you might need them. I would have given it five stars if it had the instructions and box.

This thing does what it's supposed to do, won't replace any high end speakers but definitely more pop for any mobile device you have, iphone, tablet, laptop. Quite loud and when you go just short of the max volume, pretty crisp sound. Not much bass but for under $20, it's a nice addition. I bought this as a bundle which included bluetooth headphones and bluetooth dongle which will be a gift, kept this for myself, good deal for $35. Only thing is the wire is a bit short maybe 2 inches long but you can buy extenders on Amazon or ebay for extra couple of bucks.

I use "sneaker wear" to keep my email data syncronized across three different computers. Is about 8 Gb total transfer; this drive gives plenty of room for that & I can keep other longer term data on it at the same time.
Came brand new in packaging, works great. Great buy for the money. I needed a new one and a longer one.

First and foremost, this lens will fit perfectly onto a Nikon D3100 or D3200 DSLR.  There were quite a few people asking if it would, but no definite answers when I was researching this lens before purchasing it.  It is heavy, much heavier than the stock Nikon AF VR 18-55mm lens, and bigger but it does fit perfectly onto the D3100/D3200 body just fine.  In my opinion, the larger 62mm body looks better on my D3200 compared to the smaller 52mm lens that came with the camera.The first thing that I noticed right away is that the AF works perfect now, meaning I can focus onto an object at any distance and the lens will automatically focus into it and hold that focus while I steady myself before closing the shutter.  With the Nikon VR 18-55mm lens, that thing was possessed and would rarely hold a good focus point for me, especially in low light.  In good lighting indoor our outdoor, no problems with the AF on either lens.  But in the low light, the Sigma lens works much better and I can focus onto an object much faster and take quick shots with my D3100 now.  Surprisingly, the Sigma lens motor is more quiet compared to the Nikon VR motor which really whines a lot when focusing.  The shorter time needed with focusing, and the quiet motor works great when I'm taking pictures in a quiet environment.  The 18mm view is slightly wider on the Sigma than it is on the Nikon VR 18-55mm lens, but just barely.  The picture quality in low light indoors comes out a little better compared to the Nikon VR lens, mainly due to the AF being able to hold onto a point with constantly adjusting.I'm not a professional photographer, but I can take some good portrait pictures for websites and print.  The colors with this lens are as good as the Nikon VR 18-55 with no Photoshop needed to render the color spectrum.  For an 'all around' lens with good versatility and range, I would highly recommend it for the average person who's looking to only carry one lens around to capture anything & everything.Also to note, this lens comes with a 62mm lens hood.  I didn't know it came with one, so I now have 2 since I purchased a spare lens hood with the camera.  Therefore, no need to get another lens hood if you see Amazon recommend it as part of a package.
summary: Works great on my Nikon D3100

reviewText: 15" Samsung Series 9 with 256GB SSD, i7 processor and 8GB RAM. The specs are great and the Series 9 has an elegant, slim, solid unibody-type design. I couldn't live with less than 256GB storage and I'm really glad I didn't settle for the 128GB flavor.1) Machine is very fast - boots from cold in less than 10secs, resumes from sleep in less than 2. Incredible. Screams through any task I give it.2) Screen is about right at 1600x900 - enough pixels for side-by-side documents while not requiring a microscope to read text. Screen is matte which is nice but I am not as impressed with the color rendition as others seem to be - it's ok but nothing amazing.3) Battery life is very good - I regularly achieve 8 hours or more which for me effectively equals all day use. Very impressive.4) Audio is OK but I wouldn't use for listening to music. I did have to make a change in the audio settings to boost the max volume to a more usable level (Speaker Properties > Enhancements > Loudness Equalization).5) I liked the fnLock key with its LED which allows me to use the Fn keys for screen system controls (brightness, sound etc) without requiring the Fn button each time.While the Series 9 has a lot going for it I had to make a few adjustments to really enjoy the machine properly:-1) Downgraded from Windows 8 to Windows 7 - just couldn't get on with 8 and needed this to be focused 100% on the desktop experience. During this process I also reclaimed all the drive space partitions which gives me 230GB of usable capacity. Much happier now. YMMV.2) Touchpad - I'm used to a MacBook Pro touchpad which is pretty much perfect (even when running Windows in Bootcamp) and the Series 9 touchpad was unpleasant at first - sometimes selecting when I wanted to scroll, right-clicking when I wanted to left-click etc. In the end I found a different driver for this that solved all these issues (ironically NOT the latest version - the best was Elan version 11.6.4.001 for those interested for themselves). I also disabled right corner clicking and reversed scroll direction ("natural"). Feels better now.3) Keyboard backlight - there is no manual control over this if the sensor decides the room is too bright. In my experience there were times I wanted it on but the software refused me (why? let ME decide!). So I blocked the light sensor with a small piece of tape and now I have full control over brightness. Works but I really shouldn't need to do this.4) I had a key (BACKSPACE) that was temperamental - sometimes didn't register key-presses at all. I was almost going to return the machine but thought I'd try a blast of compressed air first from one of those pressurized cans with a straw. Out popped a microscopic piece of plastic debris and Voila! - now it works perfectly.5) The micro-ports are a bit of a pain - not happy about carrying adapters around for Ethernet and VGA but I got used to that with the MacBook Pro VGA dongle (didn't like it there either) and the Series 9 is much thinner - Samsung at least provide the Ethernet adapter in the box. Charger port isn't as elegant as Apple's mag-safe but it does the job.So as you can see with a few software tweaks Samsung could have had a 5-star machine - basically ship with a better touchpad driver and backlight software that gives full control to the user and you're golden.Overall though I now love my Series 9, it just needed a little TLC at the start.

Instead of a card and an adapter inside of a case, I received a card, a broken adapter, and a small plastic bag. luckily I had another adapter that worked. I did have to reformat the card with my pc before it would work in my cell phone also. The phone would not recognize it until I did.

I use this monitor with a Mac Pro and love it. You should calibrate it with the Apple Display System Preference to get the color profile you like. After that forget it. The monitor adjustments all work with the Mac. No dead pixels, good stand, nice appearance. I am using a HDMI to DVI cable to connect to my Mac Pro. I've found that a lot of things won't work with a hub, but most things I have worked with this one.  I mainly use it for mouse and keyboard for laptop, handy to just use one USB and easy to plug in and remove, and keeps the mouse and keyboard cables together.

I know there are a lot of bad reviews about this product being doa or dying within a couple months. So far I have not gotten any problems with it. I guess only time will tell whether I will be added to the negative statistics. However, if the PSU lasts it would definitely be a worthwhile purchase considering your getting a SLI ready 630W PSU for such a reasonable price.

This is my second experience with a Zagg product. The first was their product for the Palm Pre when that was my primary cell phone a few years ago. It was hideous to install and and it looked like hell after it was in place...air bubbles all over the place! Not sure why I decided to try their product again on my first gen ipad other than I needed to replace the plastic screen cover and the price was right. Guess what?! Same exact results. Air bubbles all over the place. What is with this spray you have to put on your hands and then on both sides of the film? Then you use a micro squeegee they provide. It all adds up to a crappy result. I think if you use a pair of surgical gloves and their special spray there is a 0.1% chance that it might turn out better. Either I need to send it off to be applied or they should stop selling this crap. I will never, ever buy a Zagg product again.  Don't waste your time or money. I won't even install the back plastic, just because I don't need both sides of my ipad to look like crap covered in air bubbles.
summary: Impossible to apply correctly - DO NOT BUY

reviewText: Never be lost again! I especially love the Lifetime Maps. My son has an older version navigator and learned he would have to pay fifty dollars to update his maps. With all the changes in roads, subdivisions adding new streets, etc., this feature alone makes it well worth the price. I love the easy to use features and specific direction aides, time/miles etc. that helps lead you to your desired direction. If you're traveling alone, in a big city with heavy traffic, etc. you know how crazy it is to try to look at a map, your roads and exits simply come up too fast. Not only is the TomTom navigator convenient, it is simply safer driving. Almost everyone has experienced the frustration of being lost. I doubt I'll ever be lost again as long as I punch in the proper address (another challenge for me at times).

It took a little long to get but it was within the time they had estimated. This flash drive is of very good quality, it's solid and sturdy. I really like it. There is one little problem depending on the tv you may have a problem getting in the usb port because of the way it's shaped. Not all tv's, i guess it would be hard to know unless you had it to try out. There was no problem with the laptop or computer, even fit into the blu ray good.

I bought this only because I needed a replacement since my brother asked me to "borrow" it and then never gave it back. The sound quality is amazing. I use it to connect my iPod or my cell phone and it's so clear, never any static or anything else

After using iPad covers which completely encapsulated for protection, I was a bit apprehensive to try theKensington K39785US KeyCoveron my iPad2.  I've been using the KeyCover ever since I received it 10 months ago.  I've experienced no problems from lack of protection on the back of the iPad.  The padded feet have fallen off, the finish on the back and buttons are showing wear, but overall is still functional.  I'm excited to try out both the Kensington K97007US and K97087US for use with my new iPad Air.The Kensington K97007US / K97087US KeyCover keyboard case for the iPad Air, made in China, is both a protective cover with a v3.0 bluetooth keyboard.  The iPad Air snaps securely in place with quick release corners for tablet removal. Raised corner pads keep the keys from pressing against the iPad while in storage mode, and a hidden magnet enables the sleep mode while secured in storage mode.  A magnetic well secures the iPad Air for viewing in landscape and portrait mode.  In addition to the keyboard, the package includes documentation and a USB to macro charging cable.  On the surface, both KeyCover's, weighing about 13 ounces, appear to be identical.However, there are a few differences between the two KeyCover options.  The K97087US includes backlighting with seven color options (purple, red, green, cyan, violet, yellow, cool white) and +/- brightness setting keys with a 1500 mAh battery lasting for 60 working days or 480 standby days.  The K97007US keyboard currently comes with a free skin offer valued at $29.99, valid through December 2014, to cover both the iPad Air and KeyCover with a 420 mAh battery lasts for 60 working days or 480 standby days.The KeyCovers only use a magnetic well without the stand found in older versions to support the iPad in either landscape or portrait mode.  I'm guessing the stand was eliminated due to a slimmer width.  When I use the KeyCover, it's not unusual for me to type and touch the screen to complete a task.  For instance, registering the keyboard on Kensington's website had me entering information into a web form, tapping "Next" buttons, and browsing for and uploading a receipt.  The iPad remains in place as long as I only use the keyboard.  Any touchscreen activity can easily lead to a falling iPad if not being careful.  Even with plenty of function keys, I can't pull up my emoji keyboard, swipe between apps, and more without touching the screen.  I'm constantly resetting the iPad during use; even when holding the iPad in place with my free hand. The lack of a stability stand is a design flaw as far as I'm concerned.The iPad Air fits into the KeyCover snugly, and includes a flexible rubber corner for simplifying removal from storage mode.  The old KeyCover, with half the height, didn't have this feature and also fit snugly at first, then over time became a snap to remove.  I'm guessing the same will happen with the new versions, with the rubber corner being a cross between past complaints and the doubled height.I'm not sure what Kensington means by 360 degree protection.  When the iPad is secured in storage mode, the back is exposed to potential scratches.  I like personalizing my iPad with a decal or skin, which offers limited protection.  I haven't yet run into an issue with this strategy and am comfortable continuing to do so.  While I understand the concerns regarding the lack of covering on the back, I had them myself; time has shown me this type of damage is not common for me.The Kensington KeyCover keyboard cover does a good job of protecting the iPad when snapped in place for storage.  Additionally the keyboard works well, with the keys responding accurately and quickly.  I'm mostly excited by the addition of backlighting, something I desired from my old KeyCover.  I use my iPad regularly in multiple environments as a laptop replacement, and find the instability issue too concerning and worrisome.  I'm not sure if other keyboard covers have this issue, but I'm going to keep looking for better options.PROS:Effective v3.0 Bluetooth keyboardEasily pairs to iPadLong lasting batteryOne year limited warrantyCONS:Lack of stability standMay be difficult to remove iPadWill not protect the iPad's back from scratches and scrapes
summary: Stay In The Groove: A Kensington K97007US / K97087US KeyCover Hard Case Keyboard for iPad Air Review

reviewText: I got this for Christmas and was absolutely amazed once I figured out how to work it.  I have a Sony 46" LED, Sony Blu Ray, and now the Sony 350 and everything sync perfectly and sounds absolutely great! The bass is pure, the voices are crisp, and I'm so happy with the product! reviewerName: Knife Knut "Just my opinion, take it for what...
reviewText: Just a disclaimer upfront, I will use basically the same review for 2 or 3 different items in this product line.  I ordered a "combo pack" of these with varying sizes and models.  The pros and cons are identical if not so similar there is no reason to write 2 or 3 almost identical reviews.So far I love this thing.  I've seen lots of clever techniques and products for cable management.  I have tried many of them.  I was in need of some new power strips and was intrigued by the design concept of these units.  Sleek, modern looking power strip with some cable management built in.  I had seen one at home depot for full price and after looking at it out of the box the amazon price sold me.Other reviewers have taken issue with the design and materials, in particular the hinge that the cover sits on.  I agree this could be better designed or made with more durable material.  However in defense I would say that one needs to be realistic about the operating environment/conditions.  I generally take very good care of all my stuff.  Aside from my wife being a little clumsy we don't have much in the way of accidents around the house.  Now, if you have a house full of little hellions/kids/dogs/relatives running around tearing stuff up.  This thing is obviously designed and constructed for function and aesthetic, not necessarily for durability.  Further more; location location location.  A power strip is not something you generally have out and exposed where said destructive forces could have a go at it.  Would the cover hinge assembly break if I kicked it or tripped over it?  Yes it probably would, but I don't have the unit anywhere that will happen and it still meets my needs.Overall I would recommend this product provided you use some good common sense in regards to how your going to use it vs. its intended use and capabilities.  If any issues pop up in the future I will edit this review or post a new one.
summary: Very nice and functional with reasonable use

reviewText: So far, so good.  Everything I expected.  Excellent price for this high capacity hard drive.  I would definitely mention this to friends.

works great does what it says it will do. price has come down over the years and quality has improved. I use it in my note 3 and it does a great job. when I fill it up I put everything on an external hard drive and the card can be used over and over and over again.

reviewText: For those of you who have kids that grab the PS3 controller when you want to watch a movie, this is the controller for you. It looks and duplicates a NORMAL remote in every way, so even parents can use it comfortably. Take control of your Blue Ray movies on YOUR PS3. Your kids will be upset, but they're teenagers, it's OK.Also, the instruction manual that come with it for setting up the Bluetooth function are clear and concise. The Bluetooth is how the remote sees the PS3. The PS3 uses bluetooth, instead of infrared, is why you can't program your other remotes for your PS3.The faceplate functions are clear and easy to find. I only use the basic ones to watch movies, but they are well layed out and I don't double hit buttons. Overall, everything I expected it to be at an affordable price. As usual, Amazon delivered it pronto.
summary: Playstation Remote for Watching Blue Ray Movies

The badge is pretty low-key, so it isn't a huge deal, but I just don't like being a billboard for companies.The only issue I have with it, that I think will matter to others, is the placement of the posts. I think they should have been put in the back. It just looks unfinished, because there isn't a great way to hide the wires coming out of the sides.

Looks like the old 80's video games.It is also painful to switch between displays.  Aside from all of this, it charges my Ipod and lets me listen to music while I work out.Little overpriced for what you get.

I was so excited to get this little gadget along with 3 months free Netflix!  I must say that as I waited for it to arrive, I became anxious that I wouldn't be able to get it to work with my TV. My fears were unfounded, though. I followed the super easy instructions for Chromecast and I also followed the equally easy instructions for connecting with Netflix with the code for the free 3 months and in approximately 15 minutes I was watching a movie on my flat screen TV. My TV is an RCA bought in 2009. It is not considered fancy by anyone's standard. Your TV will need a USB port and a HDMI port. It helps if those two are near each other as mine are. There is a selection of cords, however, so if your TV does not have the USB port, there are other ways to supply the Chromecast with power. I think there is even an AC attachment. It comes in a very impressive box, so if you are giving as a gift, it will deliver a nice impact.
Excellent quality, as is all Samsung merchandise.  Very sturdy and it works well on all my "flash card" equipment.  The price was right too!

reviewText: I've.  purchased many RCA y adapters but I have to say. The quality of this one is the best I have ever used

I bought this because I have a cheap TV that only has one HDMI port so it was either the cable box or the dvd, now I can have both and still have one port open.  Nothing complicated about this.  I just plugged it into the tv, plugged the cable box into slot one, and the dvd into slot 2.  If I turn my dvd player on, even if the cable box is on, it goes over to the dvd player through which I get my net flix, pandora and any other program I choose.  It was a lot simpler than I imagined and it was also much cheaper than getting another TV.

I ordered this to use for photo editing- there is an open source driver available for this called Paddy that allows it to work with Lightroom for photo editing.  Which with all the programmable macro buttons this can seriously cut down on editing time for professional photographers. (Dedicated boards serving that same function is in the hundreds of dollars.)I am impressed with the form and ergonomics of this board. The only down side for me is I seem to keep getting faulty units.  The first unit had loose parts on it that would pop and click when using it, the second one had a key (G15) that would not register a push properly and would have to be pressed several times for it to register. I will be receiving a third unit soon and I will update this review to reflect my experiences.I think I have just been unlucky as my experience with Logitech products in the past has always been exceptional.

reviewText: I bought this in lieu of buying headrest monitors.  I have bluetooth in my car for the stereo so I can put movies on my iPad 2 and play the audio through the car system.  This works great for us as we have a baby that is rear facing at the moment in the car seat....so when she can be forward facing I can just move this to the other headrest.  Overall it works great.  It does rattle a little (the ipad rattles in the holder) but you can put some small padding on the inside and it works great.

I must say that aside from the computer for a moment, the upgrade to Windows 8.1 makes a big improvement in the utility and sensibility of the OS. The HP computer was good enough that I purchased two. I bought one for my wife, who wanted an all in one and touch screen. After setting it all up for her (uninstalling the bloatware, giving it decent security suite protection and customizing the look and feel and redoing the tiles, and switching it from Microsoft's lackluster 'combined environment' over to Google's, I liked it enough I bought one for myself, although I got the edition with 6 gig of ram. It makes a big difference in speed. The OS slows what would be a fast computer, and the more memory you give it, the better it works. I also added an external harddisk and a personal network cloud (WD MyCloud) to better share data and protect it with auto-backups to the cloud of complete system images.The external drives were configured to the the default download repository of photos, videos and so forth, making that data easy to recover or apply to other computers. It also leaves the somewhat skinny half terabyte drive C for applications and scratch space. It's not quite a 5 star system. It would have made it to five if it had been offered with Windows 7 Home Premium, which is leaps and bounds a better and easier to use OS than 8/8.1 which seems to have tablets in mind rather than desk or laptops.

Yee so this is the maximum space allowed in the gopros to my knowledge. The older versions like the Hero 3 are the larger SD cards but now the micro SD cards are allowed. Great price and great quality for those HD pictures and movies. Get it.
summary: Got this for the Newer GoPros...Working Great!

reviewText: I purchased this extension HDMI cord because of my tv and Playstation 3 setup. I was using a standard HDMI cable that works perfectly well but needed to move my PS3 unit further, hence the requirement for this cable. The first thing I noticed when I took the cable out of the box was how slim it was. This cable is about 3 quarters the thickness of your standard HDMI cable. I figured as long as the signal can pass through it would work. This extension piece was the end that was going into the PS3. When I booted it up I noticed flickering in the signal. Just random flickering distortion on the screen and on a couple of occasions the signal would give out completely and it was like the PS3 wasn't being read onto the TV. I tried playing with the cable and I still noticed random flickering.I used another HDMI cable, a 15 foot one that could easily reach without any extension and BAM!, the system booted up perfectly with no signal interruption whatsoever. This extension was the culprit. I think it has to do with the thickness of the cable, it may be too slim for the full signal to go from the PS3 unit to the TV. Hence, it did work, but just had signal interruption. This may be because the PS3 simply has a lot more signal to send out, therefore this extension may be ideal for units that are smaller. Perhaps a smaller tv, an audio device, or a DVD or Blu-ray player.If you require an extension, I would NOT recommend this one for at least any gaming system, as I know the Xbox perhaps requires just as much juice as the PS3. If you do use this for any other device and see or hear signal interruption, this extension is most likely the culprit. My advice would be to seek out an extension cable with the standard width of any HDMI cable, this way you'll know there is plenty of conductor in it to properly get the entire signal through.
summary: Not Very Durable and Intermittent Signal, Causes Flickering

reviewText: The sound on these is pretty good - but the sound reduction is amazingly effective at the gym.  Now I can hear the music without turning it way up. reviewText: I looked all around for different NAS devices for use at my home.  Of all the reviews I read, it seemed that the Synology brand offered the best device and the most features for a home NAS.  And the only thing I noticed for complaints was the consistent report of how slow the NAS is for loading and then thumbnailing photos for use by its photo browsing software, or via its Media Server software.  Once I got the device, I validated this is a big pain with the device, but I was able to setup a process to work around the issue for me.  This work around is ok for me, since it will enable me to keep the photo service and media server service active, which my family really likes.Now that I have the device and I have loaded it with most of the content from my home PCs, I can now comfortably say that I am happy that I bought this device.  I ended up buying this drive for it:Western Digital Caviar Green 2 TB Desktop Hard Drive WD20EARX.  I still have more to play with it, and more things to setup and explore, but I've used it enough that I think I can comfortably write a review about it now.I have so far, been able to use the NAS from all 3 of our PCs, and all of our Android and iOS devices.  For Android, you can use either the Synology DSFile app, or can just use any file browser with Samba mount support.  I was able to have the kids write a document on the laptop, and then I could read the document on my tablet, make comments on it, and put it back on the share so that they could see my comments and make another pass at it.  Then when they were all done, I could go to our other PC which is hooked up to the printer and could print the document right from there.  And if I tried to edit a document that someone else had opened, I was told which PC had it open, and could ask then to close the document so I could edit it.  It worked exactly the way I wanted it to.PROS- nice and quiet.  I cannot hear the fan or the hard drive in this thing.- nice looking device- it has a lot of functional components to it.  I wanted a Media Server, FTP server, and a Windows mountable share.  I got that plus a whole lot more.- Photo browsing software is actually quite nice.  It seems to have a lot of functionality for photo browsing.  I am still playing with the features that are available so I haven't mastered everything that it can do.- Nice application support for iOS and Android platforms.  I installed the DSPhoto+ software on my wife and kids devices and they can all browse our photo library and digital camera video library with ease now.  Although I have had the ability to view photos via the PS3 using Media Server on my PC, it works so much nicer with this software.  This was a huge win for my family.  I also installed all the other DS Android apps on my tablet, and I am quite happy with what it enables.- Lots of account options for it.- I really like how they don't install every option that it offers upon initial installation.  It actually lets you chose which modules you want installed.CONS- the biggest downfall for this device is the slow thumbnail process for photos that get uploaded to the photo share.  I will detail this issue below.- the provided software was outdated and I should have just went online and obtained a new version from there.  The version I initially tried ended up messing up the date/time of the photos that I originally loaded.  Luckily I can just write a shell script to fix them all, instead of copying all the files over again.- the speed doesn't seem as quick as I was hoping it would be for file transfers, but I need to do a lot more testing of my home network to make sure it is not a network infrastructure issue.  I have a Linksys E3200 router and a gigabit network card in my PC, and I was not able to get what I thought was fast transfer speeds as I transferred files to the NAS.  So I did some testing with a 1GB movie file to see the actual speed numbers of the NAS.  Here is what I noticed:(NOTE: "Windows D" = my D Drive on my Windows box, and "Windows C" is my C drive)Source......Target......Time...MB/s...ApproachWindows D...NAS.........52s....19MB...Mapped Drive CopyNAS.........Windows D...42s....24MB...Mapped Drive CopyWindows D...NAS.........45s....22MB...FTPNAS.........Windows D...42s....24MB...FTPNAS.........NAS.........37s....27MB...Shell Command Single Drive CopyWindows D...Windows D...54s....18MB...Windows Explorer Single Drive CopyWindows C...Windows D...19s....53MB...Windows Explorer Multi Drive CopySo as shown above, the write speed of my Windows Drive can achieve up to 53MB/s when using 2 internal drives, and that speed slows down to about half that speed when the NAS is used, since the network adds overhead.  I expected the NAS to be slower than an internal drive would be, and after I went through the above test, I guess I am not as disappointed with the speed of the NAS.  After all, the NAS outperforms a single drive copy, so I think that is not all that bad.AREAS FOR IMPROVEMENT- Improve upon the photo upload software and also the photo thumbnailing process to not be so slow.  This could be achieved by providing options to the user on the quality of the thumbnails.  Although its nice that the NAS wants to create 5 different sized thumbnails for each photo, this process takes a long time to achieve, even if using the provided upload software.INTERESTING THINGS I HAVE DONE WITH IT- I have been able use the PS3 Media Server to view photos stored on it.- I have used their Android and iOS apps to browse files and photos- I have been able to run those apps from outside the home network (once I opened the ports for it) so that I have my own cloud storage option no matter where I am- explored the shell scripting capabilities that it has.  I find it to be a little limited with options and commands but it is able to do most things that any Linux OS should be able to do.  (I wish it had cron though)HOW I FIXED THE PHOTO UPLOAD SPEED ISSUEMy first attempt at loading my 11,000 photos was do just do a copy of the files from my PC to the NAS.  This took a few hours to do, but once it was done, I then noticed the thumbnail status in the admin website, and it was going to take a while.  I let it run for several hours, and its performance was absolutely horrible.  I am talking about over a minute per photo.So I then re-uploaded the photos using what Synology suggests we use - the Synology Assistant Photo Uploader.  That process was certainly faster because it could use my PC's CPU to do the thumbnail process, but I still thought the performance was a bit too slow.  It was about 3 photos per minute (source photo size about 1MB).  At that rate, it would have completed in about 4 days, since my newer photos average about 3MB in size, it would take longer once it hit those larger photos.So, I did a little research and found that they use a product called ImageMagicK to create 5 thumbnails of different sizes.  (1280x, 800x, 640x, 320x, and 120x)  So I installed the same on my PC, and then wrote some CygWin scripts to go through my photo directory, and create the thumbnails on my PC.  I was able to choose a lower quality of the thumbnails to a much more reasonable number, which also saved me a bit of space on the NAS as well.  I was able to run 4 simultaneous processes, each thumbnailing different directories using the above process, and was able to generate my thumbnails in a matter of 6 hours.  Once that was done, I then zipped the thumbnails (with no compression to help with the speed of unzipping on the NAS), and then transferred a single zip per year of photos over to the NAS.  This sped up the transfer time greatly as it is much faster to transfer a few large files, than to send over 55,000 smaller files.Once the zips were on the NAS, I then wrote another shell script that I run on the NAS to unzip the file, rename each file to the proper filename (the thumbnails have a : in the filename which Windows can't handle), and then I copy the files into the proper location of the photo share.I then un-paused the thumbnail process on the NAS, and it quickly updated its count of files that needed to be processed.So given the above process, here is what I think Synology should do to improve their upload tool.1. Allow the user to chose the compression/quality rating for each of the thumbnail sizes they create.2. Allow the user to opt out of creating some of the thumbnails.  It creates 1280x, 800x, 640x, 320x, and 120x thumbnails.  I assume each is used for a different purpose.  Maybe we should be allowed to skip one or two of the 3 larger files, and have the NAS use the closest available match if the desired size is missing.3. Rename the thumbnail files so that a : is not part of the filename to make life a little easier for people who want to get the files there via other means.4. Provide the ability to do multi threaded processing when using the upload tool.If anyone is interesting in doing a similar process, here are the options I found to be good for me for the ImageMagicK software.  Of course, adjust as you see fit:convert "$filename" -resize 1280 -quality 60 -auto-orient "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_XL.jpg"convert "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_XL.jpg" -resize 800 -quality 60 "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_L.jpg"convert "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_L.jpg" -resize 640 -quality 60 "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_B.jpg"convert "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_B.jpg" -resize 320 -quality 60 "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_M.jpg"convert "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_M.jpg" -resize 120 -quality 60 "@eaDir/$filename/THUMB_S.jpg"(Once the files get on the NAS, they need to be named like: SYNOPHOTO:THUMB_XL.jpg )So is the above process something that everyone will want to do?  Most likely not.  But it is something that was important for me to be able to do, so I was glad to see that the NAS offered a Linux shell which I could run some commands through, to do this type of processing.  I will most likely still use their software upload process for converting my camera movie files, but for all large photo uploads, I will now use the scripts I wrote for my initial photo upload process.UPDATE 06/12/2012I have found one usability issue with my experience with this device so far.  I wanted to move all my music to the NAS, and then have iTunes use the mapped drive to the NAS for its storage of its library.  This did not work well at all.  If you forget the fact that I didn't find an easy way to move my existing iTunes library to another drive, the big issue I had was that when I tried to download new music from iTunes, the downloads did not work.  It failed while it tried to download and process the files.  I was left with a bunch of download.m4a audio files, non of which were able to be moved to the proper directory once the download completed, and non of which were playable.  So I had to abandon this option.  Instead, I now have to continue storing the Music on my PC, and then copy it to the NAS after it is downloaded.  I am a bit disappointed with this.  I don't know whether this issue is common to all Windows network mapped drives, or is unique to this one.  Maybe its a fault of Windows and not the drive but I won't be trying it again.
summary: Great NAS, but horrible, painfully slow photo uploading

reviewText: First, I thought I had a problem with the magnet feature. Then I remembered I had to turn on that feature in Settings.I'm using it on an iPad 2, and it fits fine, too. It's easy to "install" as well, and I prefer it to the cases that encase the whole iPad - mostly because it "seems" lighter and more streamlined this way.This case has a nice, fabric/plastic hybrid feel. It looks smart, and has an elastic stylus holder on the outside. Unlike Apple's Smart Cover, this protects both back and front of the iPad.The front cover doesn't lay as flat as I would like, though - it kind of curves up a little in the middle and the corners. I remedied this to some extent by bending the cover and corners a bit, but it's still not quite flat.The "pull" of the magnets doesn't seem that strong, so you may feel paranoid about whether it will open during transport in a bad, etc. That doesn't seem to have happened so far.Also, like other cases which use this "tab" type of stand, it feels a little unstable when standing. If you push the screen while it's standing, it's likely to tip over.It's OK in the typing orientation, though.Other thing is, using the tab takes some practice, as it starts out kind of stiff (but this is needed to keep it "tabbed", though). Hard to prop it up single-handed.Right now it's a toss-up between this andSpeck Products HandyShell Case for iPad 2 with Flip Ring (SPK-A0259), which has more gripping and standing options, but doesn't protect the front. The Targus has a better angle if you like to type (or play the Garage Band accelerometer keyboard) in landscape mode, though.Pros:Smart, outer and inner material feels nice, easy to install, auto on/off. Good typing angle. Has stylus holder.Cons:Unstable in landscape standing position. Wish cover could lie flatter or have more rigidity. Would have liked something to hold onto for better gripping. Limited standing options.My rating is based on someone wanting a slim cover with auto on/off. It's a smart-looking case but it could use some more refinement. I'd give it 3.5 stars.
summary: Nice looks and feel, with minor gripes

reviewText: I've owned and used the Sony EX51s, 71s, 75s, and now the 300s, and these are by far the best of them all.  The larger bass drivers make a huge difference in the sound, and the dynamic range overall is much better than anything I've heard before, even with traditional over-the-ear headphones.  Even with the drivers, these earbuds fit snugly and unobtrusively in your ears, and while they will try to fall out if you're working out and sweating, it's easy to just push them back in.Some people dislike the cords, which are made so that the cord to the right earbud goes around the back of your neck. They are not supposed to hang down in front like the traditional stock iPod phones.  That's why the left cord is so much shorter than the right cord.  The idea is that you can remove the earbuds from your ears (for a conversation, for example) without having them fall off, and also if one of them slides out of your ear, it won't fall off.  If you prefer the original iPod cord design, stick with another brand, but I like this design.The carrying case isn't perfect, but it's better than any I've used before.  The buds sit in a plastic tray, then you wind the cord around the outside of the tray and it slides into a squarish fabric-covered box that has a velcro closure.  It protects the earbuds and cord and it works fine for me. Speaking of the cords, these have the same ultra-thin cords found on other Sony earbuds, which has been a problem for many users in the past.  They don't tend to be as durable as thicker cords.  So far, these have held up well, but I've only had them a couple of months.  Still, even if they don't last forever, the outstanding sound outweighs any potential cord wear.I paid full retail for these earbuds, and they were worth it, but the price here is even better.  I highly recommend these phones!

For example, I owned and sold the finest active shutter glasses and IR system money could buy - 3D Vision 2.  The glasses were think, solid, felt like a million bucks and also weighed down my head and warned against cleaning the lenses should "dust" or face oil accidentally get on them.For less than a pair of that ball and chain high end 3D solution, you can invest in 2 pairs of these glasses and along with being literally as simple and straight forward as the pricey pairs were to charge and turn out, this pair allows you to flip between right eye or left eye lead 3D experience watching - what does that mean?  It means, if things in the background look like they are in front of close things, simply click the same button that turns the device on and off to remedy that.Perhaps the biggest secret weapon this pair of glasses has, is they are extremely light. Cheap feeling - for sure, but aside from actually being cheap, they hold up well and are weightless feeling to wear. They also comfortably fit glasses, at least modern smaller sized ones.At 144hz with the incredible line of 3D DLP Link Based Projectors, buying these also ensures you'll be able to watch the latest 3D movies at a rate higher than 3D movies are even filmed at, which as of Hobbit 2 was 60FPS.  These glasses deliver 144 effective refresh rate of action, so everything is smooth but not flying too fast or causing disturbances.

I love this case. It's great quality all around and there is soooo much room. It is a wide case so if you're putting it in a cabinet make sure you have room (~13 inches from side panel to side panel compared to my old standard case which was 8 inches). The 3 140mm fans move a lot of air and aren't loud. The separated compartments really lend to a minimalistic, clean build. There's a ton of room in the back with the PSU, 2x 5.25 in bays, and 5x 2.5 in SSD bays for hiding wires and components. This is a great case out of the box that has tons of room for customization and modification.Pros: SPACE! Room for at least 2 240mm radiators. Great airflow if you are air cooling. Clean/minimalistic design.Con: Wider than a typical case. Only 2x 3.5 inch drive bays (hot-swappable). Neither was an issue for me.If you have the room for this case (table/desk top, extra wide cabinet, etc) I would 100% recommend getting this.

This was the best! The Gain was more than advertised! 75' away from the transmitting source of the Interned signal was not as weak as anticipated. This is one piece of engineering genius! This works without question! This is not an amazing piece of work since it follows all of the principles of propagation/reception theory for antennae. As a retired Electrical/Electronic engineer, their principles are fully explained and designed to work and I agree to the fullest, not only with their design, but with their whole principle! I recommend this antenna for exactly what they advertise no matter what! It works exactly as they say! What more do you want?
summary: Bolo Brands N Wireless 18dbi 2.4GHz Wifi High Gain Antenna 18 dB 2.4 GHz...

OK, first off, I didn't run the iPod back up to the dash. I figured this is taking the place of a CD changer, which sits in the trunk anyway, right?I was nervous about the install, reading all these 8-page instruction sheets people had done up, and when I finally went exploring, I found the CD-changer cable right where everyone said it was, behind the right side panel behind the back seat.There are two clips you push down and the panel pops out. The cables in the bottom of the opening include the CD changer cables, taped to some other cables down there to keep them out of the way. Pull the tape off to free the cables(there are two) and plug them into the adapter cable. Plug the other end of that cable into the adapter. plug the OTHER cable into the adapter, and plug the other end of that into the iPod. Tuck the whole thing back into that compartment and snap the cover back on.Go get in the driver seat, turn the key and switch the radio from radio to CD, then switch again. You're now listening to your iPod.You'll probably want to go back now and get the iPod again and take it inside to make some playlists.Name them BMW1 thru BMW5, and they'll show up as CD's 1 thru 5 on the radio display when you hit the radio station preset buttons. You can skip to the next/previous songs on the playlists the same way you skip next/previous track on CD.Sound is fine, and I don't have the music jumping whenever I go over bumps (something I'm prone to do in my Mini.I'm very happy with it.
summary: Mini Cooper install was ridiculously simple.

reviewText: This is a great price for a certified HDMI cable. Some HDMI cables sell for as much as $85 and the truth is you just don't need to spend that much money on a cable as it will make no perceivable difference in image quality since the information is digital. The one thing that can affect signal quality is distance, but if you are looking at buying a 6 foot cable you have nothing to worry about.For longer cables consider one that has an active booster.The connectors are built well, but if you are going to be constantly plugging and unplugging them you may want to look at something a bit more heavy-duty, but for normal home use these are fine. These cables are smaller in gauge than some cables, but that in no way affects image quality, so again for everyday home use these are great.I use these cables to connect my PS3 to my 37" LED-LCD and have a great 1080p quality image.

One of the clear advantages of netbook computers is their ultra portability. You can take them on business trips on which you might otherwise regret lugging a 7 pound laptop.I recently decided to replace an eight year old HP Omnibook with an Acer Aspire One and needed a small case to move my new netbook around the landscape. I purchased one at Fry's that was made for 10" models, but my Acer was just a skosh too big to fit in it. There are plenty of neoprene bags available for a few dollars, but I wanted something that would stand up to travel and let me fit a few small items along with the netbook.Enter the Case Logic eSling, made specifically for ultra portable PCs.Talk about a perfect solution! This bag is made from tough nylon, has an adjustably long messenger-type sling, and has lots of pockets! There's one, of course, just for your netbook and it is ingeniously designed with two long interior felt strips that grip the computer and keep even small 9 inch computers from sliding around inside. Then there is a larger pocket in front that serves as a personal items pocket, with specific places for business cards, pens, a cell phone or ipod and sunglasses. This larger pocket can accommodate letter size folders or a spiral bound notebook and your charger. There's another exterior pocket that is perfect for a magazine or your Kindle, then there is a large flap that covers it all that also has a larger zipper pocket, great for a wallet.The outside of the case is stain- and scuff-resistant black, but the inside is a burgundy colored material that makes it easy to find things. No more fishing around trying to find where you put your keys in the dark interior of your bag!The quality of this bag is what sets it apart from virtually every other netbook case out there: it is very well constructed of expensive looking materials. This bag may cost more than cheaper bags, but it will outlast them by years. The stitching is reinforced at strategic spots, the zippers are strong and durable, and even the zipper pulls look like they'll last forever. My only quibbles here are that the strap, while light weight, is less impressive than the rest of the bag, and there is no rubber feet protection on the bottom of the case where you are likely to set it down.You won't find that the bag is large enough to replace your briefcase or backpack unless you really travel light. But for quick day trips, it is a great solution for carrying your small computer and a few other items. You will love the quality and thoughtful design of this bag.

There are many reasons that I really like these cd/dvd storage cases. The cases are a durable clear plastic so it makes it very simple to identify a video game or dvd movie. I like how thin they are so my huge collections of video games and dvd movies take up far less space than with my previous storage cases. The little lock on top keeps the disc secure.The cases look very stylish and look much better than the standard square shaped cases. I had originally purchased a case of 50 to try them out but ended up liking them so much that I purchased another 400 for all my games and dvd movies ^_^ None of the cases were defective and I'm very happy with my purchase!I highly recommend these cases if you have limited space for your games and movie collections.
summary: Great for video games and dvd movies

This drive found its way into an older Sony Vaio laptop that breathed new life into an already fairly fast computer. There is nothing better than super fast boots and programs starting in almost a blink of an eye. Once you've tried an SSD, you'll wonder why you sat through all that time waiting on a mechanical drive.There are so many benchmarks on SSD's pitting them against each other. At the end of the day, this is so much faster than a mechanical drive, in the real world the differences between drives is almost impossible to detect. I bought this drive at a deep discount. If I were paying full price, or there wasn't a sale, I would buy a Samsung 840 EVO.The cautionary tale, these drives can fail. If you are saving important things on these drives, be sure to back them up routinely.This Crucial drive is a bare bones drive that has nothing additional in the box - you get the drive, that's all.Here are some detailed installation instructions:Size matters with these drives. If you are putting this in a desktop, a 240Gb drive would probably be the right size. Add a mechanical drive for data and files and you will be super happy. Install applications in the default C drive, and make sure that any files they use for data or temporary things goes to a mechanical drive. In a laptop, 240Gb might push the limits a little bit - a 500Gb will give you more room before you have to use an external drive. On my MacBook Pro, 240Gb was perfectly fine for over a year.My frame of reference is a number of SSD's. My first was the Samsung 840 with 240Gb used on a desktop computer for the boot drive and application installs. My second drive was a SanDisk 240Gb that went belly up after about eight months (that drive was in a MacBook Pro - SanDisk replaced the drive under warranty so it went into an ancient Acer Aspire One netbook running XP, and darn that machine is now super fast). I also have a Crucial M500, 240Gb drive in a Sony Vaio laptop. Being totally honest, there is absolutely no difference in apparent speed or utility with any of these four drives. They are all lightning fast. If this were a critical computer, I would buy the Samsung. If this was a play around computer, I'd buy something based on price (the Acer is a goofing around computer that I can risk it going belly up again and won't cry).This Crucial SSD is a bare bones drive. The box contains two items, the drive and a plastic spacer, nothing else. If you have done an SSD upgrade before and have the SATA to USB adapter (or a SATA drive enclosure), or are going for a clean install of the new drive; this is the drive to purchase.Once you have done the upgrade, do not repurpose the mechanical drive - simply tuck it away for the day the SSD fails. That is the fastest, easiest way to recover a failed SSD - swap the drive out. The first step after the upgrade is to do a full backup of the new drive and start using a backup strategy - TimeMachine (Mac), Second Copy (PC), and / or CrashPlan (off line backup). Be religious about your backups - do them daily.Critical first step before buying an SSD is to check how much data is on your mechanical drive. If it is less than the 246GB, the drive will work fine. If there is more than 246GB of data on the larger mechanical drive, either delete things or buy a larger SSD. The job took about four hours to do the upgrade. This was the first time I've upgraded / cloned a drive, so I worked slowly. I could probably get this done in about 3 hours now.How to perform the installation (Crucial doesn't pack much in the way of instructions or have much information on their website - you kind of have to find this stuff searching the internet):If this is a clean install - bolt in the hard drive.This might get a little complicated in a desktop; Crucial does not pack an adapter tray with the drive. You're in luck if your case has a 2 1/2 inch bay. If not, you'll have to buy an adapter plate. This OCZ plate will work just fine:OCZ Solid State Drive 3.5-Inch Adaptor Bracket 2 OCZACSSDBRKT2. Boot the computer on the installation disc and follow the instructions. Literally, there is nothing else to do. An SSD is no different from a mechanical drive for a clean install. Win7 recognizes that the drive is an SSD and adjusts the settings appropriately.If this is cloning, or copying over the exact mechanical drive to the SSD:Find cloning software. With a Macintosh, use Carbon Copy Cloner. The software is free to use as a trial to simply clone a hard drive. I didn't need any of the other functions, so I just used the trial software. SuperDuper is another Macintosh alternative. Macrium and Paragon are excellent free packages for PC's.Next you have to connect the SSD to the computer via USB. This can be done with a SATA to USB adapter. With bare bones drives, either you can buy a universal SATA to USB adapter (somewhat expensive) or a SATA drive enclosure (a lot less expensive). So go figure, it is cheaper to buy an enclosure than a simple cable. An enclosure is really a good idea - your old mechanical drive can go someplace useful after the swap - it can become a good external hard drive with an enclosure (once you are confident the new SSD works). What are the price differences? A good USB2 enclosure can be had for $8. A USB2 adapter cable is around $15. A USB3 adapter cable is around $20-29.Once the adapter is connected to the SSD, plug it into a USB port on the computer. In the world of PC and Mac the drive has to be formatted. For PC, format the drive with NTFS (use the Storage > Disc Management portion of Computer Management (right click over the My Computer icon and choose Manage)). For a Mac there are some odd little steps to follow. When you plug in the drive the Disk Utility will automatically run. You have to format the drive and then go through a special HD backup partition step. Carbon Copy Cloner describes every step perfectly. Just follow those instructions.Launch the cloning software. Now comes the fun part, waiting and waiting and waiting. It took just over two hours to copy 199GB of data from my hard drive over to the SSD. It's important to understand that the SSD and the computer will get pretty darn warm while this is running. Given that it took so darn long to copy the data, and I wasn't going to format my mechanical drive right away, I didn't bother verifying the copy.Once the clone is done, shut down the computer, remove the old boot drive, and install the new SSD (dirt dog simple on a PC). On a MacBook Pro this wasn't too complicated (there are instructions all over the internet on how to open up a Mac to replace the hard drive). I pulled all the small stainless steel screws and lifted off the cover. The hard drive is to the right of the battery (the big long black thing). Be careful about not touching anything inside the computer and you don't have to unplug the battery (looking around, unplugging that thing looked more complicated than I wanted to tackle). The hard drive is held in with a clamp (like those stocks used in Colonial times to punish people - the hole for the head and two for the hands). You only have to remove the one clamp that is farthest away from the computer body. The drive will now slip out of the other clamp. Pull off the SATA connector. Remove the four mounting screws that are Number 6 Torx. There isn't really a good way to remove these without a Torx screwdriver (the screws are really tight and pliers around the screw might mess things up, you might MacGyver it, but it could go wrong).Mount the new SSD. Screw in the four Torx screws on the side of the drive. If you really want to make sure this is a secure mount, place the self-adhesive plastic spacer on the top of the drive (this is the black and red SanDisk label side), and you can remove the little plastic tab for pulling up on the drive from the old mechanical drive. Reconnect the SATA cable. Replace the stocks clamp. Replace the back cover and the stainless screws.Voila - the work is now done. Start up the computer. You will be ultra-disappointed on the first start up. Somehow the Mac got a bit confused and it took a couple of minutes to start up the first time. Once the system checking and hardware stuff was updated, and my desktop appeared, the computer was instantly available. Boot time is much faster now. I rarely power down my Mac, but cold boot a fairly fast 2 minutes with the mechanical drive. Once the desktop appeared it took another thirty seconds or so to actually be useable. With the SSD gray screen is around one minute and once the desktop appears every single program is instantly available.The big win with this SSD in Mac land is how fast applications start. Safari is virtually instant, blink of an eye. IPhoto is a little longer, maybe 10 seconds (it used to take a good 30 seconds to get rolling). IMovie is incredibly fast now. I use Microsoft Office 2011 and really hated starting up any of that software on the old drive. Now after the SSD I click on Word, the program is running within about 10 seconds. I can wait that long.The only hitch I ran into was with Microsoft Office. For some reason, once I cloned the drive, Microsoft decided I had a new installation. I had to enter my product key again. Lucky for me I could find the key. Before cloning the drive, you might want to look around for the product key in Office someplace. And actually the second time I've done the upgrade to an SSD, Microsoft was no longer happy and I had to remove the software and completely reinstall it. Downloading from the Microsoft site and asking for my Key back wasn't too difficult.This is one darn fast drive. The only thing to watch is drive space. Macs tend to throw files all over the place and not care a lot about how much storage space is used. They are then difficult to prune down to get rid of no longer needed files. I chose to copy everything over from my old drive to the new without any housecleaning beforehand. I did find a set of movies I can get rid of, leaving me with about 60 GB of free space.With an SSD, an external drive will be critical. I don't have a lot of trouble with that because I currently use a 2TB external drive for my Time Machine. Big files can sit on that drive instead of locally.I happened to have all the tools I needed for this migration. That was super lucky; I just finished building a PC with a Samsung 840 drive. If I didn't have those tools, this drive would be really hard to install. Honestly, if you don't have the tools, the Samsung is a much better, cheaper choice. Yeah, OK, somebody ran some benchmarks and says some of these drives are faster than others. That's benchmarks, not real world. At some point, a blink of an eye is fast; half a blink of an eye doesn't appear to be faster. Bottom line, you'll never see the difference with real files and real work between the drives.This is an excellent bare bones hard drive. If you've never experienced an SSD, it is the world's best upgrade you can do to speed up your computer.Hard Drive Enclosure:Vantec NexStar TX 2.5-Inch SATA to USB 2.0 External Hard Drive EnclosureSATA to USB3 Adapter cableSyba USB 3.0 to SATA Device Adapter Cable with AC Adapter (SY-ADA20079)Anker Uspeed USB 3.0 to SATA 3ft Converter Adapter Cable for 2.5 inch/3.5 inch Hard Drive Disk HDD and SSD, Power Adapter includedCable Kit USB2 SATA and IDE:Vantec CB-ISATAU2 SATA/IDE to USB 2.0 Adapter Supports 2.5-Inch, 3.5-Inch, 5.25-Inch Hard Disk Drives (Black)

reviewText: I tried several kinds of headphones for working out and specifically running.  Earbuds of all varieties no matter the promise always fell out of my ears.  So I gave these a try.  The sound is pretty good - though there IS room for improvement.  But why do you need amazing sound when you're running anyway?  The best part is the comfort and security.  These do not move with extensive physical activity without causing a headache by grabbing too hard.  The bungee on the cord is helpful when you accidentally snag the cord on something, which I have done.  And the woven cord literally NEVER tangles (Apple should take a lesson... ).

I have read a lot of negative reviews of this camera here. Having used my own for nine months, my conclusion is that some folks could take a picture with a pinhole camera and get results like Ansel Adams, and then others might possess all the high dollar gear in the world and still get pictures of their fingers, and out of focus pictures at that. Like most folks reading this, I probably fall somewhere in the middle of that grouping.So. This camera is the digital equivalent of an Instamatic, which is to say, you point and you shoot. It has a 4x optical zoom that works quite well, it has a nice bright display which accurately portrays what you will get on your finished shot, and it has lots of options you may or may not find useful; fact is, most of us will do little with it other than take what we used to call "snapshots". To each his own. But if you take the time to work at it, you can get some mighty fine snapshots with this piece. This is our family's third Cyber-Shot and I've found it's a worthy successor to its predecessors.

I recently purchased this case to protect my HTC G2 smartphone.  Having seen my children and grandchildren drop their phones and iTouches, with the resulting cracked screens, I wanted the best in protection for my smartphone which also has a glass screen.  Mind you I am very careful with my stuff.Yesterday when getting ready for a bike ride I dropped my phone on the floor of my storage shed.  I was horrified that it was broken.  The phone worked perfectly after falling about three feet.  I then proceeded to begin my bike ride.  I carry my phone in a small case attached to my bike.  After a half hour, a woman pulled her car out in front of my bike causing me to swerve which resulting in my loosing control of my bike.  In the process, I had failed to zip the phone into the small bag where it is carried and the phone flew out and skidded along the asphalt.  Once again I expected that the phone would be damaged but it was not.  Part of the protective case did pop off during the fall of the phone to the asphalt but again it was not damaged at all.  What are the odd of dropping my phone twice within a half hour?  I was so impressed that I ordered one of these cases for my wife's iPhone.  This product works as advertised!!
summary: Otterbox Commuter Series - Awesome, Saved My Phone From Damage

reviewText: Consumer Reports placed these at the bottom of the list of one of their recent center channel speaker comparisons, and I COULD NOT AGREE MORE. Lower costing speakers performed far better. In some calculated tests of my own, I found these had far less range and "presence" than other major brand speakers. I have a Yamaha NS-C444 speaker that provides full, lifelike sound, and handles plenty of power.This Bose center channel speaker was a major disappointment, and far from representative of their generally outstanding audio components.
summary: These sound terrible. Bottom of the list in independent tests

reviewText: So my Panasonic rp-ht480c headphones suddenly started to short out on me about a week ago after working great for 6 months. This was rather upsetting for me and both my parents as my parents paid $55 for them as a Christmas gift. Headphones this expensive (on a lightning deal, no less) should last longer than 6 months. Well I originally was looking at the V-Moda Crossfade LP but just didn't wanna pay that much. Well I had seen these before so I decided to look at em again and lo and behold they are now discounted to 29.99 due to them being discontinued. I ordered them and got them in 2 days with Amazon Prime 2 day shipping, and they have blown me away. What a steal! They have a nice, premium look and feel about them, and I like the detachable cable, splitter and carrying pouch. Also, the sound quality is as good as you will find at 29.99. In fact, these may well be the best headphones 30 bucks will buy. Unlike the Panasonics, which required a solid day's worth of break in time to get good sound quality, these sounded crystal clear right out of the box and the bass is clear and well balanced-they sound better than the Panasonics ever did. So, if you are thinking of getting more expensive headphones like the beats solo hd's for instance, save a lot of money and get these, which have better clarity and only a little less bass-leading to, in my opinion, a better overall sound quality in these. Hopefully these will last longer than 6 months.

I needed an MP3 player to take to the gym, and to just listen to around the house. I didnt want a super expensive one because I tend to beat up my electronics especially if I am wearing them! I purchased the SanDisk Sansa c250 because it looked like it was easy to use, had a big enough display and it was a good price. I have been really satisfied with it so far and I have had it for almost two years now. I love the display on it, its bright enough and easy to read what ever song/artist is playing. It clearly tells you how much battery life is left, and when you do have to charge it, it doesnt take long at all.My only complaint is that the way the menus are set up is a bit confusing, and for some reason no matter what song I left off on it always starts up playing the same song! I dont know how to fix that!I have replaced the headphones that came with it a couple of times, those never last as long as I want them too!

reviewText: I've been using Zalman products from the time they hit the market. They were the first company to figure out that efficient quiet cooling is done with heat-pipes, copper and large slow moving fans. So when everyone else started copying their designs i remained brand loyal with them. All of their coolers are made in Korea, and the quality shows over the Chinese garbage.This cooler is no different, and does a great job of cooling an i7-860. In a Zalman HD160XT case, the CPU doesn't go over 38C, even when all 4 cores are at 60%.The only reason i'm giving this 4 stars is because Zalman really needs to offer this as an optional PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) 4-pin fan for Intel chips. Having to use the clunky fan controller might be okay if you're slumming with an AMD chip, but if you're running an Intel and a decent mobo that will control the speed of all the fans in the case this makes no sense.If you have an Intel chip/board, you're probably better off with the 9500 (Zalman Computer Noise Prevention System with Silent Fan Pure Copper Heatsink CPU Cooler CNPS9500AT) that comes with the 4-pin connector.This is too bad because otherwise the 9700 should be a better option all the way around. The amount of copper mass is enough to keep any decent chip from overheating even if the fan fails. The bigger fan (compared to the 9500) means that it can move slower and near silent and still deal with the worst gaming demands.And if you read any review that claims that this cooler is loud, i wouldn't take it too seriously. If you use the clunky fan controller you can turn the fan almost completely off, and well within the realm of silent. When the fan was running at full voltage, my cpu was @ 34C, when i turned it way down to the point of being almost inaudible the temp went to 35C. So the copper mass makes this cooler very efficient, so it really takes very little air flow to make this thing work.But seriously Zalman, you need to offer this with a 4-pin non-LED fan. Then it would be the ideal cooler for anyone whose case will not fit the crazy bigZalman CNPS9900A LED Ultra Quiet CPU Cooler. If you're case will fit the 9900, or if you are willing to mod your case, take a serious at that one because if the fan on that one ever failed it probably wouldn't even effect the temp of the cpu.
Love the quality.  Takes a lot of beating on my keyring, but doesn't break off like so many USB keys.  Wish it was USB3, but not enough of an issue to lose a star.Well worth the price.
