The soundbar sounds pretty good for TV and movies (though I didn't expect a ton there), but it's a huge upgrade over the TV speakers.  It sounds phenomenal for music, far better than anything that size has any right to sound.  The Sonos software makes it really easy to set up, and to stream music from my phone, network, or the internet, and I've found myself using that much more than I expected simply because it's so easy to do.  I was initially worried about having to run everything through my TV to switch things, since that would create a cabling mess with my setup, but I was able to get a four-port HDMI/optical switcher from monoprice that splits off a separate optical signal based on HDMI inputs, so I'm using that box to switch inputs and then sending the HDMI output to my TV and the optical output to the playbar.

I have to respectfully disagree with the poor review from Wrestling NX before I give my opinion. The Windows are actually not Windows at all, they are called Palettes and are not supposed to be resized, otherwise anything that needs resizing, IE the image iteself can in fact be sized or viewed in the bird's eye (awesome feature). All of the Palettes can be maximized and minimized, not uncommon with Image Editors really. Lastly, the reason it looks different was not because Nikon wanted to confuse us, but rather because the previous version (awful) was created solely by Nikon, whereas this version was a collaborative effort between Nikon and Nik Software (no relation). Smart move since Camera makers are notorious for making terrible Image Editors.My opinion on this software is high, spent 30 days with the trial and then bought it I thought it was so good. It is very easy to make a crappy image look wonderful, and a great image look even better. Extremely intuitive, and user friendly palettes; standout features are three-fold-Control Points as a means to edit specifics. Allows real control over the  image and it is very logical to make impactful changes with this feature.-Edit List to show you what you have done without disturbing the original. Great because you check & uncheck what you have done and see with your eye if it was the correct choice.-Raw editing is great, no compression so your starting with great source material the way you shot it from the camera. This is really where this software shines.I would suggest spending a little time with the manual, especially if you are mostly familiar with Photochop. This software is not a chopshop, it is for balancing, and enhancing digital photographs, this is what it is designed and targeted to do, not compete head-to-head with PS. The workflows are great and easy to understand and don't interfere with anything.My only knock on this software is it requires at a bare minimum 1GB of RAM to flow, if you want it to really move plan on 2GB, it's a hog. But all software is bloated these days (particularly image editors) so I am not removing a star for this.Buy and enjoy, it will improve your editing experience.1/17/06- One MAJOR point/drawback I want to make about this software..I advanced myself into shooting and editing in RAW since I learned everything else pretty well in this software. I just want to warn anyone thinking of this software, and please PLEASE!, HEED MY ADVICE HERE. If you don't have a MINIMUM, an absolute MINIMUM! if 2GB of RAM, raw mode will crawl to the point it is so slow and innefficient it becomes not worth it. I have 1GB of RDRAM and I switched back to jpeg mode because it was awful in RAW mode. Would have loved to have had that functionality, but I am not upgrading my entire PC in order to do it.  Too bad it is so bloated.
summary: Excellent Software-Excellent Usability-uses ALOT of SYTEM RESOURCES!

reviewText: The lens hood is not removable so you can't use filters with it. Sony really missed the boat on this one. As most will use this for landscape photography where filters such as graduated ND and Polarized are essential. I did find a solution by using a Cokin P setup with a 67mm ring for a slip on filter [...]. Still this is bulky and cumbersome, and only allows the use of one filter at a time. It also adds expense of buying a new set of filters rather then being able to use my 49mm filters that work with my other lenses. It seems that Sony should have been smart enough to have made this with 49mm threads and a screw on Lens hood, but unfortunately that is not the case. -2 starsIt only works with the 16mm lenses -1 star+4 stars for optics as the optics are good for this price range+1 star as I have not found anything better for wide angle shots with the NEXThus my 3 star rating.

It runs even modern games at a very good and high speed and very cool temperatures.This card is one of the best in the market while looking Price vs Performance, so it gives a lot for the buck.Pros: Excellent price vs Performance, Excellent iddle (35C) and load (65) temperatures, Very good build quality, Very easy to install, Runs games at excellent speeds.Cons: None I can think of.

reviewText: I bought this a couple of days and at first I was wary until I finally installed the wireless on the machine.Before then, i had bought a 2gb sd card and put some pdfs on there. I was disappointed when the machine wouldn't read them initially and soon became a little frustrated.After the wireless update to whatever the lookbook is supposed to be from, the lookbook had a new kind of shelving system for the book. I want to figure out how to get rid of some of the books on there (it came with 25 old books), but other than that, i do like the way it feels and reads.I had to turn a couple of pdfs sideways to get a good screen but most times it's pretty darn good.The only thing i wish is that it had an audio function, but it's color and that's awesome in itself.Now i did read some of the reviews and the buttons could be just a tad bigger, but other wise once you get used to the side buttons, it's really okay to deal with for the price i paid. the battery life is only four hours but i'm cool about that. reviewText: I bolted this without the foot to my desk with the included hardware. Had to drill a 9/16" hole in desk and install. I could have used the foot and not had to do any of this but I wanted it to look clean. It's very stable. I love it. I'm using it right now.

As others have noted, this battery connects and fits in the UPS housing perfectly. The pulling tape on mine was also on the wrong side, but it is not a problem to edge the battery out of the housing without it. I checked that carefully, so I did not bother to reposition the tape which may or may not have stayed in reliable position over time, once removed.On the initial 24 hour charge, it ran my Dell workstation with two hard drives an i7 processor and an advanced graphics card, two monitors(22" CRT and 24" LCD respectively), modem and router for at least 10 minutes, while working continuously in Photoshop(I restored power thereafter) which is about what would be expected, given the estimated  particular VA rating of this load on my UPS1400 unit.The only thing about which I obviously can't comment is on how long in the future the battery will perform to backup time specification; however, as noted previously, there is a 2 year warranty which I believe is the same as the APC battery for which you will pay about 50% more, seemingly needlessly. This is my second replacement battery since I bought the unit about 6 years ago. The first replacement was an "APC" battery, which, as mentioned in other reviews, is not made by APC,  confirmed by a telephone call to their customer service department. While they, of course, strongly recommend replacement with "their" batteries, they had no rejoinder to my suggestion that the aftermarket batteries may well be just as good in quality.According to my research, American Battery seems to be a well established company with a high rating, and a very diverse inventory. I also doubt that Amazon would sell third party products that wind up being a source of complaints and demands for refunds!BTW, if having working time according to expectations from the specifications is important for your workflow, please don't rely entirely on the periodic autoload battery test which the APC units do for you, especially after the battery is >2 years old.  As the battery becomes weak, and nears the end of its life, if you have a power outage when the "green light" is still on, you may only get 30 seconds or a minute of backup, instead of 10 minutes or more, which is exactly what happened to me recently. So, please profit from this experience.  Interestingly, although the unit had passed all the self tests prior to that outage, giving a false sense of security, after I subsequently recharged the old battery for 24 hours and then did a MANUAL load test, the battery failed.I see no reason not to recommend this unit highly, with the sole limitation aforedescribed, as a cost effective RBC 7 battery replacement.

I purchased both the Brainwavz Peridot and Zirconia (this item) around the same time. The Peridot is clearly better in my eyes. It's more stable especially for larger headphones. Sure - it's a plastic version of the very expensive wood stands with the same shape, but frankly the quality is very good. I understand that some people are beside themselves that Brainwavs would put their logo all over these stands - but I can't figure out why that's such an issue.The Zirconia is a good stand, and I use it for some lighter headphones, but due to the way it balances - it's putting a crease in my headband on those cans. I've had good and not so good experiences with Logitech products. Some of them work flawlessly out of the box and continue working for years. But there have been a few times when I've purchased something and I got the sense that Logitech had overreached. So I am happy to report that with the Logitech Alert 750i we have a simple to install, relatively easy to use indoor security system. The camera image is quite good, though in low light you will discover that facial features are difficult to ascertain. The included software, which I thought easy to install, worked quite well right from the start.I am fortunate in that the necessary power outlet, used to transmit the camera image, is easily accessible to my home network. This is a possible problem area so make sure you have the requisite power outlet within easy access to your computer/computer network. The internal 2 gig mini-SD card records 6 to 7 days of video which is more than sufficient for most needs. Because of its ease of installation and use, the copious amount of included connections, mounts, cables and software, and the incredible ease with which you can expand your monitoring activities, I can enthusiastically recommend this system for home use.
summary: The finest Logitech system I've ever used

reviewText: I haven't been able to find a direct source of sunlight strong enough to charge this product, so I will have to rate it on its capabilities as a charger pack alone.It does charge products as advertised, it just takes a really long time to charge. It works great for charging products with low capacities (like an MP3 player or old-school Kindle) but has a negligible effect on higher use products (like smartphones.)I found that it charges my Sansa Clip fully in less than 30 minutes. However, when I use it to charge my Galaxy S3 I don't really notice a difference. If I turn my phone off or don't use it, I'll get a recharge rate of about 1-2% every 10 minutes. If I use my phone while charging with this device, my battery will still go down, but at a much slower rate.Personally, I would recommend buying this product if you do a lot of "day trips" where you will be away from any charging source for 12-18 hours at a time but can still charge this via usb at night. (It uses the same cord as most Android smart phones.) I would not recommend this for long trips or if you plan on relying on the solar charger to work.This is a good product for the price of $20-30. But I would not spend more than that amount.
summary: Good for what it is. Pay attention to the MAh size.

reviewText: I love these little headphones.  They are lightweight and have great sound.  I get the best use out of them riding on the bus and at the gym.  They seal out other noises, so they may not be completely suitable in situations where you still want to be able to hear your surroundings.  The only minor complaint I have is that the main control button is rather stiff which results in uncomfortable pressure in your ear and a very loud click.  I am definitely happy with my purchase.

reviewText: I have been using a Nikon P500 for the past couple of years and have been very happy with ability of the camera to respond to such a wide range of situations.  However, it was not really capable of all of the things that I wanted to be able to do with it.  Night shots were definitely in the "so-so" category.Many years ago I had a Pentax film camera that I loved until it was stolen.  So, when this camera became available with such a wide range lens, I just had to give it a try.Here is what I like about it:1.  If you just want to start taking pictures and are not quite ready to start changing settings, set the camera to the auto mode and you will be MORE than pleased with the results.  This camera far outperforms my prior Nikon in the auto mode.  Of course, this is a much more expensive camera, but it is nice that you can just start using it have great results!2.  Flexibility!  This camera is capable of just about anything that you want of it.  The settings are easy to work with and the symbols actually make sense.3.  Contrary to some comments, the included kit lens does a GREAT job!  The zoom is very smooth and the auto focus is quick and precise.  I have taken several macro shots (2 feet) with max zoom and the clarity is superb!  (keep in mind that you need to use a tripod if you want clarity with this type of picture).4.  The camera has a very nice feel to it and is very solid and does not feel plastic like.  The comparable Nikon and Cannon camera felt very inexpensively built compared to this camera.  I can very easily one hand this camera without issues.5.  The 16.3 MP camera delivers very nice pictures with plenty of ability to crop to be able to come out with a fantastic shot.6.  The battery lasts a VERY long time!  I have taken over 800 pictures and not had to replace the battery.What I did not like:1.  The included software is only certified for Windows 7.  When I contacted Pentax, they seemed puzzled as to why I would want to have the software certified for Windows 8 64 bit OS.  Guess it really does not matter since I have not used their software and have not had any issues with my current software (Photoshop and Corel).2.  The Pentax support people did not think that anyone would want to connect their camera to an IPAD and as such stated that it was not supported.  For the record, it works just great with my current generation Ipad and the Ipad mini.  Makes it very easy in the field to tell what type of shots you really took.  Just use the lightening to USB connector to connect to your camera cable and download the pictures.  Great while in the field to ensure your camera stays water tight and dirt free.Overall, I am very pleased with this camera and the Pentax support folks were quick to respond, even if they seem a bit in the dark about using something other than a computer to work with pictures.I would definitely recommend this camera to anyone looking for a entry to mid level digital SLR.
summary: Pentax K-5 II DSLR DA 18 - 135mm WR lens kit

reviewText: This camera was so inexpensive, I thought I would try it, and toss it if it didn't work. It worked as soon as it was connected. The video is very good. It works well with Skype.

I looked for sometime for a head unit for my 86 Porsche 944, it was time to update my DEH-P5200 from 2002, I saw this unit sometime ago.. however I try and wait till whatever something is going to replace goes 'south' but in this case the unit that replaced the ole 5200 just looked stupid in my console..Aesthetically this unit looks right at home in the console..kinda mimics the over all look and feel of the original Blaupunkt, I 'wanted' an Alpine in it for sometime..however the looks of this unit in addition to its feature set of multiple Hidden SD/USB/Input Jacks really steered my choice.... It looks very cool but obviously not in a hyped up teenagers spaced out gadget way...It also has a VERY shallow install depth, and in the case of some modern cars it allows all those USB Cables ample room without worrying about crushing them, and better cooling...At the time I received the unit Parrot is working on another update to its software, it does run an early vsn of android; 1.5. It's only run on the bench, I'll be doing a dash recovering/gauge cleaning in addition to installing this unit to route the cables to hidden locations...It came with a Ipod cable [a major plus because many simply make you buy the cable] GlobalSat BU-353 USB GPS Receiver with magnetic bottom, Microphone and a simple USB Extension Cable to facilitate connecting a USB drive/3G/4G Dongle without pulling the unit out and it also has a SD Slot behind the Jog wheel half of the faceplate.the SD slot, compared to all the devices I use has to be the easiest and fumble free to insert/remove, a simple click in addition to the recessed channel make it a snap..the faceplate removes/installs equally easy, and of all the units in the past that have had the removable faceplate, this one was well thought out... Begin by placing the right side of it in to the unit and at once amagnet grabs it, then simply push the left side in and its engaged.. should you be interrupted and not fully engage the faceplate the magnet has it. The faceplate once installed has almost no room to "wiggle" when pushing buttons, something that always erked me with my others. Once removed the weight and "feel" of it is solid, like holding a block of aluminum. The buttons are just the right size for large fingers and have just the right feedback. The jog wheel doesn't respond to very rapid turning, if so it will respond once in every few notches. It didn't take me too long to learn the way it navigated when browsing the 'home' menu, your jog wheel controls all up/down left/right movements and the submenu button is to its right and the wheel center is your "Enter" button.Another reviewer had stated a problem with 'syncing' contacts... that would be a singular issue with that user.. headunits that support phone connection will use a "push" feature of the BT standard to add your contacts to the headunit at connection, the manual also explains how to send only contacts you wish to have on the headunit.** Since this review installed an Offline mapping app that has trip logging and reports back to my servers, installed Navigon, a speedtrap/radar app, FTP and a general bearing/heading app with mph.. It also recognizes USB Keyboards [have one on order to use in the car for programming and logins] USB Hubs work well with it, and I've setup USB to LAN interface to AP, [wifi dongles don't work on the current release. I don't need the 3g capacity but I do want to be able to access the unit from home to allow map updating & audio transfer.. having made batch files to update USB drives on the PC I adapted them to FTP media playlist changes, maps and apps to it from inside the house..and if your a power txt'r there is a paid feature [again if your going the route of BT DUN, tethering or 3/4G dongle] that provides speech to txt by subscription...In my heading i left a 'but' however having been tooling around with the unit I am so far VERY happy that it is a unit that has some growth potential to handle other hardware and the potential for great uncomplicated driver aides..when needed..One word of caution.. if your hoping that you can tether easily.. Do your research on your cell/droid cell AND Cell plan, many carriers charge you 2 times for internet.. they call it web when Ya use it ON your phone.. DATA when you want to tether and charge Extra for it.... there are ways around it, but if your just an avg user be cautious... My phone manufacturer specs state that it has the capacity to do the "bluetooth D.U.N." [dail up networking] but the carrier has locked that feature out.

This is a no-brainer to buy if you're looking for a USB flash drive.  You simply cannot beat the value of it.  I've had mine well over a year now, and it still works perfect.  Some USB drives are difficult to use because they have small slide devices and buttons you need to press, to slide out the USB.  You also worry about breaking them because they are so small, and usually stick out.  But with this, it couldn't be easier to slide out.  Not only is it easy to use, it has a huge amount of space on it - you can fit just about anything in there.  Another great feature is the secure attachment; it won't break off.  I've used many different types of USB flash drives and this one is by far the best.  I highly recommend this!

I work mostly between my old iMac and my somewhat newer MacBook. I publish 3 different newsletters and find transferring information between the 2 Macs  is simple and fast. It is also great just used as a backup. Easier to find files on the flash drive than searching the 2 Macs.

and this set is great for that too.I have been incredibly pleased with other AmazonBasics accessories I own, and this set is no exception.The Wall Charger is compact, and in addition to plugging this cable, I was able to use it with the cable for my Kindle, and that charged great.The travel charger easily plugs into any of the "cigarette lighter" plugs in my vehicle.  I particularly appreciate that there is a little light on the charger, so I do know if it is getting power.The cable is a great length (over a yard) and I tried using it with not only my iPod Touch, but an iPad, and a Nano.  As expected, it worked with all of those.  A bonus for me with the length of this cord is that I could use the travel charger that is in the middle seat of our van, and the device can still be used in the front seat.The stylus?  It works fine, but I simply do not anticipate using this with any regularity with my Touch.  I'm giving it to my kids for use with their iPad, but I expect it will end up in the seat cushions or otherwise lost.The stylus wasn't something I was interested in anyway... it is the package deal of the cable and both chargers that got me.The packaging is wonderful.  I love packages I can easily get into and use.

reviewText: Most of the cat5e cables that have failed on me were the silly latches getting broken off. Now I always try to get the cables with the nice anti-snag boots. Works fine and lasts a long time.
If feels kind of cheap with lightweight plastic, but gets the job done.  I can now connect my directtv receiver, wireless media player and netflix device all to my network at a remote tv.

If you buy these for the Android feature, be sure to check the download site (Google Play) to see if there is a version that has a prayer of working with your Android device (e.g., there is no Android app for the Kindle Fire HD).  I own both these and Sennheiser's comparable model.  The Klipsch earbuds cost about $10 more, presumably for the Android control feature.  Both have good enough audio, not audiophile mind you, but OK.  In my opinion the Klipsch buds are the more comfortable and for that I give them the nod.

reviewText: First Pi I got is running a small bitcoin operation for fun. Every so often I delete the SD card and start over just to keep up with the terminal language. Bought another one to hope starting on making a little home PI server for the fun of it.

I had this hub for several years but recently my mouse stopped working one day and it turned out to be the hub.  I don't know that mine overheated (like others have reported) but after I realized that the mouse was fine and it was actually the hub, suddenly all of the various glitches that I had noticed in recent months made sense and I came to the realization that this hub had been dying a slow death for quite some time now.I intended to buy another but after reading some of the reviews here I went with a "Plugable" hub instead.  I was a little unsure of the brand having never really heard of it before, but then I remember thinking the same thing about Belkin many years ago.  I've always had good luck with Belkin but I chose not to take another chance on this hub.5 stars for an excellent product from a design and usability point of view, but minus 2 stars for slowly dying after only a few years.

Hey hope this helps. I bought two of these. The reviews before me stated it would hold its place on audio books and music and remember the radio station. Sadly it does neither of these. In my opinion the fm transmitter is OK. Not the worst but not the strongest. I would recommend this as a workable solutions for somebody that wants to listen to there music and does not care about a certain amount of static throughout the drive. The static is not constant but it will crop up as the FM transmitter fights to keep a station and ends up losing. As you drive you will be listening to your MP3 and then latter listening to the radio station as it gets stronger.

reviewText: I'd had an Acer Aspire One for a few months when my brother expressed an interest in buying a small laptop; I hatched the idea of giving him a deal on my AAO if I could find something I might like a little more. My only real dissatisfaction with my AAO (120G HD, WinXP, 3-cell model) had been battery life; watching a movie on iTunes, I could barely get through an hour and a half, and I generally had to pay a lot more attention to the battery meter than I wanted.After some research, I settled on the Samsung NC10 as something that might suit my needs better.  Both are fine machines, with very similar specs; here are my thoughts on the two, after a few months with the Acer and a few days with the Samsung.Size and weight are the biggest difference (though in fairness, a 6-cell AAO would be pretty close in weight) - but as with most tradeoffs, the right choice depends on what you want to do with it.  If I was really going to be carrying it around regularly, the Acer would be more handy.  My primary use, though, is as a "kitchen computer" for around the house, plus entertainment and email on the occasional trip.  Since portability is a bit less of a concern, I can afford the NC10's bigger dimensions to get the bigger screen and keyboard.Things I like about the NC10:* Bigger keyboard feels very close to full size.* The matte screen is better in many environments compared to the glossy screen of the Acer.  Flying with the Acer, I had problems with the reflections of the reading lights of the passengers behind me, and there were similar issues in other environments.  I get a bit less contrast with the NC10 -- the blacks aren't quite as black in some settings -- but it's a reasonable price to pay.* I wasn't really getting used to the Acer's touchpad buttons being on the side. The NC10's button position underneath the touchpad is more natural for me. The difference isn't as great as I had hoped, though - I'd wanted to be able to click-and-drag with one hand by using the thumb and index finger, but the touchpad area is so cramped that this is difficult, and I still resort to two hands fairly often.* Aside from positioning, the touchpad's buttons do feel more usable on the NC10; you really need to push on the Acer's buttons, while with the NC10, you can do a more gentle tap.* The NC10's labels for the side connectors, printed on the top surface around the keyboard, are a very useful touch I'd like to see more of.  Not beautiful, but a victory of function over form.* Both give on-screen feedback when you do various Fn-key operations such as turning off wireless or changing the brightness or volume, but Samsung uses nice clear graphics in the middle of the screen, while Acer's feedback is with simple and fairly light-colored text near the bottom of the screen; the latter was harder to see on light backgrounds.* Very quiet out of the box.  The Acer was just intolerably loud before I found and installed Ralf's free fan control app, which made a huge difference in the enjoyability of the AAO.* If you're hung up on fingerprints, the NC10 has hardly any surfaces that attract them.* I haven't done it yet, but I like the option of easily adding more memory.Things I miss about the Acer:* A nifty feature of the AAO's physical design is that the display's hinges are only at the sides, leaving a big gap along most of the length between the main body and the display's lid.  I found I could get a very nice one-handed grip of the open AAO by slipping three fingers into this gap (getting my medium-size male fingers in up to the second knuckle), and spreading my pinky and thumb wide underneath the unit, turning it into, well, a mighty big "palmtop".  This gives a very strong one-hand hold, leaving the other hand free for typing.  If you think you might be using your netbook on your feet a lot, you should definitely try the Acer on for size.  (In contrast, holding the NC10 Statue-of-Liberty style and trying to type on it isn't nearly as solid or comfortable.)* The Acer's lid opened wider, which is nicer sometimes for casual household use,  e.g. standing over a table or counter.* The Acer's status LED's are above the keyboard near the display, easily visible while you're typing; the NC10's are on the front edge (toward your body as you type).  This hides them under your hands when you're typing, and if you set the NC10 down in front of you to watch a movie, those bright blue LEDs are shining right at your face, and are a bit distracting.* I kinda miss that extra money I had to spend on the Samsung; it's not the cheapest netbook.Things I like about both:* One thing that drew me to the NC10 was the similarity of its keyboard layout to that of the Acer; I had found myself coming to like the little navigation section in the lower right, that puts page up and down keys near the arrow keys.  I had discarded some other NetBook options based on keyboard layout; I like to use PgUp/PgDn when reading, and having to hit a function key for them was unacceptable.  I still have to hit "Fn" to get Home and End, but I use them less often.  In contrast, the keyboard on a colleague's Dell Mini 9 felt very unnatural - not only cramped, but with many keys in nonstandard places.* Both fit really well on a cramped coach airline seat tray (the Acer a bit better, of course).  In contrast, my full size "work" laptop (a 15" Thinkpad) is just about unusable.* Space!  I hate it when a computer's disk starts getting full and I have to worry about what to delete, so I never really considered the SSD-based netbooks.Things I don't like about both:* The vertical resolution (these are 1024x600) isn't enough for many web pages, particularly flash-based web pages for kids.  Pbskids.org and webkinz.com were a couple of the sites where the richly animated apps just didn't fit vertically.  If you're thinking about a netbook as a kid's computer, you might want to think  seriously about a more full-size laptop, and maybe try out their favorite sites in a smaller browser window.In conclusion: they're both great Netbooks, but the battery life and usability of the Samsung NC10 made it the best choice for me, despite the Aspire One's greater portability and lower cost.

I recommend this to anyone who ran out of inputs on their home theater system.  My Onkyo only had three digital audio inputs and, of course, when device #4 came around I needed an inexpensive solution to get it connected.  The CtG 28731 really fit the bill.  I just disconnected the S-Video and Optical Audio feed from three of my devices from the Onkyo and plugged them into the CtG, then ran the CtG output to the Onkyo.  My fourth device just got connected directly to the Onkyo.The remote is really small, but its not like you're changing TV channels with it.  No audio or video degradation has been observed, as I would expect from a CtG product.

The strap works as intended so I believe it was designed in such a way that causes an issue for me.  I watched the video demo at: //optechusa.com/Videos/SlingStrap.html  You can clearly see in the video the camera hangs by your hip area with the eye cup and back LCD screen rubbing against your pants/shirt.  When I have this hooked onto my Sony A99 and I walk around, my camera rubs back and forth against my clothes and I can imagine it will eventually destroy my eye cup and my back LCD screen due to friction.  I also tried to position my camera so that the part that rubs against my clothing is a not-as-delicate part of the camera but the only other position I can maneuver the camera into causes my clothing to rub against the top part of the camera where the second display plastic screen is on top.  All other positions feel unnatural when I walk and it naturally wants to twist back into the position that causes the eye cup and back LCD to rub against my clothes.  I have tried it with a Sony A99 and 85zeiss, 135zeiss, 28-70zeiss, 16-35zeiss, 24zeiss, and 50 1.4 all with the same results.  If you see this video of a Joby strap youtube.com/watch?v=76aS_cCL9UA it shows how the side of the camera rests against the clothing (the side of the camera is not as delicate as the eye cup, LCD screen, or top display on the Sony A99).  However, I am wary of using the Joby because I am afraid the tripod threads may come loose...anyways, back to the optech...so if you are one of those folks who really like to take care of their equipment, I would recommend a sling bag where the camera is fully protected in a bag that is slung around your shoulder...or a sling that attaches to the tripod thread if you are not afraid of it coming loose.  If you do not care about damages to your equipment then this sling may work for you.
summary: Can Destroy the Eye Piece and Back LCD screen

reviewText: Am using this controller on my third build and am very pleased. I set it up for manual speed control for now until I get to where I feel confident with the temps my PC will put out at various loads. I am not using the mobo bios temp/fan speed controls at all - just this Scythe Kaze Server 5.25" and am feeling more confident with it everyday. I am montoring and controlling temps/fans to: CPU; GPU; NB chipset; SB chipset. I have a 92mm fan fastened to the CPU cooler; a 92 mm fan mounted just below the GPU; a 120mm front case fan which I mounted inside just past the HD's which moves air across HD's; NB & SB; Ram etc.; and a rear 92mm fan attached to outside of rear case opening. (I cut out the grill on the back to allow max. flow of air out of case.) For me, this all works great.

I love this keyboard and I use it one at work and at home!  A clean, traditional key layout with shortcut buttons that actually work thanks to the excellent Intellitype software.  The key response is the best I've used since the old IBM keyboards of the 1980's.  The keys are solid, stiff and emit a nice tactile click when you press them.  You won't find any keyboard flex or mushy/spongy key response that you'll find in some of the cheaper, no-name keyboards you can buy [elsewhere] for [less].  Microsoft has done their homework with this one!The included wristrest completes this great setup.  If you're looking for a basic keyboard and don't require dozens of quickstart keys or the latest RF/wireless model, you'd be hard pressed to find anything better than this one.  Take it from me, I use mine all day at work and at home on my own PC!
summary: Great keyboard!  Best tactile feedback ever!

reviewText: Combined this with an opti drive caddy for my macbook pro `15 2010 and gave me an extra 750gb of storage.  Bought it from warehouse deals and saved an additional $25 so it was a great deal...it also runs very quietly and is decently fast.  no complaints

reviewText: Thought it would be to short looking at the package. It unrolled though to an amazing length that would easily fit any tower.Don't let the name fool you either. I almost did. It is a SATA data cable for a SATA drive to hook to a motherboard. Nothing could be easier then hooking this up either. All you have to do is plug one end into the drive you wish to connect and the other into the motherboard. No fussing over pin 1 or master/slave jumpers like you have to do with most IDE drives. SATA drives are a wonderfully easy thing to hook up. Seriously doubt that there is anything easier to hook up then this.The only thing you need to hook this cable and the drive to your motherboard(the flat square thing in your tower that everything is connected to) is a 1" long by 1" high tab on the motherboard that has a slight (almost so slight you won't notice at first glance) L shape to it.
summary: If this doesn't do , nothing will.

reviewText: I wash thrilled to find just the right size split tube to keep some of my computer wires together and out of the way.  And I got so much for such a great price.  Very happy with this purchase and would buy from them again.

Not only did this bring new life to my laptop...but the extra 3 cells give my laptop a nice little boost off the desk so air can flow around the whole laptop and it makes it easier to grab and pickup...

I have a Starmate 5 portable plug-n-play Sirius receiver, and I have docking stations for the home, car, and boat. I bought this "boom-box" so that I could take the receiver to the beach, on a picnic, and so on.The nice thing about a portable receiver such as the Starmate 5 is you take the license with you, so you do not have to purchase a subscription for each location (home, car, boat, beach) you want to take it.The boom box works great as an addition to the "system".The boom box also has a 3.5mm phono jack for an auxilliary input, so I can also use an iPod as well.  The unit will set you back a few dollars when purchasing batteries, but they seem to last for awhile.  And you can use an AC adapter, which keeps battery draw down, and is typically used at the backyard barbecue.The antenna holder could be a bit better though, which is why I gave it a 4 rather than a 5. It simply sits on the unit by friction fit. The holder also interferes with the main handle of the unit as well.  I would have liked to see a permanently installed antenna (with provisions to rotate it), rather than what is used.
summary: Great addition to your plug-n-play satellite receiver.

reviewText: For such small speakers the sound quality is not bad at all, the price makes the deal even better. I pruchased this speakers in order to listen to videos on my PC, and so far i have no complaint, not sure if they will be strong to last me a while, but so far so good

Certainly, this is one of the better sounding speaker sets available, and easily the best LOOKING that I've seen. Even the power transformer has the cool translucent plastic look which has become the apple standardMy main complaint is that if you're going to make a (...) USB speaker system, shouldn't you at least put a mini-USB hub into it so that you don't completely burn a USB port for the speaker?
summary: They couldn't put a USB hub in this?

reviewText: Terrible product. If you want to have a computer experience comparable to about a 1980 PC then get this Nook. Slow, awkward, SD card never works, locks up constantly, screen flickers, bad/slow if ever response to commands, bad menus, poor power usage and on and on. Absolutely terrible. There is nothing I would not change. They completely overlooked the structure and software of this product with a sole emphasis on book sales. Sad. The touch screen barely works, usually takes multiple taps/swipes for it to even recognize that you are trying to do something and then who knows what it will actually do. If you are used to an iPad screen this is in no way similar. Avoid. I don't know if a Kindle is any better.

I have 4 external LaCie drives and I have had problems with the power supply. To the people that have returned it to LaCie I must say i am sorry that you were told to do that, if the issue is the power supply they can replace it. I have had to do this a few times and had two very nice tech support and one 16 year teenager who was rude and very bad attitude. In the last case i actually had to talk to supervisor who turned out to be his buddy.The drives themselves have been OK, but at present two of my !TB and 600GB power supplies are gone out again!Update: Feb 2009 - The power supplies were replaced by a very nice 3rd tech support lady and the drives have been working fine.I have 5 LaCies now with the oldest being 3.25 years old and still ok. My drives are always on.
summary: Read for Power issues and support

reviewText: Love the new generation features and this shade of orange is the coolest color out there!

Sansa still continues the issue from previous models in that not all audio books sort properly.  I found that the tracks across multiple files always sort in track order (i.e. Book 1 track 1, Book 2 track 1, Book 3 track 1).  I have fully re-tagged and re-copied the files multiple times using multiple methods.  Nothing works so I cannot use this for audio books.  Music has no such issue.  It's strange that it only seems to affect files located in the audiobook sub-folder and not the music folder.Otherwise the product works well with good battery life.  This version no longer has the lock-out function for the buttons so that was a dissapointment.

reviewText: What can i say?  It works well.  I use it with my Nexus 7 and an app called 'Nexus Media Importer'.  Works really well.
for the prices - you can not go wrong. not a super high end unit but it looks great. I'll take this over any smaller lcd...

If you're looking for a laptop for gaming or for installing programs on, turn around now. This device is not for you.The Pro:Here's what I love about this computer-1.) It's pretty much weightless. I love that this computer is so lightweight, because as a college student, it makes transporting it back and forth between my home and campus super convenient.2.) Everything is based around the Chrome web browser. I don't use much else on my PC besides going onto the internet, so this computer is perfect for me. I love all the apps that are offered through Google (such as Google Docs, Google Slides, etc.) because they're free, and almost identical to their PC counterparts. For example, Google Slides is so much easier to use over the 2007+ versions of Microsoft PowerPoint. Anyone can figure it out, and it's much better than OpenOffice as well. The best thing about this being internet based is Google Drive. You get it for 2 years free with the purchase of your laptop, and you never have to take your laptop with you if you prefer to leave it at home. I had a presentation due and just had to log into my Google account and pull it up on the school computer. This made my life so much simpler. And it automatically saves any changes that you make to your file, so if your computer were to crash, everything is backed up and you can access it from any other computer in your home.3.) Super fast boot speed. I don't know why anyone is complaining about having to wait for this thing to boot, because it is instant. I mean maybe a 5 second wait time if you let it die or power it down, and compared to a PC the boot time is 100000x faster. Whenever I get on my desktop now, I feel like it takes it forever especially when I've been using my Acer and haven't touched Windows in a few days.3.) The battery life is decent, especially for what is considered a "netbook". With brightness turned up all the way, I get about 4 hours of batter life before it dies.The Cons:1.) The only complaint that I have at this point in time is that I can't use Google Music Manager. I haven't came across a Webstore App yet, but if I do I'll be sure to update my review.2.) Not compatible with Itunes, which is a given considering the type of device that it is. I just thought I would include that in here for those who don't realize that you cannot install any type of programs on here (Itunes, Photoshop, etc.) However, if you are looking for a web based Photoshop replacement, Pixlr (just type that in on Google) is an amazing replacement, especially for an online program. It is almost identical to Photoshop, and if you know your way around, you can do some pretty awesome things on there.
good case; the price is good and the quality is good; it looks good too; I have no complaints so far

I bought these to use at my job, in the office when I cut soundtracks for fireworks shows. I needed something that would be somewhat noise canceling as we don't have a dedicated studio, but I also needed to be able to hear if someone called for me. In that way, they cancel just the right amount of background noise out. The sound quality is good, albeit a little too much bass for my taste; it isn't that there is too little mid- and high- range, those are definitely present, the bass is just a little too thumping. I also have to expect my work to be played back on sound systems at stadiums which tend not to have a lot of bass sometimes, so it isn't necessarily a true representation for me. However, if you are buying them just to listen to your iPod through a good set of headphones, these are perfect. They are very comfortable up to a few hours, and after that, I think just about any headphones would be annoying.

Live?  It's not live, you have to dock it to record.  The unit I saw was boxy and clunky compared to the XM unit, which does pick up live broadcasts and costs half as much (though I suppose the price will come down).  I'm interested in the Sirius programming, but with this kind of drastic difference between the hardware, it's pretty tough not to go with XM.  Maybe they should have spent that Howard money here.  Note the manufacturer; Pioneer?  Samsung?  Nope, "Directed Electronics".  Uh huh.
summary: Is this some kind of joke??

reviewText: Works great with Mac and Windows.  Good quality.  Powered by two USB plugs.  You will need two available ports to use this device.functions well and is build much better then most of its peers.

I tested the charging points without the battery,​ and they are putting out 3.6 volts which should be plenty to charge this battery?  I can't be sure if it the laptop or the battery?  That is the reason for the two stars , if I come across another 1525 or 1526, Inspiron & the battery works or not I will change this review.As always  shipping & RMA can be no better or easier than with Amazon.Maybe someone will read this and get back to me as the solution or similar problem.

reviewText: I found that this device is primarily a set of FM radio headphones.  You actually have to tune in the transmitter's station to listen to TV, or whatever device is connected.  That means that you scan through each radio station (frequency) until you find the sound from your device (only by listening).  Once you have the device, the sound is muffled in comparison to most of the regular radio stations.  Also, sometimes the headphones lose the frequency and get static on them, which comes in quite loud, since I have to turn the volume all the way up on the headphones to hear the TV.  Crazy, baby!I paid only $13, but I do not recommend these headphones.  You get what you pay for.
summary: Poor Sound Quality - Not Easy to Use

reviewText: This mouse was one of the few available Bluetooth mice on the market. While I don't have much experience with the other mice, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this mice as a ultra portable alternative to the traditional mouse.  The scroll touch works well - its speed sensitive so the faster you slide your finger the quicker it'll scroll.  Overall, I think this mouse may be one of the best LAPTOP mice available.  My desktop mouse is a Logitech gaming mouse which I ergonomic....and huge. It really matches the Microsoft Surface tablet- same type of feel as the cover, and it doesn't take up your lone USB slot!  While I am not a brand-whore, I normally don't trust wireless mice from unbranded companies.  I will update this review IF it breaks, so you will know what sort of life expectancy this mouse may see.  I am not abusive to my electronics but most of my IR mice have died within 6 months to a year (Logitech, Microsoft).

I've only had the lamp for 2 weeks so I can't comment on how durable it might be. It looks to be well made, it's well finished, it throws ample light on the keyboard, it's easily adjusted and the 13 leds are grouped nice and compactly.And, most importantly, I found it useful. And all this for a few dollars. It's a no-brainer.UPDATE: 1 month ago, 2 LEDs failed, one going out entirely and the other in flicker mode which makes it unusable.  Given the overall good finish of this product, it is just false economy not to use good quality LEDs. After all, these devices are noted for their longevity. Disappointing!
summary: Good product. Does all that I want.

reviewText: This is an excellent product. It is still working like a charm after more than five years. I upgraded my system months ago. It seemed my new and sophisticated hdtv and AV system complicated the old usual setup, so I thought this dvd player was "dead"--it wasn't showing color. Remember this is the era of hdmi cables and not your cave-age three-color three-headed cables. The dvd player does not have hdmi; I kept trying composite connection but it didn't work. Anyway, I only recently returned to rethinking the connections--after nearly calling Geek to come and do it; bad reviews of Geek made me return to the task myself. I used a mixture of the optical connector and--yes--the tricolor cave-age cables. This arrangement worked beautifully, and with great sound from my over-achieving AV system. Just as an afterthought after the success, I tried to search if there is an update of the dvp player--still the modest 5-disc carousel but now with hdmi connections. Unfortunately, not available; only 400-disc players!! Too bad. I will keep using the DVP NC655P until I find something similar but with hdmi connections.

I've used the rayovac PS1 (AA/AAA only) charger for several years and it's still working.  The PS3 does most battery types & may have the same longevity.  While I recharge NiMH batteries, I mostly just recharge old alkaline types.  While the manual says you can't recharge ordinary alkalines, you can with care.  Except for 9V batteries, the others are nominal 1.5V  Most new ones are about 1.62 volts.  If they are discharged to 1.45 or more, they will recharge to nearly full voltage.  If they are discharged to less than 1.4 volts, recharging restores them to some extent, but it's probably not worth doing.  While the instructions imply you need to recharge 2 or 4 AA or AAA, this charger will do one at a time (I tested).  However, 9V batteries are different for some reason.  I haven't tested NiMH 9V, just alkalines, the PS3 recharges 9V alkalines VERY FAST for some odd reason (like in less than 5 minutes when there very discharged).  Unless there is something wrong with the one I have, you have to take the 9V batteries out in less than 5 minutes to test for voltage.  I'm amazed at how well rayovac chargers work and this one is no exception (just watch out for the 9V).
summary: If you need a charger for most battery types - this is it

Handily, the ssid and password are printed right on the label! I'm not sure if that's a security issue or not but it sure is helpful.  I then connected my browser to it and set it up to extend the wireless.  We had slightly less reception in our basement but now it's great!I also liked the idea that you could turn an ethernet connection into a wifi hotspot, which is helpful when travelling and ethernet is free, but wireless is at a cost.The instruction guide is simple, straight-forward, and easy to follow.  I was able to do everything I needed with a minimum of frustration.I can't wait to take this with me on a trip to use as a wireless extender at a hotel, where you really need it!

If your main objective in purchasing the SONY MDRNC8 is to take advantage of good electronic noise cancellation, you will be gravely disappointed. The switchable NR electronics (powered by a single AAA battery) in this model are singularly underwhelming. When activated, there is some cancellation of overall "room tone " However, there is nothing contained within that will offer serious relief from train/plane or auto noise. It works--but not very well.NOW- Let's talk about overall AUDIO performance. These are an excellent set of cans. I would put them up against anything made by BEATS for sheer musical excellence. For a cheap pair of fold-up music reproducers, I was very impressed!.  These are comfortable hi-fi musical instruments and I was not disappointed listening to them for 8 hours on a coast-to-coast plane flight (I actually purchased these at a retail kiosk in the airport).BOTTOM LINE--I found the SONY MDRNC8 to be ineffectual as active noise suppressors--but a surprising good companion for quality listening on a long flight. Your experience might vary.

Logitech's Ultimate Ears 200 Earphones passed the married man test! Plugged into my laptop, I surfed Blip.fm for two hours -- The Beatles, Ezio, Red Hot Chili Peppers, George Thorogood, Dusty Springfield, Jane's Addiction, Lenny Kravitz, Johnny Cash -- sitting in the same living room while my wife watched back-to-back episodes ofDog Whispererwith a 7.1-channel home theater speaker system.PROS:The earphones delivered quality sound and range.The earbuds are comfy and stay in place.The earphones isolated every hint of Cesar Millan!I was excited to try these earphones because my experience with the Logitech brand has been nothing but positive. I have been using Logitech trackballs for nearly a decade. I owned and recommended Logitech'sCordless Optical Trackmanand theirAudioHub Notebook Speakers.My only concern was whether I would find Logitech's earbud design comfortable to wear. I don't care for over-the-ear headphones because they leave my ears hot and sweaty. I previously usedPhilips SHS3701/27 Earclip HeadphonesandAltec Lansing UHP303 Behind-The-Neck Ear Clip Headphones, both of which took getting used to before I could wear them for longer periods of time. However, I had no problem wearing Logitech'sUltimate Ears 200 Noise-Isolating Earphones. The package comes with five additional ear cushions (L to XXS) to ensure a perfect fit.Another nice feature addition is the hard plastic carrying case Logitech includes with the package. With a couple quick wraps around my fingers the earphones can be easily stored in my pocket. In summary, Logitech's earphones were more comfortable and provided better sound and range than my other headphones.Rating: Five stars.

Almost none of the consumer and "prosumer" camcorders currently being marketed include a viewfinder in addition to the LCD screen.  This fact, as well as the recent fire sale for this model, lead me to believe that this feature soon will be available only on professional camcorders. Apparently, persons younger than 45 (the average age of onset of presbyopia) and those who never go outdoors comprise the target demographics for manufacturers of consumer camcorders. This is the only plausible rationale for designing cameras that rely solely on an LCD screen for framing and focusing shots. Practically worthless in bright sunlight, the challenge of using them, indoors or out, is revealed by the number of users who must hold their cameras at arm's length in an effort to frame a shot. So, in spite of being very satisfied with the image and build quality of the Canon Vixia HF200 that I formerly owned, my frustration with the lack of a viewfinder forced me to sell it and buy the M41.The body of the M41 appears to be made of black plastic. Perhaps it will prove to be very sturdy, but it does not make as positive an impression as the finish of the HF200.  Another difference is the use of a touch screen for making shooting adjustments on the M41 rather than the tiny joy stick device on the HF200. I have found the touch screen to work effectively and prefer it to the micro-mechanical approach (both cameras also use membrane switches located on the body of the camera). I must admit that I have some apprehensions about the long-term durability of a touch screen for this application, but they seem to hold up on smartphones and I won't be using the camcorder nearly as often as I use my smartphone. I made one other concession by accepting the 10x optical zoom lens on the M41 in contrast to the 15x lens on the HF200; however, this is consistent with a general downgrade in this feature across manufacturers (offset, perhaps, by improved digital zooming that is accomplished by software rather than optics).The quality of the videos I've shot with the M41 seems as good as those I took with the HF200; however, consistent with my intentions in purchasing this camera, the framing and tracking of subjects is much improved because of the viewfinder. Having achieved this fundamental objective, I am willing to take a chance that the plastic body and touchscreen may not hold up under appropriately careful use.Until very recently, the price of this camera was typically well above $600. In early November, Canon reduced the price of its direct sales to $499 and apparently offered a $200 rebate to retailers so that they would fall in line on pricing. I purchased it from Amazon for $449, a price that seemed to be available for only a day or two.  Given the quality of the technology on which it is built (see other reviews and the product information from Canon), I feel that it was a very good value. The current pricing gives the impression of a close-out on this model.  I would be surprised to learn that it is being replaced with a better model that includes a viewfinder. Instead, as I noted above, I expect that the M41 may be the last consumer camcorder that features a viewfinder.
summary: A camcorder alternative for presbyopic videographers and those who shoot video outdoors

reviewText: I was very skeptical as I had used some Tamron lenses in the past and found them to be unreliableduring my use of them, but this lens ( and honestly their new line up ) has really impressed me.First off let me tell you the VC ( vibration compensation ) is amazing. It's similar to IS on Canon's lenses.It helps achieve keeper shots at low light and it's great for video as well. The lens does get a littlesoft in the corners but thats only really noticeable if you zoom 400x or something crazy like that.As for the build it's like a tank, nice weight to it and the elements used are of the highest quality. I likethe front element the most because usually you find a curved glass but this has a flat element making it almostlook like it has a pre-builtin filter. One downside is the filter size is 82mm so if you plan on getting this lens realizeyou're going to have to get new filters if you dont already. 82mm isnt common so I had to get a whole new setfor this lens. Another downside I find irritanting is the focus and zoom rings are reversed of Canon's, I know it's not thatbig of a deal but that's like saying "ok here's a new car, brake is on the right and gas is on the left."Not too mention the focus ring is so tiny compared to the large zoom ring. And one more oddity is I dont know if these lens' are really rated at what their real coverage area is. I took a shot with a 50mm f/1.4 and took a shot with Tamron at 50mm. In comparison to the prime lens it was slightly off by Id say 3-5mm or so? If thats the case then maybe the 24mm might even be a little wider ( which for me isnt a bad thing at all ). Overall its a great lens, if you can live with some of these issues you'll find a lensyou'll have for many many years to come. Enjoy but most importantly get out there and shoot!
summary: An amazing alternative to the Canon 24-70 L

I used two of these for wall mounting dual 24" ASUS LED backlit LCD monitors in an over-under layout. Because they tilt, I can have the top monitor angled down slightly and have the bottom bezel BEHND the lower monitor. They came with everything needed - screws for the back of the monitor, and also screws and plastic anchors for the drywall. However, I used my own drywall anchors and screws - the ones that come with it are HUGE and could hold a 747 to your wall. As my monitors are relatively small and light, I didn't the 33 Lbs. of rated strength - my monitor weighs more like 3 Lbs. So if you don't want to put giant holes in your wall (rentals, rearranging the room later, etc) I reccommend a quick trip to the hardware store for smaller hardware. I also never put the top screw in to hold the two plates together. If you are mounting in an RV or public place (somewhere the screen could get bumped) I would put it in, but this way, I can pull the screens off the wall if I want to, and they stay in place just fine. Other than that, I love these mounts.

Odd... well, one would think a product released later with a higher model number would be better. Apparently, that rule does not apply here. Sneaky marketing?I also own the X-230 and I was very impressed with it, considering they're 2.1 speakers. The X-230 actually feels like surround sound. However, I can't say the same about the X-240's. The X-240 just sounds like what one would usually expect from 2.1 speakers.The X-230 has two drivers in each speaker (total of four), whereas this new version, X-240, only contains one; that may be why it sounds more flat.The X-240 sounds like I'm just listening from a regular jukebox. It doesn't sound terrible, but it just doesn't have that rich dynamic feel and sounds a bit muffled.The X-230 bass is pretty overpowering even at the lowest setting; maybe because of those complaints, Logitech decided to make the X-240 rely more on treble and tried to go for clarity. Unfortunately, the result ended up sounding more flat. I guess Logitech tried to cut back costs by using only one driver for each speaker. Bad idea.Speaking of cheap... honestly, the dock is very cheap. Basically, you slide it out -- and it doesn't even come out that far -- where you place one of the plastic "adapters" (included for the iPod, Zune, etc...).  I tried to set it up, so I could place the iPod sync cable and place my iPod Classic, but that was a mess. The cable would not hold in place firmly at all; and without connecting to it, there wouldn't be anything secure to hold the mp3 player. The "dock" (if you can even call it that) is just unreliable and worthless for me. There's really no weight to the "dock", so it would easily knock over. It is basically a HUGE volume remote. The volume control is also on the side of the dock, and the dial, again, feels cheap. The speaker dial for the X-230 is located nicely on the speaker and the design/feel is so much better.Bad ergonomics: The X-230 cradle (huge remote) is also hard wired together to the subwoofer, so that makes it very difficult setting it up on the desk.Everything--ergonomics, design, sound--the previous model, X-230, wins against the X-240. I was looking forward for the added "dock" feature, but that is truly a gimmick. It was definitely an afterthought.I own many Logitech products, and I've been impressed with most of them, but this one was disappointing. The sound difference is quite significant. If you have a choice between the two, I would definitely go for the X-230, even if it costs a little extra. No question.If you absolutely can't stand bass, then the X-240 may be for you--but you will also be sacrificing a more dynamic surround sound because of less speaker drivers.In the end, these are just "Okay" speakers.
I take this thing everywhere.  Has great sound, fills the room.  Great at parties.  Easy to use.  Just plug in your reciever. Worth every penny.

I bought this item on June 27th 2013. Around September/October, it started malfunctioning frequently. While typing, random series of letters/numbers would appear, and the keys on the number row would stop working.I realized that this stopped when I fiddled with the cable. It only happened once every few weeks, so I didn't pay much attention to it (and at first thought it may have been a driver issue). But it happened more and more frequently. Now in January 2014, it happens up to several times a day.Since the cable is detachable, I swapped it out- same problem. Turns out that the issue lies with the USB connector of the keyboard - it must be cheap and prone to short circuiting.I searched online, and it seems like it is a very common issue with this keyboard. I contacted Cooler Master, and they offered to RMA it, which is a huge pain as I got used to typing on this keyboard and I'm going to have to send it back and wait for weeks before getting a new one. I also changed the keycaps, so now I'm going to have to take them all out again. All in all a hassle.Avoid this product. It's amongst the cheapest mech keyboards you can find for a reason.
summary: Cheap connector construction ruins an otherwise good keyboard

reviewText: For starters I dont have the focusing problems that some reviewers have had, but I have used this body with manual focusing lenses on static subjects and I havefound that the live view is very well designed (better than my Nikon D300) and very useful. Suddenly an old Nikon super-telephoto lens that was very hard to focus has taken on a new life. I'm using an adapter ring of course.Live view has also made it easy to use atilt and shift lens.Pictures using lenses like the 50mm AF F/1.8 lenses are extremely sharp (and therefore the focusing is accurate), and I get the impression they could increase the pixel count even further and it would be worth it. My 24-105 mm lens however is beginning to look soft in the corners with this camera.I found the user interface an instant improvement when moving up from the 5D. This is partly facilitated by the improved screen resolution, so now I can find what I'm looking for much faster. It's almost visible in full daylight (but you better use your body to shade it).The user manual is very well written.The infrared remote control RC-5 does not make it possible to take instant shots: there is always a delay. This is a disappointment. HDR photographers will also be disappointed to note that you still cannot take more that 3 exposures without touching the camera or buying a rather expensivePromote Systems Promote Control, Remote Control for Digital SLR CamerasI have not used the video yet, but I have seen a professional documentary that was entirely filmed with this camera and was blown away by the quality.Low light photography is improved over the 5D which was highly praised at the time. You get about an extra f-stop.I also appreciate a bit of sealing as the previous model was extremely vulnerable on this count: like you would not want to bring it to a party with drinks splashing around.This camera may not be a sport's shooter's dream but it is very good for landscape, with a tilt and shift lens likeCanon TS-E 24mm f/3.5L II Ultra Wide Tilt-Shift Lens for Canon Digital SLR CamerasAll in all there are no regrets moving up to this, and I will sell my 5D for a low price.
summary: Worth the step up from the previous 5D model

A good headset makes all the difference when on the go, so I ordered this one. It features comfortable ear pads (that can be changed out). It collapses for easy carry and fits into an included zippered case. The device carries a one year warranty.Controls for Apple phone products include include Answer/end call, use voice control, and increase/decrease volume. For Ipod/music, the functions are play / pause, skip track, previous track, fast forward, and rewind.For my Android phone it has only play/pause. I knew that it didn't support full Android functionality when I ordered it, so I'm not deducting any stars. The middle button will initiate voice calling and answer/hangup. However, it is a bit of a pain in some ways; the volume controls do not work except on Apple devices.The sound quality is excellent. The headset is light and comfortable on the ears, sounds are clear, and there is a good deal of bass sound. There is absolutely no problem with the sound. I used an HTC M8 for testing.As a hands free (when answering while listening to music and such, since it cannot be used for driving), the quality on both ends was acceptable. The mic is inline with the cord, so the outgoing quality depends on which way it is pointing, but it was clear enough to hear.The only thing I didn't like: the ugly off green cord color. The headset itself is available in this color, but the headphone part is dark purple/white, and I expected a black or white color cord. Maybe some people would consider it trendy, but it looks out of place with this headset.Summary: Well designed, with great sound and comfort. Probably best for Apple users, but acceptable for Android as well (within the design limits). Highly recommended.
summary: Great Sound, (sort of) Works With Android

reviewText: It's not Ipad2-sexy but it is the tablet that's picked up most in the house.2011 had a glut of Tegra2 10" Android tablets so spec-wise there's not much to differentiate (10", 1280x800, Tegra2 dual-core) it from many of the others except:-full-size SD card (the card's edge barely sticks out - I'd consider it a non-issue)-full-size HDMI port-brilliant screen (non-IPS but still great with good viewing angles, disable auto-brightness if you want to control the levels)-rubber backing (I hate to say it, but this is one of the best features.  It's easy to grip with no fear of it frisbee-ing out of your hand like some tablets!)-interchangeable back cover (for different colors)-replaceable battery (good feature on paper, but I haven't had a chance or need to use this as the battery life is acceptable for everyday usage)-included applications (there is some bloatware on there like game demos, but some usable software as well)Of all the devices in the house (3 tablets, 4 laptops), the Thrive seems to get the most mileage since it's just easy to pick up and hold/cradle while watching TV, etc.  I've also got the dock which makes it the largest (though the most functional) alarm clock ever.The full-size SD card slot really came in handy when I needed to get pictures right away from someone that lives out of town.  Just popped the SD card out of their Canon point-and-shoot and popped it into the Thrive.  Copied the pictures over and gave the card and camera back!  No fuss, no muss.  Sorry, can't do that with an Ipad.Performance is good and Honeycomb is snappy when swiping between screens and applications.There are more "advanced" tablets, but when it comes down to ease of use and comfort (even if that means no fear of dropping it), the Thrive is a great choice.
summary: Great everyday tablet - not the slickest or thinnest but possibly most practical

reviewText: I purchased this for use in the kitchen. Hooked up to a basic set of rabbit ears, we can now watch tv in the kitchen. The picture is crisp and vibrant. If you need a small tv, give this serious consideration.

I read the reviews on this thing before I bought it and was a little leary to buy this mouse based on some of the noise I was hearing.  Let me start by saying that someones review sighted that the extended pinky grip with rest could cause the mouse to tip.  This is absolutely false, in fact the added rest has a slide pad on it making the mouse more stable and actualy less likely to tip.  Secondly in the same review he/she said that with the same pinky grip that the mouse is impossible to pick up during normal mouse usage.  This is also false.  The angles of the mouse make it quite easy to pick up and reset.  Also in this review the reviewer stated that with the palm rest fully extended there was an uncomfortable gap.  This is blatantly false as your hand would have to actualy curve backward at your palm to produce any sort of discomfort.  All of this leads me to believe that he/she never bought the product but simply made observations while looking at pictures.  Lastly he /she stated that the precision button could not be remapped and let me tell you that it can and it is incredibly easy to do so.  Now for my review.I bought this mouse mainly for use with photoshop and gaming.  Out of the box this mouse is amazing.  The reciver plugs in via USB as you would expect but is a combination reciever, battery charger and storage for your weights.  The grip, texture and overall design of the mouse are stunning and functional.  The sensitivity of the mouse adjusts with a quick touch of a rocker switch and the precision aim button slows the mouse to a crawl to get that perfect headshot or precision pixel selection in photoshop.  I wish the weel had a free spin mode like my old mouse but this is a very minor complaint.I have very large hands and like a mouse with decent heft so a mouse that scales and customizes to my grip was atractive.  A small mouse gives me painful hand and wrist cramps and most mice are made for people with average to small hands.  It took only about five minutes or so of playing with this mouse, adjusting it and swapping grips to turn it into the most comfortable mouse I have ever owned.  I had a first gen M Revolution X and I cant belive that this mouse actualy fits my hand better.The next thing I did was download the photoshop profiles.  Figuring out how exactly to install said profiles from the website was a bit bewildering but it didnt take too long to figure it out.  After getting them istalled and messing around with the settings for a few minutes the mouse has become invaluable to my immage editing.  The side scroll can even be set up to increase and decrease brush size.Then I downloaded profiles for my favorite games.  I minutes I had this mouse performing beautifuly with all of my favorite games.  The only downside to this mouse is that it does not automaticaly detect active programs and switch profiles forcing you to manualy switch.  In some ways however this is a benefit as with many of these auto detect softwares there are frequent problems with games or programs not being detected properly (a constant problem with my old logitech mouse).  This takes out any chance of error.  Also as a side note there is a wow addon to more easily configure the mouse as well.

This was one of the few I found that said it would fit the iPad 2.THIS DOES NOT FIT THE iPAD 2!!!This is the EXACT same model as for the original iPad.  The problem is that the iPad 2 is significantly slimmer and a little shorter than the original version.  This makes for a very loose, unsafe fit.I will be returning this at once!  Very, very disappointed that Hard Candy would market this as an iPad 2 case without fitting it to the device! Not cool man!

reviewText: I have an HP slimline that lost its power supply to hurricane Sandy!  I had an ATX 430 Watt power supply as a replacement, but it did not fit the motherboard, a M2N61-AR mini-itx.  This board has a mini 20 pin connector and of course, ATX is 20+4 (24 pin), standard size!This cable did the trick: I snapped off the +4 (this can snap back on for future 'standard' use) on the ATX power supply cable, connected that to the white 20 pin ATX end of this cable and the black mini end to the motherboard, powered up first time.  Now I have enough power for a graphics card!
summary: Worked great on mini-itx motherboard with ATX power supply

The...Logitech USB Optical Mouse with wire tracks hand movement so much better than this MX700 wireless that I retired the wireless MX700. The MX700's software doesn't allow enough slow speed selections but gives many fast motion speeds that are impractical to use. I've run the MX700 on a Mac under OS 9.1 and on Windows XP with the same poor results. Had the same problem with Microsoft wireless mouse even though tried every driver configuration possible for all mice. The by-wire Optical is the most accurate mouse I've used so I bought one for my Mac and Windows machines. When using the USB port on my Sonnetech add-on board on the MAC computer the Logitech software control is lost, but the click button and good tracking still work, Kensington software, according to Sonnettech support, does work for Kensington mouse products.
