My RX-371 is a few years old now, it gets left on for days at a time.  I blow the dust out of it infrequently.  The receiver powers very efficient speakers (Klipsch Forte II's (99db 1w/1m) and a Klipsch Quartet center (98db 1w/1m)).  Most of the time it's input is either my PS3 or Mac Mini.  This receiver has worked quietly and solidly for years, no dust in the potentiometer (Volume Control) this receiver has been at the center of a great home entertainment system for years and for such short money.When the PS3 sends DTS, the receiver recognizes DTS, when the PS3 sends Dolby Digital, the receiver recognizes it.  My speaker s all have large Tracrix midrange horns and believe me, if this receiver made any cacophonous sounds, they would be amplified greatly, but it doesn't.  This little brute quietly does it's thing year after year.  I use both of the optical inputs although the sound port from my Mac is limited in capability, the sound port from the PS3 is not.  The Cinema DSP is nothing short of amazing.  Along with very large speakers this receiver provides an amazing sound stage.Seeing this ad made me want to buy another one, this receiver is the best deal out there, it provides lots of power, no real audio distortion (unless you're super sensitive to S/N ratios).  It has pushed my speakers to 110 db steady state without clipping or shutting off, so it can crank.  My Forte II's are good down to 34 Hz and believe me, so is this receiver.  There is not enough good I can say about this receiver, it has been a workhorse for a few years now and will probably continue to work for a few more years, or until I get tired of it.I'll tell you what, buy this receiver, with the money you save, buy a pair of Klipsch Heresy's and you will have a system that will last you a lifetime.Klipsch Heresy III Walnut (Ea.) Heritage Series 3-Way Floorstanding Loudspeaker.  Just get a subwoofer if you get the Heresy's.  Because of pesky things like the cabinet size and the laws of physics, they are tight down to 50 Hz, when they roll off.  If you really want to party, try a pair of theseKlipsch Cornwall III  Three-Way Horn-Loaded Loudspeaker with 15-Inch Subwoofer (Walnut), I have them in my living room, powered by another modest receiver, with a Heresy center channel, the results are one amazing sound stage.  Oh yea, both the receivers are Yamaha.  The older one is a Yamaha high current, multiroom model.You could do a lot worse than this receiver.  You can't do much better for powerful, basic home entertainment.

I purchased this for my HP dv6000 series notebook.Purpose: My previous battery was a 6 cell, and it would run out after 20 minutes! Abysmal. For some reason it decreased its battery life; before it used to get 1.5 hours. Not sure if this was an error on HP's part. Note: If you run an HP diagnostics test on the battery, they tell you that some laptops' batteries have been recalled/have major issues and HP will replace it free of charge and extend the warranty one year. See HP for details if your laptop qualifies.Installation: As mentioned in other reviews, I had to slam the battery in. At first it may seem like it will not fit, but you have to give it a good hit so it will lock into place.Performance: I get around 3.5 hours out of this puppy! I was really excited about this. I could watch a full movie on Netflix's Watch Instantly, or pop in a DVD.Heat: Like others, I like that the large battery props up the laptop, thus allowing for better ventillation, and negating a need to buy a fan.Shape: The bulky battery makes it too easy for the CD-ROM bay to pop open. It seems as if it pushes out the CD and if you just tap it, *pop* it comes out. Minor issue. Also, since the battery does not run across the entire bottom of the laptop, it may make it a bit wobbly when it's on a flat surface. Another minor gripe.Verdict: An awesome upgrade! I have reinvigorated my laptop with such a long battery life, and now can watch full movies and do video editing all over the house. Excellent purchase.
summary: Excellent Battery Life, a bit unwieldly

I purchased the red Poetic Nexus 10 case after giving the similar Nexus 7 case to my father at Christmas.  The Nexus 10 case is of the same excellent quality as the Nexus 7 case.  The red is perhaps a bit more pinkish than the pictures show (on second thought, maybe not).  It is also a bit more feminine than I would like.  The Nexus 10 snaps in very firmly.  There is no chance of it falling out.  The case is not overly bulky, but it does take away from the svelte style of the naked frame. Also, you trade the velvety smooth back for a felt feel. Like many extended batteries on smartphones (I'm thinking of the SIII), this case makes the tablet a bit easier to hold.  Before the Nexus 10, I used the Galaxy Tab 10.1 with a Samsung made case.  The Poetic case is perhaps a bit thicker, and the triangle-fold cover flops in a way that I'm not used to - the Samsung case was a flat stiff cover.  It would have been easy for Poetic to put magnets in the back of the plastic case, so that the cover would stay attached to the back - this would be a huge improvement.  The triangle stand works very well when in two modes: 1) the low profile mode (screen at a 30 degree angle), and 2) the stand up mode (screen at a 60 degree angle).  However, it won't keep the Nexus vertical if you are laying in bed watching Netflix (as the OEM Samsung case did), nor will it hold the 60 degree angle on your lap (as the Samsung case did).  The sleep/wake function is flawless, and was well worth the wait.The reason I didn't give the case 5 stars has to do with my suspicions about its build quality. The plastic case seems solid - it would last a fall down hardwood stairs, protecting the Nexus very well, especially if the magnet cover holds. I have my doubts that the faux leather material will wear as well. I suspect the major joint will fray over time. The flap, however, is designed to hang on the bottom of the Nexus 10; this way it doesn't interfere with the camera. All of the cutaways have ample room, except the volume rocker, which you kinda have to sneak in on from the back (I have to use my nail to adjust the volume as opposed to the pad of my finger).The one feature that is not like the pictures is the logo.  The empty "Poetic" logo is filled with a silver reflective coating.  I would have preferred that this stayed empty.  Other than that, the only thing that goes as well as this case with my Nexus 10 is my Kindle ebook,Android Mandroid: Thoughts on Android Smartphones from a Conflicted User.

Since the arrival of the iPad, the traditional 500mA USB adapters have been augmented by 2.1A and dual 2.1/0.5A adapters for the iPad plus any other USB-powered/charged device. You have to read the specs carefully since some chargers are not rated at that full load. Lots of people need a travel charger, and that calls for folding AC prongs. There are several such available on Amazon, I have every one of them and some that I bought elsewhere. I have narrowed my preference down to two brands/models -- this is one of them. It isn't the smallest one available, but I was able to measure the output current from both ports simultaneously and they met the specs -- which was not true of some of the other chargers I have.
summary: Excellent 2.1/0.5A USB AC Adapter for travel

reviewText: It's been quite some time since I purchased an external case for internal hard drives.  Let's start by saying that since it had been so long, I wasn't expecting what I received.  The old cases required you to open them up, mount the drive and close everything up before turning it on.  (Yes, I know the description was spot on but again, it's been a few years).  Now this thing, wow!  There is no need to perform all the 'old school' tasks just to see if a drive works.  You pick up a drive (2.5 or 3.5) slide it in the top without having to open anything and badabing, it starts to read it.  Since I love to tinker with computers, this has made backing up and finding drives that actually work easier than ever.  I have plugged it into my Dish Hopper and am able to transfer recordings flawlessly for safe keeping.  The easiest external docking station ever!!  Enjoy

Boy, I don't think I have been so disappointed with a product purchased through Amazon than this time. Apart from the fact that it is a real noisy Chill pad, mine seems to have a technical flaw that it makes an overbearing noise as one of the fans gets stuck. I have a considerably light weight Mac Book Pro so weight is not the issue. I have to switch it off 3-7 times ON-OFF-ON-OFF till such time that the noise stops. Another amazingly absurd thing is that the extra USB ports do not work. I have tried many times, to attach my external drive, Keyboard etc, but THEY JUST DON'T work, so it is either that the supplier has pulled a fast one on me and supplied a thrown away item or the product itself is rubbish.

Edit- 5/26Since I wrote this, I see that they lowered the price, which is now much lower and reasonable then the $397 that it was when I wrote my original review. Just know that this device does NOT improve the picture quality, and does not add the 2 settings that they removed in March 2012. I know many owners were hoping that this kit will improve the picture quality, and some were even told it will  last year before they bought their TVs. Samsung even made a video last year and played it at the 2012 CES show, which is also on YouTube, which states "improved picture quality" but I think they were referring to the "Smart hub". If you use the smart hub, and apps, then maybe you will benefit from this and be happy with it.Since Samsung removed the "Shadow detail" setting, which may be the same as the "Smart LED" setting found on the F8000 that controls the dimming, I was hoping they would at least add this setting back to the TVs with this kit. Since they removed the settings from a "Firmware" update, then they can easily add them back the same way, but this never happened. This is why I'm so upset with them. Many consumers who purchased the 2012 ES8000, aren't even aware that these settings were removed, because they were removed from the "ES8000" when it had its very first FW updateMay 10, 2013  (ORIGINAL REVIEW)I do not own this. I'm writing this to let others know what this kit is "supposedly" going to do. Last year they promoted this kit as it "Will" improve your picture quality, and it "Will" bring it to the next years specs. It was "Never" called the "Smart" Evo kit, until just recently. It was called "the Evolution Kit" now it's called, "Smart Evolution Kit" and also, there are reports saying that this kit will "NOT" improve the picture quality. So all these people who saw these TVs in 2012 as being an "upgradable" TV every year, that will "improve" the picture quality, may be very dissapointed. I know a lot of people bought these 2012 models, because of this Marketing, and IMO, it seems like it was done so consumers like us "owners", bought "their" models, and not another brand like a Sony, LG, or Panny.  And now, here we are a year later, and now everything is different. Even the name is a little different, along with this ridiculous price. You can buy a Blu ray player for this' price. You can even buy a blu ray player that has this new smart hub 2.0. why should anyone pay over $300 if it isn't going to improve the picture quality like we were all told before we bought these TVs?I mean, $400 or even $300, for things that can be done through a Firmware update? of course adding a "Quad core" processor can't,  be added through FW, since its hardware, but, why can't they send everyone the new Smart Hub 2.0  through one of their "Mysterious" FW updates? People can buy a Blu ray player for less then this, and get way more for their money. $400-$300 is a "rip off" for this. You can buy 3 Apple TVs, which IMO, run way faster and smoother then their Smart Hubs 1 and 2.0. Even with their "So called" quad core processor. with The new Sony Playstation and XBox coming, I would save your money for that, then waste it on this. The web browsers on the 2013 F8000 with the quad core processors, are still slow. Just like the 2012 ES were with the "Dual core".Now, I also want to let all you 2012 Owners of the "ES7500" and "ES8000" know that 2 picture settings were removed after its very first Firmware update in March 2012. The picture settings were, "Shadow Detail" and "Edge Enhancer"Last time i looked up the description for "Shadow detail", it had a very similar description as the "Smart LED" settings that Samsung left on the ridiculously "over priced" 75" ES9000.  They also have this setting on their new F8000 series, which actually cost less then what I paid for my ES8000 in March 2012. You would think the ES8000 would of been "Cheaper" since they are making the new F8000 sound like its "way" superior this year, and so "different", but it actually cost less for the F8000 compared to March 2012 when the ES8000 came out. Just to give an example, i paid $2,700 for the 46" ES8000 in March 2012 LOL! and, it had these 2 picture settings at that time. LOL!Then, theirs a setting called "Cinema Black" thats on the 2013 models. This setting seems to be the "SAME" setting as the "Black Enhancer" that's on the ES8000, only difference is, the name change, and its only available to use with "movie" mode. Not standard mode like the 2013 F8000 have. All that takes is a FW release where they can enable it for standard mode and give us the setting to control it. Also, The folks in the UK had their "Black Enhancer" setting and another removed from them last March 2012 from a Firmware update as well, leaving them to be forced to use only the "Standard" setting because the clouding, and flash-lighting (Edge Bleed)  is totally masked in Standard mode.I guess we in the "US" got lucky, because we could use "Movie" mode because we still have the "Black Enhancer" "aka "Cinema Black"  as an option for Movie mode..It looks like some where after CES "January" 2012, they decided to turn the 75" ES8000 into a 75" ES9000 and charge $10K, and make the ES8000 look like its a "lower" end model. IMHO, they removed these settings from us "owners" of the ES8000, just so they can market the 75" ES9000, as being a totally different TV to make it look like its worth the $10K it was charging for it last year, when really they both probably have the same exact hardware in them, and the only difference is the Software. If we still had the "Shadow Detail" which IMO, is basically the "Smart LED" setting, then we wouldn't have that constant dimming they call "Ce" dimming, when using the Standard mode. also, the owners in the UK, wouldn't have so much clouding, and Edge bleeding.So Samsung, I'm curious why the folks in Canada who own the F8000 don't have the "Smart LED" setting? Or the folks in the UK?  Also, do we have to spend $300+ for this Evo Kit in order to get those 2 settings back that you removed from us, after we already owned the TV?And what's up with your Firmware updates? I've had 2 or 3 of my TVs get pretty messed up after it had a FW update. One TV got so bad, it had to be replaced. Ive also seen the picture quality go up and down, up and down, all year long. I never heard of FW updates making things go backwards. Usually, they are to fix bugs, not take steps backwards, and Not change the picture quality so much. Also, It looks like the plasmas and LEDs are the same Firmware. How can a plasma have the same Software/Firmware as an LED? Wouldn't that destroy the plasma over time? I heard that a lot of consumers plasmas "Screens" cracked last year due to heat, and I wouldn't be surprised if this is happening if they are both on the same Firmware. Is this how you made the 2013 F8500 so bright? I think its strange that you have some FW updates go straight to the TVs, and other updates available for download on your site.And, What's up with all these Firmware updates? I heard Sony, Panasonic, and LG's TVs don't get so many Firmware updates as these do. I mean, my 2012 TVs, have had more FW updates then my 2009 iMac. What's up with that Mr. Samsung? Please! I've been waiting for answers about these settings being wiped out of my TVs and others for a year now. Can you please Add them back? We shouldn't have to spend $300 to get them back either. They can be added through a FW update the same way they were removed.I read about you guys losing at court for that class action lawsuit for using those "50 cent " capacitors in your $3k and $4k TVs. Was that done so people will have to buy a new TV every couple of years?  Is this $300 Evo kit being done now, because of that lawsuit? Where as, if you used "reliable" better quality capacitors, then people wouldn't need to buy a new TV for years, but you wouldn't sell so many TVs either and make any profits.. But,  It seems like you found the perfect replacement though with this $300 Evo Kit every year. Congratulations Samsung! You sure are the BEST at marketing. I was hoping to read that 14 million went to your quality control, since IMO, there are just way too many consumers buying These TVs, and having dead pixels, banding, and needing "Main Boards" replaced, and needing to go through like 3 or 4 TVs, before they get a decent one. reviewText: For some reason the idea of a DVD player that upgrades standard DVD to simulated HD DVDs seemed a bit suspicious. I had just replaced our old tube TV with a 40" LCD HDTV. The old DVD player seemed to give OK results, but curiosity got the best of me. I chose the Sony only because the TV was a Sony. Other, less expensive brands may be just as good.With both DVD players hooked up to the same TV I could try the same DVD in both and see if there was any difference. There was. The picture with the Sony upscaling player was noticeably better. There is a lot less pixilation. But, do not expect miracles. It does not get to Blue ray level of clarity.I am quite happy with it until a) the price of Blue Ray players comes down and b) there are a lot more Blue Ray discs available.
summary: It does what it says it will do

reviewText: I'm happy with this cover. It was the second try for me after really disliking a pleather one that wrapped around the whole Kindle, covering the sides. This one leaves the sides free and clear. The way it flips around is pretty smart and innovative, and works, though some bending and fiddling might be needed on first use. The stylus holder is convenient. Being able to use the stand at multiple viewing angles is good too.I dislike how hard it is to put on and remove. I only use it when traveling so I put it on and off more a few times a month and sliding it on and off could be easier. And I wonder about the long term effect of the corners that clip on and off of the Kindle- will they eventually stress the Kindle and damage it or crack the screen? If I kept this case on 24-7 I think this would worry me.  But as I use it only a few times per month, it's not too bad.Crazy nice for the price. (Can't review how it stands up to daily use, but for my purposes, it has been great.)
summary: Looks really nice for being so inexpensive

reviewText: Great value for the money.  Solid quality housing and cables.  Works great with external hard drives, printers, etc.  Does not support charging my Android phone, but now my desk is organized and only one cable to plug in to my laptop.
Easy setup and worked perfectly. It's a bit expensive but I read the aftermarket ones were inconsistent. When presenting to customers, you need to have something that works.

Got this (black one) and the purple one for my wife.  She opted out for a different case instead, but I found this to fight snugly and protects my tablet from accidental drops (I've dropped a few times on hardwood flooring) and also provides some traction for holding so it doesn't slip out of your hands, as the new Nexus 7 (2013) does not have grips like the old one.

This flashdrive was maybe a little too great.  It worked flawlessly and was super small.  Maybe a littel too small - I think I've lost it.  All-in-all I'd buy another one without any negative thoughts.

I was comparing prices to a lightening to VGA and lightening to HDMI. I found it cheaper to buy a lightening to HDMI and a HDMI to VGA. Gives a bit of extra length, which can be good at times. Great price. I'm very happy with this product.
Cheap and works ok.But it looks like its not a standard design, although Amazon said it fits my car, but not true at least for my Hyundai Sonata, too wide to put it into the slot. Will return it.
summary: The device works, but too wide to fit the slot.

reviewText: When it comes to SD media I am not brand loyal.  They all seem to work well.  So price is the main factor, and you can't beat online pricing on this product.
Works well.  Protects my laptop, and has enough room in it for my power cord and mouse.  Would recommend this to others.

Final update adding to the notes below. I ultimately purchased a Yamaha A-S1000 which replaced the need for preamp and amp. I am so happy now. Upon installing the Yamaha I got the biggest grin ever at the most delightful and engaging sound quality I have heard over the past 25 years of my hobby. I have no agenda in posting this just wanted others to have a chance to consider the Yamaha as likely one of the most under celebrated integrated amplifiers of my multi-decade hobby.My original review is below. After several hours of listening, I identified a faulty lamp which was not illuminating. Instead of requesting a return I simply returned it as the sound seemed a little harsh on the upper midrange lower treble. Maybe it simply featured other weaknesses in my system but in the end it resulted in noteworthy listening fatigue. I'm now seeking a little warmer integrated amp to replace several components and a lot of wiring clutter.This unit replaced an Adcom GTP-400 from circa 1990 as I desired subwoofer outputs which the Adcom was lacking. The sound, build quality and feature set of this preamp are tremendous. Thanks Emotiva for building audiophile quality at an affordable price point. Bass extension, clarity, soundstage depth are all excellent in this model.
summary: Ended up returning it after initial happiness replaced with a Yamaha a-s1000bl a must consider albeit more expensive alternative

reviewText: This keyboard works great and I like how you can snap the ipad into it for carrying. i wish it felt firmer when in the propped position. Comes with usb charging cord.

It holds the Nano 6th Gen Ipod perfectly and is comfortable around the neck. Can listen to music with head phones without getting tangled. The only reason it is 3 stars is because I wish the cord wasn't silicone as well. A cotton cord would be stronger and if it beaks you will lose your Ipod Nano. You can still clip the Ipod directly to your collar without this, but then you can't easily grab it to change playlist or see the clock. So with this cord around your neck you have access in a second. If it breaks though at least the headphones are still attached and you should realize it before it falls to the ground. Plan on getting two to replace the broken one when it does happen until something stronger is made. Enjoy!
summary: Fits perfectly but silicone easily broken.

reviewText: This is a terrific small backpack for a big point and shoot.  Lots of pockets are perfect for stuff.  Seems well made.  I don't think I would recommend this item for a DSLR, and multiple lens....not big enough.
summary: Cool backpack for big point and shoot

reviewText: After having bought this motherboard (version 1.1) awhile ago, it was very stable and reliable.  So I bought another one for my wife's computer (version 1.6) and it has been nothing but problems.  Blue screens of death, errors, hanging, freezing, etc. and it's driving us crazy.  The memory and everything else is the same as what I have in my Version 1.1 computer, but to no avail.  I downloaded the latest BIOS (FD) thinking that would fix the problems, but it didn't help.  If you are lucky to get a version 1.1, then you will love it.  If you get a newer 1.6 version, you may hate it.  My faith in Gigabyte has gone way down because of this newer motherboard version.
The is one tough case. It will protect your device from multiple falls with out any evidence of damage to your tablet.
works on my mac, plug in and boom...I have a disc drive. Reads, burns, does everything fast. This is great!
The drive is quick and has given me no issues. Easy to install and set up. A simple 5 star purchase.

I was looking for a tripod to go with my first new DSLR D7000.  Vanguard tripods have some pretty good reviews, so I picked this up when I Amazon offered 20% discount.  It's probably an overkill for this camera but the tripod is beautiful (even has pattern on the legs).  Functionally, it's very complete, even came with carry bag and stone bag.  I only wish it has a strap to tie the legs when folded, but I'll make one, just to make it easier to carry as putting it in and out of the bag is not very practical.  While it has almost all the functions of the more expansive fiber tripod that costs double or triple the price, it is a bit stiff and not as easier to work with.  This is the only reason it gets a 4 stars instead of 5.  I'll update if the joints gets smooths out after some use, together with the durability, then it will deserve the extra star!Update: After 2 weeks of use, it has loosen up a bit but still quite stiff.  I was in a camera shop the other day and check out the Gitzo while waiting.  The Gitzo is definitely more refine and feel lighter (without the ball head).  I noticed that the center column of Gitzo is also made of fiber carbon vs the Vanguard is aluminum.  The Gitzo is no doubt a better tripod but at double the cost.  So all in all, this is still a good alternative for non-professional such as my self.  The rating stays, hopefully, the joints and twists will loosen up after more use, that will make it more close to Gitzo.

So if you page down like 10 pages or more you will see a couple reviews with numbered step by step directions on how to set this modem up with a wireless router. That is what I used. It's easier than it looks. Well at least in my case.I have a 5 yr old Netgear wireless router.I am an existing AT&T; customer with an existing wireless router set up. I'm just replacing a dead modem.You need your AT&T; user name & password. This would be your original e-mail account user name and password. Your user name is your main AT&T; e-mail address. The entire thing, "dot net" or whatever included.So I followed the auto set up directions for the modem and then did the advanced thing noted 10 pages down in these reviews to bridge the modem to the router. Then I unplugged the network cord from the laptop and hooked it up to the router. I went in and changed the router user name & password to the same as the modem & voila - blind bridge!So this took me no time at all! We shall see how long the modem works, it felt a little warm.My usage? .... All wireless ... Laptop, iPhone, kindle, desktop, iPad, printer, BlueRay player (Netflix, pandora, slacker & amazon instant video) ... Not all at once LOLI draggggged my feet because all of the negative reviews but The Walking Dead returns tonight and I won't be able to see it in the morning if my Internet isn't working! It really was simple! Oh BTW don't hook up the modem to a cord/phone jack that has a filter on it! If u just unplug a phone & plug that cord into the modem it won't work because of the filter.Wish me luck. I will post again if it poops out on me.
summary: Replacing a 10 yr old SpeedStream 5100 from when AT&T was SBC Yahoo

reviewText: Considering the price, this keyboard is pretty good. It is a little bit wider than what I expected, though.
These seem to be a great set of headphones for the money.  I might have to get an extra set.

Works exactly as advertised.I have my entire home theater/gaming setup hooked into to this. DVR/Cable Box is hooked into the "always on" outlet and everything else into the switchable outlets (AV receiver, Blu-Ray player, XBox, Wireless bridge, subwoofer).When I'm ready to watch something I push the surge strip's switch from across the room and everything attached to the switchable outlets is provided power (stand-by power - as if plugged into the wall). I turn on what I need and, when I'm all done, I turn all of the equipment switches off (as I would normally) and then push the surge protector switch off from the comfort of my couch 15 feet away. The surge protector turns off everything so nothing is using standby power while not in use.Worked right out of the box the first time - no adjustments needed to be made.Definitely recommend.

I'm an iOS developer with a published app on the App Store. I've developed an iPad application as well and used iOS personally for some time.I'm also a heavy user of Google services (mail, cal, docs, etc.) and after using these on my first break from iOS I was sold on Android.(I used to have a Droid X and now own the Nexus S 4G)However, recently I was thinking of buying a tablet, and in the end after writing up all the features and applications I needed and wanted, giving each one a weight in importance and then rating the experience and quality of each on both platforms based on reviews, the Samsung came our ahead (very slightly) for my criteria at least. There are a number of things I really would have wanted the iPad for (It is sooo shiny!) but in the end I bought the Samsung.I love the Mac (owning both a Gaming PC and the new 27" iMac and MacBook pro) but I get more done with less hassle in the Google ecosystem.What appeals to me about honeycomb 3.1 (I am quite pleasantly surprised at just how much better it is than gingerbread) is how closely it ties with your Google account. But this was not even what I based my decisions on (those were things like screen quality, connectivity, battery life, etc)However, there was some issue with the Samsung. Mainly for me was the problem with the keyboard dock intermittently not being recognized fully, as well as sporadic temporary problems downloading apps from the market (tested on several different WiFis and even after a factory reset type thing)I am hoping these issues may be sorted out, but although disappointing, I have decided it may not be worth giving up (and returning it) on what I have come to love otherwise.PS: I also don't like Flash (hate that as much as Skype and Facebook), AND I would have loved to have a iPad to develop on.. but the other plusses of the Android just shines.
summary: Solid Tablet, some issues with accessories.

reviewText: Just bought the Bose Companion 5, and this is what happened:First, the setup is as easy as Bose wants you to believe.  It took mere minutes, and my i7 Windows 7 Dell Studio XPS had this thing configured very quickly and painlessly.  One thing to remember is that you have to get into the sound setup in the Control Panel to ensure that the Bose is the default system, it does not happen automatically.  The cords provided are long enough to allow for slack and easy hook-up.Second, I gotta say that the aesthetics are fantastic.  This system takes up less room and looks great.  The bass module, however, needs some real estate underneath the desk (not in terms of height or width, but in length, it is 17" long).  The graphite and silver finish is also pleasing in terms of looks and contrast.Third, the integrated volume/input pod is great, easy to use, and unobtrusive.  It allows for easy connection of another source (2 channel), headphones, and when it is tapped on the top automatically goes into mute mode, another tap and it goes live again.Finally, let me tell you about the sound.....it SUCKED!  I couldn't believe it, after spending a premium amount of money and getting a system that sounded tinny and muddy, so tinny that it hurt my ears to listen.I read the manual, look online, and was almost ready to pack them up.  I then tried 1 final thing, I turned the volume control on my computer down to 50%, and then double-checked the bass knob and turned that down to 50%.  Both were originally maxed out.It solved the problem.  They sounded like they did in the store.  Fantastic treble and tight bass, with a good overlap of midrange from the satellites.Now I show these off to my friends and family and they are blown away.  But this was an accidental discovery.  MAKE SURE THE SOURCE IS AROUND 50%, YOUR ITUNES (or other program) VOLUME IS NOT MAXED OUT, AND YOUR BASS MODULE KNOB IS AT 50%.Finally, your music WILL FREEZE UP if you don't have a pretty recent machine.  I lucked out with my i7 processor-based machine, but you're taking a gamble if your machine is older than 2 years old, in my opinion.Anyway, hope this helps!
summary: Almost returned this piece of junk

reviewText: This is a really way to convert a plug into a usb wall plate.  You essentially plug the unit into the top plug and voila, you're done.  We set this up in our kitchen so we could plug in our tablets and other devices for use to play music, etc. without having to worry about a charge.  Worked like a charm.  I would also bring this if I was traveling but not necessarily staying in a hotel so that I could use USB options for charging without having to monopolize the USB ports on our laptop.It sticks out from the wall just a bit, so it's not something you'd put in a place where you'd want a flush outlet.  I'm also not sure why they didn't set it up so that it only covered the bottom plug (like some wall extension cords) so you could still have use of both plugs with the added benefit of the USB.  This makes it so you can only use the one plug and the second plug is completely covered by the USB ports.  Aesthetically it looks more appealing, but practically speaking I think I might have preferred an alternate design.It works well, it blends in pretty nicely and it gets top ratings for ease of use.

A word to IT Equipment Express, who's selling these at $850...I got one of these babies for 1/4 that price.  That's right, a little over $200 for a NEW one!  Your price is WRONG, baby!  So very wrong.  As is your ENTIRE online store I see!  Holy Cow.  I just noticed you're hocking these same wares on eBay too, even though you don't have them in stock!  Shameful.  I hope Amazon takes notice of this and encourages you to perform some "minor" price corrections and only list things you actually have to sell!  The average price for these Garmin devices now is about $270 and that's a GREAT price for a GREAT product.  That price is RIGHT, baby!  Boo yeah.

Second pair of headphones for kids we have bought, the first being the highly rated Kidz GearKidz Gear Wired Headphones For Kidsthat our now 6 year old uses.  When these arrived, of course the older kid liked the looks better (has animal figures and the Kidz Gear are not that cutesy) and even tried to tell me hers were broken! :)I wanted to try a different brand since I always thought the Kidz Gear sounded terrible (very muffled, like you were listening with cotton stuck in your ears)So these arrive, and yes they are cute.  They also seem to be a little sturdier (although that has not been a problem to date with the Kidz Gear as they are still working after many intl/overnight flights) and maybe almost TOO inflexible in some parts, as the fit doesn't seem to be as good as the Kidz Gear, which conform a little better to the shape of the head.So back to the sound quality:  I am not trying to raise audiophiles, but on the other hand, why submit very low fidelity sound to your kids, especially given that many of the songs they are hearing for the first time?  Also knowing that it's certainly possible to produce a headphone that sounds 2x better than these at the same cost.  The earbuds that came with several phones and mp3 players as freebies sound MUCH better than both of these phones.So, yes I am being picky, and I do realize that most parents just don't care about sound quality themselves in many cases, much less for the kids, but I am not one of those parents.  Would you want to buy glasses for your kids that are hazy and unclear?Anyway, I give three stars PRIMARILY based on sound quality, which is poor, at best.  Construction seems OK, price is OK I guess, but I will continue my search.Will update here if I find the Holy Grail of children's headphones.  :)
summary: Kids love 'em, but sound quality is pretty bad

reviewText: Connecting this keyboard to my iMac was a painless procedure, which is great because I've had problems with Logitech keyboards in the past (the Desktop Wave Pro, anyone?). Right off the bat, I noticed that it responds quickly to key taps and that the keys aren't too loud, but they do have a bit of resistance, which I like as someone concerned with ergonomics. As for the solar aspects, my desk faces the sun, and I've never once had a problem with this keyboard pooping out on me, even though it's my backup since I use a Kinesis Advantage full-time. Still, when people come over who are freaked out by my Advantage, this one does the job since it's a more familiar layout, and the lack of charging when it gets access to the sun is a fantastic bonus. All around couldn't be happier with it!

I bought this based on the generally good reviews here.  I tried it for a few days but it wasn't anything like I expected.  First of all, I realized immediately that even with a high quality notebook screen, glare was going to be a problem in a car.  Also, having to use a mouse and keyboard to enter data over to your side requires you to be stopped when using it for safety reasons.  But that's not Garmin's fault.  But where the Garmin really fell down was in things that it shouldn't have a problem with.1. Accuracy.  Inconsistent.  The maps were ok and even had many new roads in my area, but when I typed in an address and started following directions, they were just plain wrong.  In one trip to an apartment that was even listed on their map itself, the unit kept trying to make me do a U turn half a mile before I reached the actual apartment.  This would drive someone crazy if they were not familiar with the place's location already.  Input a street address and sometimes it would be incorrect on the map.  I knew the area well and otherwise it would have been a very frustrating trip to find the address.2.  Data input.  When trying to type in a new address to find, it would not recognize the proper spelling of many roads, and I would have to play games to "trick" the unit into accepting an address.  Gate parkway N had to be inputted as N gate pkwy, or Touchton Road had to be put in as E Touchton Road, when it is not called that on street signs or anywhere else.  Time consuming.3.  Interface:  I also found it less than intuitive to simply plot a trip, even w/o waypoints.  It was a little less easy to use than some of the portable units I've seen demo tapes of.4.  Directions:  I tried to plan a trip to Tampa and was given a route that I knew to be longer and more difficult than just using the interstates.  I guess because it was shorter in miles.  I changed the preferences to weigh towards the interstates, but then it took me on loops around the perimeter here that made no sense.  In another instance it had me drive by a place, avoid u-turning to get into it, then drive 5 miles in a loop around town to come back to it.  But clicking off "avoid u turns" fixed that.  The problem is, it then had me U-turning at every chance possible.5.  points of interest.  Pretty good, including some very obscure places here.  But also many obvious ones were simply missing.  I'm not sure how one gets his restaurant or store  added to their maps, but when they don't include them all, you lose faith in the machine.  It's better than nothing, but not good enough to rely on.My conclusion is that no computer navigator is going to be as good as a human brain with a map.  So for that reason the routing feature of these devices is not very useful to me.  But, I could use a nice color moving map which advised me of upcoming street names, sort of a driving "assistant".  And for that, they'd do fine.  However, using gps with your laptop isn't a great idea in practice unless you have a fancy setup to point it at yourself and hold it firmly in place, and the space to do so, like in a pickup truck.  You need to be able to see the screen and you can't keep looking to your side to check it.I would advise getting an inexpensive portable unit you can attach in your line of site, entering the destination, using it to get into the general area, then figuring out how to get to the place itself on your own and just use the map as an aide to that.  It is very helpful to see a graphical display of the upcoming roads.  Units that name the roads for you are much more helpful but cost a lot more.I would NEVER trust these type of units to put me in the proper lane for an exit at high speed on the interstates.  They require too much of your attention and what you gain from them you use in awareness of what's going on outside.I also was concerned over having my expensive notebook computer in the car all the time, more prone to damage or theft, than otherwise.The unit was great at finding a signal, even indoors it did ok.
Works as expected.  Now if I just had enough memory on my computer to unload the buckets of images I take!
summary: Bought for our Canon EOS T3i

reviewText: I already have the Tecsun 390 and love it..the stereo speakers, the ETM features, great AM reception and exceptional FM reception..best I ever heard in a portable. However,it is a little big to carry in a shirt or jacket pocket and I wanted a similar radio to carry on walks with me wherever i go..hence the Tecsun 606.AM is not quite as good as the 390, which makes sense because of the smaller ferrite antenna and there is no direct frequency keys, but the FM is still incredible and it's small size makes it the ideal pocket radio.One thing I've noticed on the Tecsuns...there is absolutely no spillover of adjacent FM signals when you are in big cities. Every pocket radio I've owned, including the highly regarded Sangeans 120 and 210 have that problem when traveling through cities..the spillover of FM signals and sometimes not being able to pick up a signal at all..but not the Tecsun models. In Manhattan last week I was picking up Trenton,NJ's 101.5, Long island's 98.3 and Connecticut's 96.7 and 107.9 with amazing clarity. As I have stated, the FM reception is the best I have ever heard on a portable radio.Once in a while the radio will freeze up,but a little button pushing will alleviate that.The 606 is a little bigger than the two Sangean portables I mentioned, but this is my pocket portable from now on. At $50 this is quite a bargain.

This is a nice solid bag for small cameras. Has two side zippered pockets,another inside the flap zippered pocket that is perfect for memory cards. A flexible soft divider wall inside. Also included is a detachable shoulder strap, grab handle, and a belt loop. Says it fits Canon PowerShot SX20 IS, Nikon Coolpix P10, and similar sized cameras. Measures 7"x5"x4"

The OK/Record button did not work at first (had to mush it down really hard to get it to register).The worst part of this is the video quality - absolutely horrible regardless of resolution setting.  The mic picks up a huge amount of white noise that makes the audio unusable.  I could do better with an old Android phone, a mount, and a dash cam app.

I looked around for days and weeks to find my next perfect camera... After I quit pro photography, I wanted to have something that I can satisfy my urges to take good photos from time to time... The things I look for a camera usually clear sharp images, hot shoe to be able to use my remote trigger if I need to use strobes sometimes... and fast lens. I found all that in LX7, bar-none the best camera around for the price vs. features and image/built quality! It's not a plastic toy, that's for sure.Let me tell you something... if a camera gets its biggest complain from it's "hanging" lens cap, that should say a lot about the overall quality of it.Here are the complains about this camera that I read here and other places...1-Lens cap... thank God for the Auto Lens Cover (I got one too), but I would NOT have any complains using the cap came with it... just like on DSLR cameras.2-Sensor size... Really? With F1.4 lens, I would give a rat's rear end for the sensor size... It gives perfect results and that counts for me the most.3-Slow zoom in/out... Ok, go somewhere else then. It sure is slow and I am not making an Oscar winning movie with it... so I don't really care. Again, fast... I mean FAST focusing just makes up that "slow" zooming!!!4-No viewfinder! Sold separately... I confess, I tried to get closer to this camera a few times, thinking there is one... and little weird to take photos looking at the LCD screen, but not a big deal!5-Only 24-90mm zoom! Again... really? some of the compact cameras sold more than $1K have prime lenses, either 35mm, 50mm... etc. which, none of them as fast as F1.4.There are more complains, but they are there practically just to complain about something, nothing else.So, in short... If you are/were a pro photographer... or not, and want a camera that will get you perfect photos, with or without total manual settings... this is your machine. Check out my sample pictures. I finally uploaded some that this camera deserves.PS: Video quality is superb... I and really LOVE the fast recording option which shows slow motion actions... pretty cool :)
summary: Love it... I simply love this camera!

reviewText: LED light on the device alone is a great feature! Charges everything just like a factory charger without a fuss. I use it to charge my Galaxy S5 and iPhone 4S. Never had a problem.

reviewText: at times the item feels like it was cheaply made, but so far it functions well and I'm rather happy with it.I've only had it for 2 days, so I don't know if it will last but we'll see

I bought this bag when I bought my first DSLR.  The bag is excellent as a small bag for a quick trip.  This bag has some pretty great features.  On the outside, the bottom has a EVA plastic base that protects from water and minor dings.  There's also air mesh padding on the back of the bag to help it breathe where it lays against your body.  Inside, the bag has a neoprene suspension system that keeps the camera from laying on the bottom of the bag, since it loads lens first.  Also, the inside of the flap, the bag has memory foam padding to protect the LCD screen on the back of your camera.  There's plenty of room for a Canon 60D camera with 18-200mm IS lens.  You won't be able to fit another lens or other large accessory, but there is room for a charger, battery, and lens caps or filters.  Over all, for what the bag is, I give it 5 stars.  If you need a bag to carry more lenses or lots of gear, get something larger.  But if you like to travel light or don't have a lot of lenses or other items, this bag will work great.

These are great. Best present I gave my husband (really for me since I make them use them when watching t.v. late). Great price!! They don't have bluetooth - so have to stay in front of the set so perfect for bedroom.

Couldn't shrink it with Clean Master; you need to reset to factory defaults to clean it out.  So, as long as you don't mind wiping your device every few months (which obviously no one does), it is fine.  Looks like people talking to Amazon customer service have found out the people at Amazon have zero clue what is in Others as well.  Super duper.

reviewText: In general Rocksmith 2014 is an extremely viable product. It has a lot of room to improve but remains the best product in its class. I am, however, very disappointed about two specific issues. First is the outrageously expensive DLC. Based on this pricing I have no plans on ever buying any of the extra available songs, turning this into a somewhat dead-end experience. This ultimately limits the game because it comes with such a small number of songs to learn, and most of them are terribly annoying. So if you are a customer without hundreds of extra dollars to spend on songs after buying Rocksmith, you may want to avoid this product. The problem is so severe that 3rd party websites have popped up allowing Rocksmith 2014 users to take control of the DLC situation. Good job Ubisoft--I now need a 3rd party site?! The second major problem with Rocksmith 2014 is the developer's completely ignoring existing guitar education methods while attempting to re-invent the wheel. I can appreciate giving gamers a GUI that will ween them off Guitar Hero but Rocksmith 2014 has no traditional music staves or guitar tablature. Instead they've invented 3D music blocks that fly at you and have weird shapes. This leaves players without the foundation they will need to go out into the real world as musicians.So, about playing the game. All things considered this is still a great product. First a few big impressions: I am learning lead guitar fast with this thing, there are (Windows) bugs, Ubisoft site / Uplay is a fail, and I do feel the pain many are experiencing with installation, though I am personally a tech-wiz who loves Steam and navigated the install without a hitch. I sold my old Peavey and I'm now playing a new Epiphone SG Special in honor of this great event. While Steam proudly displays my 90+ hours invented into Rocksmith, it seems the Ubisoft Uplay system has failed to recognize much of my progress. So, the 60-day challenge, which I entered just for fun, isn't properly being tracked. According to Uplay the last time I played the game was on the 18th even though I've been playing daily. So, although I was going to remove a star for the above mentioned issues, I'm leaving at five due to my overall impression. History will be looking back fondly upon this one.ORIGINAL REVIEW: I am extremely impressed with Rocksmith 2014 here on my Asus laptop running Windows 8.1. This is an addictive experience that has left my fingertips tingling and my mind racing with new guitar ideas. I do have some minimal guitar skills but my main background is drumming, and I've never played any other guitar games (such as Guitar Hero). Other reviewers with heavy guitar background might paint a more complete picture, but from my perspective as a gamer and electric guitar noob Ubisoft has a monster on their hands!This Cable-bundled package has a very special cable. I've been waiting my whole life for something like this to exist. While I am using a really messed up old guitar, the idea of $200 package with a ready-to-use guitar is beyond my belief right now. I cannot think of a hotter holiday item--ever. It really works! The computer recognizes what you play while helping with calibration and tuning. This system allows people like me to learn and round out areas of musical weakness, such as all the scales I've been so lazy about. The way the product teaches, analyses, and suggests the next step is tear-jerking for a technology and music fanatic like myself. I can see a new generation of musicians fueled by this technology, unlike the plastic guitar tradition that came before it. Ubisoft did a lot of work to bring this evolved system together, and I cannot even comment on the prior version. I can say this version is really amazing.Buying this retail box unlocks your Steam key -- Steam being the digital distribution system the game is founded upon. Ubisoft also runs their own client in the background which requires its own login; thankfully it does not get in the way, but does require its own one-time account setup. Steam then remains the portal through which all additional song purchases are made. These song "lessons" contain what appear to be extremely detailed training packages, showing riffs, licks, tricks, rhythm, and bass for each song. They've done some homework. The songs that come with the package are quite impressive. Watching "lead" parts at 100% challenge level reveals how much work has gone into this. I really look forward to mastering these licks.Since the plastic Rockband days I really was reminded this would one day become a reality. It has, and then some. The retro-style mini-games, lessons, session modes, and overall attention-grabbing content makes this a very compelling product.
summary: Decent Game And Somewhat Helpful For Guitar Education

This is one detail I missed.I did test this as a headphone USB dac with my laptop alongside the ODAC and E7 and both sounded cleaner with what seemed like a lower noise floor, but both are over 2x the price of this.Having tried Muse DAC's with burr wilkins chips in the past I preferred those over the TI but for the price this isn't a bad DAC.

reviewText: I got the ASUS WL-330gE to use as a router while traveling. I often stay at hotels where the wifi is great in the lobby but not in the rooms.  I don't want to sit at the desk on a plugged in laptop with the family waiting for their turn.  It took me less than 5 minutes to setup the ASUS WL-330gE including the time to take it out of the box. While traveling I connected it to the ethernet connection in the hotel room, set up a password, and 3 generations in 2 rooms were able to get online for all their email and web surfing needs.  I was a very popular mom on this trip.In addition, the ASUS WL-330gE comes with its own storage cover, is very small and easy to put in bag. I used it for the family which had 2 iPads, an iPhone, iPod, 2 laptops and a Blackberry. The only problem we had was grandma kept trying to download a huge video file to show us, and every time she started everyone would begin yelling about their connection speed, but if we heard her giggling in the next room, then we new what the problem was.
summary: ASUS WL-330gE makes a terrific travel router! easy to use and great quality!

I am so impressed with this company!I purchased a TV from Amazon and purchased this warranty. The first TV was defective, and I returned it for another. I forgot to update the  serial # information when the new TV arrived. Fast forward to when the 2nd TV's DVD player stopped worked and I realize my mistake. Fortunately I have all the paperwork, and get prepared to battle.I filed the claim, used the pre-paid label to send the TV back, expecting an issue because the serial number doesn't match (the TV was the same model). What happened?To my delight, I received an email with my Amazon gift card just a couple days after sending the TV for the full amount I paid. I had the NC200W on my Amazon wish list and got them as a gift, and since then have been able to use them when traveling on airplanes, both jet and turboprop.  Initially, I tried them at home in a quiet environment and was extremely disappointed. The sound was muted, with muddy bass and unclear high frequencies.  I just left music play on them for a few hours to "break-in" the headphones, then started using them on flights. To my surprise, in actual noisy environments, these are superb noise canceling headphones. The bass is good, there's a little too much emphasis on the midtones (presumably due to the Linx technology), and the high notes are okay.  These headphones work much better in a steady noise environment, where listening conditions are far from ideal.  They will not replace headphones designed for a quiet environment though, but are acceptable for that purpose.  In terms of noise canceling, the NC200W appears to cut out about 85-90% of ambient noise.  With music playing, it is nearly impossible to hear pilot/flight attendant announcements. Build quality is good. I have had no issues with folding or adjustments. Based on Amazon reviews, the white color model appears to be more durable than the black color version. Another thing to note is that the headphones come with a soft bag for storage, and it has a very useful long drawstring. The drawstring allows the user to place the bag over the head, so you don't lose the bag or leave it behind, plus you don't have to bury the headphones or dig them out of a carry-on bag in the airplane aisle while boarding, because you can just wear the bag. I've used other noise canceling headphones over the last 15 years, and these are superior to noise isolation earbuds which don't have active cancellation and don't have as strong a bass response. These are the equals or betters of headphones that are/were three times the price, making them a great value, as I've paid $200-300 for older sets from other manufacturers that didn't cancel noise as well. Thus, if you can live with the limitation that these aren't quiet environment headphones, I would highly recommend them to you.

The Patriot XT flash drives are the best for speed and reliability.  I move tons of data (documents, graphics and photos) to my flash drives, and after I make changes to some of the data, I copy to the flash drive again (replace existing folder), several times a day moving multiple gigs of data (obviously hard on the drive, but I don't know a better way to save my work.  And, really I care much more about saving work that I put thousands of hours into, than I care about a flash drive.  I can always buy a new drive, but I can't get my work (data) back if it is lost.I know that my use is hard on the drives and I have killed many flash. So, to be careful, I back up onto several flash drives, plus a Maxtor External hard drive.  I have tried many different brands and Patriot XT drives (XT Boost and XT Rage) are by far the best.  Remember, I have killed many flash drives, but I have never had any problems with any Patriot drives.  Also, I have never had a problem with any PNY drives.But the Patriot XT drives are MUCH FASTER, so I am gradually switching to only Patriot drives.The other fact you should know about speed is that the smaller drives are faster, I just tested a Patriot XT Boost 4GB, Patriot XT Boost 8GB, Patriot XT Boost 16GB, Patriot XT Rage 16 GB along with a PNY 8GB and a PNY 16 GB by moving 3GB (one folder containing thousands of documents) of data onto each drive.  The Patriot drives are all much faster than the PNY drives, and the Patriot XT Rage is faster than the Patriot XT Boost, but within each brand the smaller drive consistently beat the larger ones in speed.  So save your money and buy the smallest drive that will meet your needs.  When you grow out of the drive, there will be new ones on the market that will be better and less expensive.Bottom line:  I am buying more Patriot XT flash drives.
summary: Survives Incredible Abuse and Really FAST

This router is a powerhouse in and of itself but Linksys did a terrible, just terrible job with the firmware on it and updates just don't come soon enough.I went through hell the first month+ with this thing....my internet speed would drop from 20Mb to 2Mb within a few days of use, the router would randomly reboot within a week and there were just issues that made it so it just wasn't worth the money or trouble and a surprising bad linksys product.Being interested in technology though, I'm not one to give up easily so I worked through the problems and discovered that there's a fatal flaw in the firmware which makes it so that many of the built in features that most users would want or need have to be disabled for it to work properly.I disabled the Home Defender and Upnp and voila!, finally I had a router that is worthy of the price.For the record, the router can't be easier to set up and the web portal is easy to configure and use. The range is pretty great. 2k sq ft. apartment and 5 bars using 2.4GHz N and G mode. 4-5 bars using 5Ghz N mode with great speeds - the closer the better of course, when it comes to 5Ghz. Simultaneous band use means that I can use one mode for G and N and the other for N - being able to use both bands at the same time is truly a great thing at this point in time, as I have many G devices that would pull down my N speeds if I had to use mixed mode.There has been a firmware update as of late 2010 which claims to fix some of the issues but I haven't tested it. I'd decided that I would either sell the box or run alternative firmware, and so I picked running the firmware which worked nicely for me.In the end, I cannot recommend the router as it is. However, with some tweaks and/or alternative firmware this is a great router and I would wholeheartedly recommend it.Pros:Good hardwareInformative lightsGreat featuresEasy to setup and useCons:Terrible 'initial' firmware (2009)Must disable some of the very features which make the router attractive for it to actually workRequires too many front end tweaks to work, this is typical of a low/mid brand router - not a top brandRemember, if you use one of these or purchase one recently and it comes with the B0 firmware simply disable Home Defender and Upnp to get yours to work as it should.You should also attempt to update the firmware if you can, as that MAY fix some of these issues.If you are somewhat tech savvy, consider applying DDWRT firmware to really unlock the power of this device. With DDWRT I rate this thing 5 stars all around.
summary: A potential powerhouse of a router

reviewText: I bought EyeTV knowing that my "TV-on-a-Mac" needs were simple. I didn't need "component video and HDTV and 1080 progressive scan" and whatnot.  I just needed the EyeTV to connect to my cable service (analog, no HDTV), connect to my MacBook G4 or my MacMini G4, and play TV on my Apple Cinema Display.After about a week of ownership I think the EyeTV has been fantastic.  It was extremely easy to set up, and within minutes I had TV on my Mac.  The TV feed is buffered, so (just like a DVR/Tivo), you can watch live TV and skip commercials. You can set the viewing window size from small (put it in a corner and watch while you work) to full screen (forget work, just goof off!)Scheduling recordings is very easy due to a link to a service (Titan) that maintains current TV schedules. You can schedule shows to be recorded from anywhere you have an Internet connection by signing in to your Titan account (free).  Your scheduling choices will be transferred to your Mac if it is connected to the Internet.  You can even have the recording software wake your computer, or even start it (if you allow auto log-in), when it's time to record.  There is a basic video editor, helpful for removing commercials from your recorded material.  You can also take screen shots.Multiple export options are available, and while I haven't tried them all, I did try exporting to a QuickTime Movie format.  It may be that the G4 processor is too slow, but the conversion took...3 DAYS.  I tried exporting to MPEG and the same thing.  Toast software is included for burning to DVDs, but I don't have a DVD burner to test that.  A remote control is included, although I sit at my Mac, so I don't need it.Bottom line: I love this device/software combo and think it's a good value.Why 4 instead of 5 stars?  The picture quality is only "good."  Good enough for TV watching, but definitely not like watching a DVD. And based on my G4 processor - forget about converting formats.
summary: Great product for my simple needs

reviewText: This dual band router is easy to setup and use.  It is configured to work out of the box.  Once plugged into an active cable modem, the software shows the unique names and passwords for the two wireless frequency bands.  The guest networks are also uniquely configured as well, but they have to be activated by the Netgear Genie software before they can be used.The Netgear Genie configuration and monitoring software is straight forward.  It is easy to change the names of the network ids as well as other technical stuff as needed.  But the router is basically ready to go out of the box.This router is feature rich with things like network printing, sharing a USB storage device on a home network, and performance monitoring software.  But the two features that I like the most have to do with smartphones.  The Netgear Genie software has the ability to enable AirPrint, which allows for direct printing from an iPhone to a Windows-based printer, whether the printer is USB or network connected.  I can now print an email or a PDF file directly from my smartphone to an old USB-connected HP printer that is attached to a Windows-based laptop.The second feature that is pretty neat is that the Netgear Genie software is also available as downloadable app.  This puts network monitoring capability of a home network onto a handheld smartphone.  This makes for a handy diagnostic tool.This router is nicely engineered inside and out.  On the outside, the casing is a glossy black and shiny tower that stands at a slight tilt.  As a result, it has an aesthetically-looking modern look to it.This router is comfortably running three laptops, two iPhones and a Roku box.  The speeds on all of these devices, as unscientifically tested by a web-based speed test site, are the same throughout our home.  The throughput being 25-megabits per second download, and 4-megabits per second upload. The wireless speed test results were also identical at 50 feet or five feet, but more interestingly, they were also the same whether tested wirelessly or wired directly into the back of the router.  In the past, "wired" was usually a better performance bet, but this advantage seems to be disappearing with these high-speed wireless routers.This is an excellent and easy-to-use router with fast throughput and flawless performance.
summary: NETGEAR WIRELESS ROUTER AC 1200 DUAL BAND R6200 - Easy-to-use, fast and flawless
