I recently purchased the PN42C450 from through Dell.com. Although my experience with Dell customer service leaves much to be desired, I really don't have anything bad to say about the TV. I've been nothing but thrilled since I've gotten it. Sure, I'm sure part of it is because it's my first high def TV, but I'm also very critical of my large purchases. This TV also had high expectations to live up to, since I had read so many positive things in other reviews.I'll start off with picture quality, because that's what most people want to know about. I'm completely pleased with it overall, and would definitely recommend it to others. Some people have said that it's obviously 720p, but I honestly can't tell the difference. My brother recently purchased a 54" 1080p plasma, and granted the picture was nicer than mine, but it wasn't worth the price he paid -- almost triple what this TV costs! For the low price of this TV, the picture quality can't be beat! The color saturation and contrast is great, as are the black levels. It isn't exactly as crisp as I had expected, but I think this may be in part because I have only watched high def programming via cable TV so far. I have yet to test it with a BluRay player. However, I generally notice even better results when I stream HD videos via the HDMI connection on my laptop. In any event, turning up the sharpness level is much more effective on this TV than on old standard def TVs, and that does help quite a bit. Picture controls are great too... I like the layout of the menus, and there are plenty of options to tweak the picture to your liking. I generally don't need to use the black level enhancement because the blacks are so rich already, but I love the dynamic contrast feature under advanced settings. There is a low, medium and high setting (just like the black enhancement) and it does a wonderful job at making colors pop. It can make great video look even more vivid, and it's especially great for bringing some life into dreary looking programming.The sound quality is not nearly as bad as I had expected. I'm actually quite pleased with it. It won't act as a home theater system by any means, but for TV sound it is more than adequate. It wasn't complained about much, but there were several people who seemed displeased. I now think they probably hadn't adjusted the settings in the proper way. The "SRS TruSurround HD" definitely needs to be turned on and left on. That is definitely the most important sound aspect. It isn't like most simulated surround that just adds a lot of echo... it actually has very little echo. It makes the sound fuller, emphasizes the bass a little, and makes it more pleasing overall. It really gives it more of a high def sound, rather than the flat/boring sound you're used to from old tube TVs. Apart from that, I used the EQ to add a little bass because that's how I prefer it, and I am good to go. I have it hooked up to my stereo and I rarely even use it.As far as the infamous buzzing issue goes, I don't have an issue with it. The TV does have a very slight buzz from its normal operation, but it is only barely noticeable when the TV is paused/muted. It is completely normal from what I've read, and is normal with any plasma TV. That was a relief because it was the thing I was most worried about. I did some research though, and came to find out that the buzzing sound becomes worse in higher altitudes. I live in Michigan and my elevation is a mere 594 feet, so I am sure this is why I have no issue with the buzzing sound. However, if you live in high altitudes, do some extensive research before buying ANY plasma TV.Another issue I was worried about was the stand, and attaching it to the TV. Almost every single review I read said it was incredibly difficult to insert the screws, and some people even recommended using lubricant or a power drill. However, I had no issue at all. I used a regular screwdriver from the toolbox and was not at all strained by tightening the screws all the way. I am assuming that this issue must have been resolved since the TV was released.The TV is very elegant and classy looking. The glossy finish does attract dust quite easily, but a microfiber cloth is included. The build of the TV and stand seems very sturdy and it does not look cheap at all. For being one of the cheapest plasmas out there, it sure doesn't look like it.This TV has also opened my eyes to the world of plasma -- since everyone I know has LCD, I had pretty much decided in the beginning that I would get it. However, I was limited to Dell.com and the only LCD in my price range had gotten some pretty negative reviews. So, I did some research on plasma and decided to give it a try. I must say that I am incredibly pleased and I have come to find out that I prefer plasma to LCD. The picture is much warmer, less artificial looking and the plasma technology is what gives you such rich colors and deep blacks. Those aspects of this TV will not be found in any LCD in a similar price range. Keep in mind that any light source aimed at the TV will reflect off the screen, so you can't set a lamp next to the TV or have a window open with light shining directly on it. Oh, but definitely buy an extended warranty with this TV... because I've read many bad things about Samsung's customer service, and you'll want something to fall back on just in case.In closing, I can't stress enough how happy I am with my purchase. This TV is the best bang for your buck in the price range and it really delivers! As of March 2011, I'd say $450 or less is quite a good price for the TV. A little haggling got me down to $400, but trust me... the extra $50 would have still been worth it!

I generally really enjoy Sennheiser products.  I've been using the neckband, corded headphones for the gym for years now it seems.  Even the Adidas branded version has been great.  Not to mention I've got two pairs of wireless headphones for both work and home.  It's a good brand.The trouble with these headphones for me is fit.  Right out of the box, you've got several different types of adapters to shove these into your ear-holes so they'll stay.  Well, I sweat like a pig so these had little chance of staying in my ears.  I must have fiddled with the different tips for several minutes on the treadmill before I just gave up.  I think if you've had prior experience with this type of fit for your headphones, between the multiple tips included, you would be fine.  However in my case, I just couldn't get these to work.  I did like the sound when I had music on but they won't stay.  These would probably work better for me in the car, or on the airplane where there won't be a lot of jostling.  Again, if you like the fit, these might be for you.
summary: Great sound quality but how do they stay in?

reviewText: These are excellent powerline adapters -- well made, speedy (in theory), with very useful bells and whistles. If you know you want one, these are the ones to get.But the Netgear promotional material above is carefully-worded. It never quite says that networking your electronic devices is easy. It says that establishing a network among powerline adapters is easy. Getting your  devices to recognize and work with that network, though, can be either easy or a nightmare, depending on your particular devices and their set-up. It's not any harder with these adapters than with hard-wired or wireless networks, but it isn't any easier.Powerline networks also face the problem that your power lines weren't designed to be networks. There are a lot of signals on the lines -- garbage signals kicked back from computers, appliances, and other things. Network signals have to fight through that traffic. (That's why these adapters have filtered outlets -- the stuff you want to network is often the stuff putting out the most garbage, so the filter prevents it from getting to the power lines -- but you have a lot of other, unfiltered stuff plugged into your walls.) In addition, your wiring may be new and good like an interstate highway, or old and cruddy like a dirt road. These things affect how fast  the network can be and how far it can reach. It slows down with distance and eventually can't get through. That's why these adapters also have LEDs to tell you how good the signal is.I don't want to overstate the problem; wireless networks also have issues with speed, distance, and interference. But the speed of a powerline network is very much a your-mileage-may-vary thing. These adapters are rated at 200 MBps. On paper that's much faster than the common wireless-g network standard (though slower than the newer wireless-n). But you won't get 200, or anywhere near it. Maybe you'll be faster than wireless, maybe not (especially because wireless network speed is also YMMV). And you won't have the convenience of a wireless network.If you really want a wired network, consider having the wires put in your walls. It isn't really all that big or expensive a deal (people don't hesitate to call the cable tv company to come put in a new outlet or move an old one, after all, and that's basically the same process). And its a much faster network than powerline or wireless (but also much faster than you probably need). If you don't want to do that, though, and for some reason don't want wireless, buy these.
summary: Good units but consider the issues and alternatives

reviewText: The cover was warped and would not close and would not turn of the mini. It was a pretty color, but not useable.
Sorry that I did not buy the Nikon D600 early. Interesting that Nikon is not selling a warranty for this camera.

The Nano Plus could be mistaken for a cigarette lighter.  Perfect size for walking around your neighborhood, but if you travel alot for long periods of time, you might want something 4GB and up.  This easily fits into your jeans pocket so you're more likely to carry it around than a 30GB iPod which reminds me of the Palm V I discarded because I didn't want to carry a man purse to hold it.  ;)The trick is to encode in Windows Media format (WMA) instead of MP3.  I converted my 192kps mp3s using WMA VBR 50 setting and you cannot hear much of a difference.  But the file size now is just half of the mp3 file size, so I can fit about 340 songs on it.  BTW, the player only has 980MB usable space, which peeved me to no end (same scam that hard drive makers got sued over).This player has no playlist function and will play songs alphabetically according to file name (not imbedded ID tag).  You can separate song files into file folders and use that as a simple playlist.  For audio books, you should just label your chapters "author - book - ch 01 - title.mp3" to get them to play in order.  Also, re-encode your audiobook files using mono setting.  It'll reduce your file size by half and save you lots of space.I really love everything about this player.  It does scratch easily though.  They give you a rubber case, but it doubles the thickness.  However, it fits nicely in a metal Altoids mints case.  :)
You can just tell these are high quality and reliable.  They get the job done...got my tv hooked up to cable box and PS3.

I agree totally with other reviewers, my now broken Logitech 203's were awesome. Gone forever though, as all good things. I tried these 313's at Best Buy... they sounded better than the larger Insignia model NS-PCS41's which were boomy, and had no mid range at all... stay away from those. I have a large stereo now in the man cave, so don't need killer sounds from the computer. These 313's work fine, not the best, but for $39, I don't think they can be beat. I just sent back the Cyber Acoustics 3602's... didn't last 3 weeks before they developed an intermittent loud hum/buzz that was horrible. Didn't sound nearly as good as people rate them either.... very boxy/boomy. One reviewer after calling himself an audiophile, said the 3602's blew him away. I won't even comment on that bit of ridiculousness...  If you're looking for decent sound in a non complicated, inexpensive package, the 313's are the best pick. When coupled with a decent track with some bass, they actually sound great.... pick a track with no bass, and they sound weak. Oh well, nothing's perfect...

I don't plan on using all the filters but it was nice to have all the different options. Most of them are very high quality but 2 of the graded panels aren't perfect; luckily they aren't the ones I plan on using though.

I am not new to Samsung's quality and products. I was looking for a surround sound system that would integrate a 3d blu-ray player, smart app interface, and have wireless rear speakers. I just purchased a television a little over a year ago and unfortunately it does not have smart application ability. This system does everything. It plays blu-ray and 3-d, has plenty of apps, and the sound quality is beautiful. You will have to spend sometime tweeking the sound level and other settings to get the best sound, but once you do it is great!

I had one of these that I purchased from Fry's Electronics (Los Angeles) years ago.  It was great, but finally died a couple of weeks ago.  I was happy to find a replacement on Amazon and ordered.  It worked fine for a couple of days, but then started acting flaky--hanging up, restarting, etc.  Then it finally just died.  Windows reports: A USB device connected to this computer has malfunctioned.  Tried it on another computer with same results.I'm going to re-order and try one more time...  I guess there's a slight chance that my notebook computer is doing something to destroy them...although that seems pretty far-fetched to me.  If the new one works for an acceptable period of time--at least through the warranty/return window, I'll update this review.I like the mouse--it's just the right size for a portable computer.EDIT: Jan 28, 2012.  I did purchase another one of these and it works fine.  Guess the first one was a lemon.  I like the small form factor and the retractable cord--just ideal for a traveling laptop.
summary: Stopped working on 4th or 5th use--2nd one works fine

reviewText: This is my 2nd Harmony remote, used for an additional setup. This is even easier to setup & use than my older one. Of course it takes some tweaking to get all the settings just right. The range of supported devices is abysmal, chances are you can control almost anything with large of customization possible. My wilfe loves it and we do recomend this to all.

I've had my Garmin 1450 now for about a week, and I got a great deal on it ($299). I was drawn to this GPS when I saw how easy it was to use for someone like me who has never had a GPS before purchasing this one. I played around with it on the store's display. The large screen can be easily viewed while driving without struggling to view it.I love the touch screen feature, and the easy on/off button. It does effectively inform me of which lane I should be in; however, I do not see any road signs pictured on my GPS like the one pictured here. I see small arrows on the top left that display the correct lane to get in. I love that it also displays the time at which I should arrive at my destination.It does not have bluetooth capability, and it does not come with live traffic updates (you will have to purchase it separately). I do wish there was a feature that would allow me to return to the main screen without continuously having to press the back button to get back to the home screen.I haven't gotten lost using this GPS, and I was told today when I showed up for an appointment that they were impressed that I found their business location, since even people from their city tend to get lost and can not find the address- I am impressed. In my current city, the GPS will map it's way in a totally different location than is the most sensible option. Mapquest, and Google maps would not even use some of the routes. Perhaps it is because, I have it set on the fastest route. The GPS will easily re-route the trip if you miss a turn, or decide to go another direction. I am able to save 10 addresses to my favorites, which is helpful, but I want to save more than 10.The points of Interest tab is great. I can find locations quickly for food, gas, coffee, medical attention, shopping, etc.

As a DJ, there's a discrete quantity of douchebaggery required to put on an optimal performance.  I feel that these headphones keep me calibrated from going over the line, too far towards the douchy side of things, as virtually anyone wearing Beats headphonds has gone.Amazing sound quality.  I enjoy the stereo/mono switch.  Comfortable.  Don't sit on them; they'll break.
I don't think it really needed the mesh overcoat on the cable but it does slide, coil and work just great.

I'm hard on headphones and tend to get through them pretty quick. I bought these for running - I sweat a lot, and find that regular headphones breakdown and die on me, so I need water resistant or water proof headsets if I want to get any life out of them. I figured that headphones designed for swimmers would do the job, right?I have problems with these though.The ear peaces - it comes with 5 different sizes, thats awesome, except that the L size fits my left ear with no problem at all, the L on my right ear lets in sweat, which blocks the noise, and I end up with only one ear piece working. The XL size is too big and uncomfortable to wear for long periods of time. H2O do sell a pack with 9 different tip styles, but I'm not paying additional money, for just shy of a dozen new ear bud tips, when I only need it to fit one ear.Secondly, the cable. It runs straight down your back, and is coiled. At 6' tall, this means I can't put my iphone anywhere but in a SPIBelt pouch, right at the center of my back. I usually wear it at the front, where I can mess with the controls mid run, but not when I'm using these. The cable is almost too short, and does have tension in it, even when I wear the iPhone at the back. This means these headphones can *only* be used with the iPhone in this position, and I can't wear them at the gym, or walking my dogs or really for any other purpose than running.When these die, I won't be replacin them with the same model.
summary: Not as good as I hoped for

reviewText: These speakers are outstanding, in both performance and looks. Not sure why they're somewhat ignored by the "audiophile" world, must be the reasonable price. I compared the 555's directly against the current Infinity Primus 3-way tower model. The Infinity's are excellent. But, the Yamaha's seem so much more "musical" with greater detail, focus and depth. Get a pair of these along with a good subwoofer and you won't go wrong! You owe it to your ears!Short term follow up for anyone interested. Had them for a little over 3 months now and they do indeed "get better with age." The soundstage has "widened" but still retains mid/treble focus and the bass has smoothed out nicely. Turned the subwoofer way down. Not sure what's up-breaking in maybe?-but they're sounding better and better.
I use this 1/4" tape on all types of surfaces. It is easy to read and sticks well. Makes orginizing easy.

I bought this for the back of my 6870 such that i could run three monitors off one graphics card, it is too close to the card and so gets int the way of the HDMI.  Having it this large and so close made it useless to me.

I purchased this so that I could print wirelessly from my laptop to my HP3310 All-In-One printer/copier/fax/scanner.  It works well, but with one issue: I have to remove the adapter from the HP 3310 when booting up my computer, as it will stop the PC from booting all the way up with the adapter plugged in.  I don't know if this is a limitation of the adapter or the HP 3310.  Otherwise, it works well.Update: the booting issue turned out to be caused by outdated BIOS on my computer (not the fault of this adapter)

Unless you're looking for a lot of bells and whistles in a keyboard, this is the simplest, affordable, and durable keyboard I have found.What like the best about this keyboard is the way its keys are designed - its keys are similar to the keyboard from Apple.  The keyboard feels very natural to type and very ergonomic.If you're looking for a quality keyboard on a budget, this is it.

UPDATE *****Since writing my last review I was contacted by the company and offered a replacement for the damaged cables.The customer service was excellent and the replacements arrived very swiftly.I can say that the cables are all working beautifully and now they are all Apple approved. They bear the 'made for iPhone, iPad etc....' stamp now.I have been very impressed by the customer service and will definitely be purchasing from them again.OLD REVIEW -The length of these cables is excellent.Unfortunately, with very basic use, 2 of the cables have stopped working.I was hoping that they would last a lot longer as they have been so handy, but I don't like the idea of having to constantly replace them when they fail. 50% fail rate in a couple of months is not great.The other two are still going strong for now, and I hope that they continue for a while longer.
summary: Great length. Customer service is excellent.

reviewText: The screen protector is doing it's job so far. I have been using it for about 2 weeks. It has a natural feel to it and doesn't feel "sticky" when I am navigating the phone. Overall, it's a good protector.

[UPDATE 07nov2013]. Got it back from service again. This time the doc actually said they did replace the shutter.  I set out to test it--shooting over 500 shots in and hour on the Ch setting and then going to the park and shooting a f22 all day. Only 1 spot is on the sensor and that one seems to have been there since it was returned. But no additional spots so far.[UPDATE 16Oct2013] After a month of using the D600 _after_ Nikon Service updated the Shutter for me, I am seeing a few more spots on the sensor. I haven't shot a lot of photos -- maybe in the 200 - 300 range, however, there are now a handful of substantial spots on the sensor once again--even with the fix. So if they truly did replace the shutter with that used in the D610, I'm not optimistic about the D610 nor am I'm relaxed about owning the D600.[UPDATE 16Sept2013] I just received my D600 back from Nikon Service. During the NAB in Las Vegas earlier this year, a Nikon Rep told me that they had a "quiet" service practice for D600. She said "Send it in". I didn't bother doing that until early September of this year and got it back 10 days later. They paperwork said "clean sensor, upgrade firmware" so I was concerned. I called and the Service Tech said, yes there's more to it than that, but he wasn't allowed to say--but he did say "They fixed the problem".  After a lengthy test shoot of the Sky, timelapse of nature and several "party" shots, I see Zero Dust/Grease whatever on the pictures. I believe this camera is now fixed. Thank you Nikon and of course Amazon for the best Customer Service ever![UPDATE 29Nov2012] The 4th unit is now going back to Amazon. This D600 was oil-free and I was very happy for the first 100 or so images. Then excessive dust started to appear. I "let it go" for about a week and it seems to have settled down. I called Nikon who told me I could not clean the sensor myself--it had to be sent to a Nikon Authorized service center. But my experience with Nikon service while good, is also VERY time consuming. So this unit is now on its way back to Amazon and another one has been ordered. Let's hope we get both no oil and little to no dust on this one. (Fingers crossed)[UPDATE 21Nov2012]I'm on the 4th D600 from Amazon.com (gotta love their fantastic customer service).The other 3 units had Oil spots either right after shooting or came with oil already on the sensor.This unit seemed okay for the first 40 or so images, and then I saw some particles of dust (not oil) on the sensor. I blew it away and shot another "roll" and saw even more dust and what I believe to be 1 or possibly 2 tiny oil spots (the prior units had larger oil spots).Regardless of how good the image quality is, if you can't depend on the product to product pictures vs dusty images (or oily images) it isn't worth your time.My pure speculation is that some units have oil and some have excessive dust. Oil being caused by Nikon assembly workers over-oiling a poorly designed shutter mechanism, and dust if they did not over oil the shutter mechanism. So you get one bad feature or the other.The other camera I have is a D800e and it now has 1 oil spot after roughly 1000 images. I may send it in to be cleaned, assuming no more appear. But this being the 4th D600 I'm going to conclude, based on what I've read here and from my own experience, that this model is definitely NOT ready for prime-time.I would suggest you put off your purchase until either they replace this module with a new one (one that has the problems resolved) or you invest in a cleaning kit and become what most consumers are not, a camera cleaning expert.Oh, and those who keep saying "are you sure its oil and not dust" please move along until you actually own one of these models, you're boring the rest of us who are actually trying to make this camera with great potential, work.[Original Review]This camera produces some of the best pictures of any Nikon yet. Sure the D800/e has more pixels, but a 50% increase in those pixels makes your computer run slow as it reads/processes them. Plus, the camera itself slows down as it processes 36 megapixels (again on the D800). This camera has just the right mix of features.So unless you're a pro, this should be your camera if you're a Nikon shooter (or get he new CANON 5D Mk III if you prefer CANON, both are great).This is a full-frame camera, not a Pro Camera. It has all the scene modes you've used from the D7000 but gives you that great depth of field results you normally only see in an FX (full frame) model.Likewise you can use Program/Pro mode, or Aperture or Shutter Priority modes and pull fantastic shots.The Good: FX sensor, 24 megapixels is good enough, more would be a negative feature, fits all your Nikon lens, but start buying FX (non-DX) lenses if you haven't already; it has a fast enough shutter speed and great colors.The not so good: The focus sensors have been purposely crippled on this camera. Instead of using an FX autofocus array from the D4, D800 or other cameras, they use the same autofocus array used on the  D7000 DX camera. This cheat means that you basically have a small area in the center of the view finder in which focus occurs. While this is really offensive to me as a consumer, (shame on you Nikon) it isn't a show-stopper. It too borders on "good enough" but I do find it irritating in some situations. So while focus is perhaps the biggest shortcoming feature, it shouldn't stop you from selecting this over other models.Last, like all 2012 Nikon cameras, this model too tends to overexpose its photos when not using matrix metering (e.g., spot metering). So I tend to have to shoot at -0.3ev all the time. The more I use the matrix metering however, I'm learning to know when the camera will work with it vs spot metering. The over exposure that can occur in spot metering (I'm speculating) was done to accommodate those "ultra stupid hi ISO" features. If you want to shoot in the dark, get a camera with night vision.So unless you're a professional, get the D600, you'll love it. If you're a pro... keep your D3 or get the D4 or for B-roll consider the D800.OIL SPOTS:One caveat: The original D600 I received was wonderful until I hit about 100 photos. Then a bunch of oil spots on the "sensor" (actually on the anti-alias filter) started to appear. Apparently if the person or machine on the assembly line didn't have their coffee, they might have over-oiled the shutter release on your camera. Now, it is easy to clean off dust particles, but oil is problematic. If you look around, you'll see two types of users writing about this issue: Those who received a good unit that doesn't show the problem and who falsely conclude that is never happens, and those who are having the issue. To see if yours has the issue, shoot a photo of the blue sky, and look at it on your computer. If you see little grey or slightly dark orbs, you have the problem. I originally had zero, then about 5, then it went to over 20 spots. One or two is nothing--it won't show up on your prints or elsewhere. But one or two dozen, that's a problemThe great thing about getting your cameras from Amazon.com is you can return/exchange it for another unit. And that's what I did.
summary: Best Nikon Yet but wimpy focus area

reviewText: This arrived in a large box w/3 other items I had ordered one day.  It arrived in perfect condition .  This is a gift for my daughter to keep her new region free dvd player in.
Needed this one to replace my old one that died on me to weeks ago. I put in today and everything works.

I picked up this hard drive for Black Friday sales last year. I was a little bit weary at the beginning after reading the horror stories experienced by other users (not HP users, I refer to users of External Hard Drives in general), so I started to just copy stuff that I had already burned into data DVD's. A year later, I must say I am truly impressed with this drive! It is absolutely silent, does not heat up too much, you can set up the back-up software to run in the background while you save or use data from the drive. The back up recognize the structure tree of your back-up and keeps adding all new/modified documents without altering your structure. I am a heavy computer/data user and this drive has never faltered, not even once. At Black Friday sales this year I picked up aSeagate Freeagent 1.5 Tb Usb 2.0 External Hard Drivebut that one is still unopened, as I still have over 400GB left over on the Simple Save and I will use the other one to back up my music/video collection currently burned into DVD's.
Used this to transfer my photos to my net book from the camera cards...and the net book has no card reader.Worked perfectly with no problems.Can't ask for more.

I bought this and have been using it for about 3 weeks for a TV I wanted to put on a wall on the opposite side of the cable outlet to which I have my RCN Tivo DVR attached. I was a little worried because as soon as I bought it I got an email from the manufacturer's saying they've received reports of this product overheating, and that these are not intended to remain continuously on. I found this annoying as I do not want turning on the television to be a confusing process.The 1080 signal looks great, and it was literally plug and play. I bought quiet desk-lap fans to keep under both transmitter and receiver and have kept them continually running slowly such that they are very quiet. I don't really turn off the transmitter or receiver unless I know no one will be watching TV for some time, and it has worked fantastically. Whenever I've touched the transmitter / receiver, they've never felt hot at all.  So far so good, the fans give me some peace of mind and I'd recommend some kind of fan. Also, as far as I've noticed, no interference with either my wireless surround sound or my wifi, both of which are just nearby.

This mouse exceeded my expectations for the price.  It is extremely lightweight, almost lighter than a disposable pen.  It is very slim which is great for my wrist, because it keeps my hand almost flat and parallel with the desk.  The buttons do produce an audible click...which I don't mind, and actually prefer.  The scroll wheel runs smoothly, and the optical light does illuminate the entire mouse up red when you move it.  I personally like this feature and think that it looks pretty cool!  It installed itself in about 30 seconds on a white HP Pavilion Entertainment PC running Windows 7, and is easily recognized by my usb ports.  For the price and the style, this mouse is absolutely AWESOME and I would definitely buy one as a gift or get myself another one!
Living/working abroad I need an adapter for the large part of the year that I am out of the US.

Purchased a pair of these to replace the rear speakers of my '05 Acura TL (A perfect fit). Although the TL has a 5.1 Dvd-Audio system, the rear speakers were 'full-range' speakers and sounded flat/ muffled. Replacing the stock speakers with the Infinity Reference speakers produced a clean and precise sound. These speakers sound incredible. Even the shop installer was commenting on how clean they sounded even though they are being powered with the factory amp.I highly recommend these speakers for your vehicle application.However, don't expect a giant amount of deep,low bass from them, (that is what a Subwoofer is for) however you will get tight mid-bass.My only problem that I have is deciding whether I should purchase another pair for the front of the car also. :/ For $50, I cant go wrong.CP

Definitely waterproof as stated just haven't tested to advertised depths. Tested in water parks and during heavy rainstorms. I didn't have a doubt protecting my phone. Sound is muffled but everyone could hear me fine on their end. Don't use the phone speaker as the sound waves bounce around creating an echo for folks during a call. Definitely survived a drop from hip height, no problems and didn't add much bulk to the phone either!

It's turquoise, but I love it anyway - in fact, I bought it because it actually appears as turquoise in the pictures not dark green. I like that it's sturdy and hard shelled - a perfect case for my earbuds to carry around in my man bag.
summary: Not Deep Green by Any Stretch of Imagination

reviewText: I bought this laptop for my mom and it's more than able to do what she wanted it for. It has poor viewing angles. If you aren't looking straight in line with this laptop viewing is next to impossible hence the 3 stars. If you are a first timer into computers this should be adequate. seasoned computer or laptop users should look else where.
summary: Does what I bought it for!

reviewText: It fits everything, is the right length, came on time and in great shape.  Plus I got a message from BlueRigger asking for a review but also offering service for any questions, problems, etc.  That's always encouraging.
summary: I haven't used this yet, but I'm looking forward to it.

reviewText: It's smart and switches automatically, or you can overide.  Video quality is great.  Very small so it doesn't take up much room. And it has 3 ports.  Price is great for this excellent product.

I've owned this headphone for over three years now. No problems at all. I listen to music with it practically every day. The sound these things produce still impress me even to this day. I'm not kidding. The surround sound is truly amazing. I often prefer wearing this instead of using my 5.1 surround speakers.The bass, treble is just a perfect balance. Nothing is overpowering like you would get from cheap headphones. Listening to music really is a pleasure. It's like literally being at a recording studio or live concert.  I forget I'm even wearing headphones with these. When watching movies, I really feel like I'm actually in a theater. Actually, it sounds better than the theaters. This headphone makes me listen to some music I normally wouldn't care so much for, on a regular headphone that lacks depth. It really makes you appreciate the beauty of sound. You can clearly hear the vocals, the instruments, and effects, clearly as separate channels instead of everything muffled together. Truly surround sound. Depending on the music or movie, one can get detailed sounds from all angles one normally wouldn't notice on a regular speaker or headphone.The cushion muffs is large and comfortable. It can often attract dust, so you'll want to use those sticky rollers when that happens. There's also a leather cushion on the top of the headphone; a lot thicker than the lower Sennheiser models. There's only one plug that connects to the headphones, so it's nice you don't get cords dangling on both sides when listening.The only con would be that sound leaks a lot, since these are open headphones. In other words, people can really hear what you're listening to. Then again, open headphones are preferable if you want a natural sound. I felt crazy spending $300 on a headphone, but I have no regrets. It really is like having a portable surround system.Highly recommended.
summary: Luxury headphones - A pleasure to listen with! Worth the money.

reviewText: you get what you pay for, its really really cheap but itserves the purpose. if the range would have been better its would be perfect

I've tried a small number of headsets for computers, looking for a decent quality recording. The trouble with most headsets is that once they tend to pick up all of the noise in the background, forcing a recorder to turn off their precious air conditioning and fans, and pray their computer is quiet enough to not be heard.Not with this baby. I was prepping for an amateur recording session with a friend and wanted to make sure I had everything in order. I ran a few tests: shaking my head back, forth, up, and down; jumping in place; pacing; running a standing fan (on three power levels); and running my in-window AC unit, which blows air right to my computer. After a few trials, I realized that NONE of these things were being picked up. I had to silence everything to verify, since I couldn't believe it. I recorded with the AC and fan off and then on, and the only noticeable change was when the AC unit beeped at me saying I had successfully powered it on. There was hardly even a hum on the recording track. I also have long hair, and headsets I've used in the past have picked up the noise made when my hair brushes against the headphones or boom mic; nary was a hair heard by this headset.One might think that with all of this awesome non-pickup that the recording quality of what IS picked up would be awful. Not the case. My voice came through clearly with all of my sibilance intact. The mic is good enough to pick up throat clearing and swallowing, however, so be careful when recording (or learn to post-process/edit this stuff out).The headset's earpieces are labeled with L and R for their designated sides, but if the wearer finds them uncomfortable, the boom mic rotates all the way back for a reversible wearer. That person should note that, of course, the sound made for the right channel will be heard by the left ear and vice versa. Not to say that these are uncomfortable, they're very nice; but lobe earrings might get squished between the ear padding and the jawbone and might cause discomfort. The USB cord is about 6' long, with a mute/vol+/vol-/call button on a plastic block about 2' from the headset; the cord enters the headset on the 'left' earpiece (So, technically, the main pic on Amazon's product page is of the headset backwards). The headband is adjustable for various head sizes, even for those of us with oddly-shaped heads. They aren't the daintiest of headsets, so someone looking to keep up with the latest fashion trends might want to keep away. If they are too bulky, one can rest the headset around their neck and use the boom mic to record, while using their computer's speakers to listen.No software was required to set up or calibrate the headset; but the user might want to download Skype for chatting or Audacity for recording, both free.Of note is that this headset is compatible with the iPad via the Camera Connection Kit, making it useful for Skype or recording on there as well (though portability might be an issue).In short, this is a great quality headset for those in noisy rooms who don't want to sacrifice quality, or a chunk of cash.
Very pretty but hard to put it on and take it off not going to buy anther one I was going to but not anymore

reviewText: Given the price I wasn't expecting a lot from this kit and that's what I got. It's your typical mass-manufactured, cheap plastic, almost disposable gear.The softboxes are usable though I don't expect them to last long.The heads themselves aren't the greatest. The sockets are cheap and hard to get the bulbs into. They feel like they will break very easily under the slightest of pressure. Of the two heads, on had a broken fuse cover out of the box. The nut that holds the thumbscrew in the stand attachment on the other pulled out of the plastic on the first use and isn't really fixable. Have a roll of gaffer tape handy.The stands are decent. They are somewhat spring loaded which is nice.  One of the two had a stripped locking knob on the bottom legs that I had cobble a replacement for.All in all the light output is decent. This will get you by on the cheap in a pinch but don't expect much longevity. And given the quality I would NOT call this a portable rig. Tearing it down and putting it back together even a few times will wear this out in a hurry.
summary: About what you'd expect for the price.

reviewText: If you are looking for a thin case with auto wake magnets for your iPad Mini, look no further!  This case fits perfectly, is very light weight, and has auto wake magnets in it to turn your iPad off and on.The cover folds back into a triangle which supports the mini in an upright position to watch video or to work on.  This cover ONLY holds the iPad in the horizontal position  (long side) so if you want one that will hold it in the other position, this is not the cover you want.The only issue I had with this is that the cover is a bit stiff and does not fold into the support triangle easily at first.  However, after three times of doing it, it folds quite easily now.Since I use the mini iPad mostly for reading, this cover works perfectly for me.  It also works well for viewing video.  I would highly recommend it if you want a very thin cover that will protect your iPad mini and that provides great features.
summary: Poetic SLIMELINE case for Apple iPad Mini

reviewText: I scoured all the reviews trying to find a case that gave a simple, professional look, without losing any functionality for my Asus Transformer. The fit is perfect. I had some concern based on reviewers about the clasp that holds it closed, but it has opened and closed easily, yet holds the case securely. As I said, perfect fit.  This case protects (ie covers) all 4 corners, the entire front side, and the back with exception of the camera. There is about 1/8" x 1/2" open around the camera, allowing normal use of the camera without blocking any light. All of the ports are usable. One of my biggies is that it is able to be docked in the keyboard dock while still in the case. Also, some cases' pictures show the tablet upside down when using the case as a stand. That will work for some applications, and not others...presumably whether it was designed for a tablet or not. This case has the tablet right side up when using the case as a stand. It has 3 positions that cover a good usable range of angles. I highly recommend this case.
summary: 100% functional with case on; simple, professional style

If you are serious about tracking your pace, distance and other goodies that goes along with running then look no further than this GPS watch.  I've compared, researched, and read through pretty much everything there is to know about current GPS watches out there.  At the end, Garmin FR220 won me over for a few simple facts.  The user interface is excellent.  It took me a few minutes to figure out just about all the features of the watch out of the box.  The batter time, from what I can tell, is excellent.  Charges quick, and the watch functions as it is designed and supposed to be.  Vibration alert is awesome and customization of alert mode is great as well.  Sat signal gets picked up quick too.  Did I mention, it looks great as a sport watch also?Pros:Great user interface and button locationsquick satellite pickupgood battery lifelightweight and comfortable weargreat designcons:limited color selectionall plastic constructionI ended up picking this one up at Fit 2 Run store.  They offered club discount at $225 and with their club membership the price of the watch came about the same without the discount.  I would've bought it on Amazon if the price was much better, but FR220 goes for retail price of $249.99 without the HR monitor strap online and at the store.Garmin "IS" GPS company.  If so,  it should be no brainer to those of you who are looking for a reliable GPS watch.  FR 220 is no exception in that.  Garmin did a fantastic job of executing engineering, design, and usability into the watch.  I love it!I am finally going to do away with trying to start/pause/end workout while my hands are sweaty running using my iPod and Nike+ foot pod thing.  I can finally concentrate on running!  Highly recommend this GPS watch to anyone looking for a solid GPS running partner!  Yes,  so much better than Forerunner 10, 15 or even 620.  For 99% of runners will not use more than half the features on this GPS watch.  GET IT!
summary: Perfect Partner for a serious runners!

The Cinavia software will recognize that your dvd isn't store-bought, and disable the audio on that dvd. Cannot recommend this player to anyone based on this fact alone. Unless you want to keep a separate 30 dollar "dumb-player" to view all of your older non-bluray discs. But this can get frustrating. reviewText: As an apartment dweller, I am a huge fan of quality headphones. At this point, I own twelve pairs (I know - I have a problem) encompassing a wide range of styles from the inexpensive AKG 240s to the high end Beyerdynamic DT 880s. Impressively, the Brainwavz R3s compare quite favorably to some headphones that cost much more.Since these are canalphones, I’ll base my primary comparison on a similar pair that I own by Etymotic Research - the ER4Ss.The Etymotics are more than twice as expensive as the R3s and they do have an edge in terms of absolute sound quality. They have a higher impedance, which is a blessing and a curse. The ER4Ss have a greater dynamic range, but they also require more voltage to drive. This means that they sound flat and lifeless unless you’re using a headphone amplifier, which isn’t terribly convenient. In contradistinction, the R3s have a lower impedance, which makes them much more satisfying when using a low voltage device like a laptop, iPod, or smartphone. You’ll get an additional layer of sonic detail and dynamic shading with the more expensive ER4Ss, but the inconvenience is a significant factor.Beyond sound quality, there are a few things that the R3s do much better. The Etymotics use a tiny threaded cable that provides virtually no protection from vibration, which means that if you move the cables, you’ll hear a lot of microphonics. This is a problem inherent in all canalphones, but the R3s use a thicker, rubberized cable, which dampens some of the microphonic vibrations. This makes a big difference, especially if you’re not planning on sitting quietly every time you want to listen to music.The bottom line is that the R3s sound very good and they are much more practical than the ER4Ss. You can get a nice, full sound from a portable device, and you can wear them without noticing as many microphonic disturbances.The R3s have a few other nice features that make them worth checking out. They come with a huge variety of ear tips in all shapes and sizes. When using canalphones, it’s absolutely crucial that you get a good seal, otherwise you’ll lose any sort of bass presence. With all the varieties Brainwavz includes, you’re sure to find something that works for your ears.The R3s also come with a nice carrying case that is rigid enough to provide protection if you want to toss it into a backpack or something. The Etymotics also come with a little case, but it’s soft and doesn’t do much to protect what’s inside. As an added bonus, Brainwavz also throws in an airplane adaptor, which is not something I’ve seen from any other headphone company. All in all, they really give you a nice array of accessories.Now, a few words about the sound of the R3s. The sonic signature seems very well balanced. There is plenty of bass, but it’s not overpowering. The highs are smooth, and the always important midrange feels relaxed and natural. Where the Etymotics sound more precise and analytical, the R3s sound punchy and forward. Because they have more bass presence than the Etymotics, the R3s are better suited for certain musical styles like rock, electronic, and the like. They do a good job with more acoustic styles like jazz, classical, and mellow singer-songwriter stuff, but they’re best at louder, more electronically grounded styles. That said, I was pleased with the performance of the R3s with virtually every recording I tested them with.Since most people will be using the R3s with some sort of low voltage, portable device, that’s primarily how I tested these; however, I also listened through my high-end headphone amplifier just to see how they performed under the best possible conditions. I didn’t actually notice a huge difference in sound quality. There was a bit more detail and the dynamic range improved somewhat, but really, these sound just about as good coming straight out of an iPhone.Overall, the R3s are a great value. The sound is very good, the accessories are useful, and the price is great. I highly recommend them!

The Motorola DECT 6.0 phone system works well and my husband and I are quite pleased with it.  The reason that I did not give this item 5 stars is that it was very difficult to set up and figure out how to make the base phone, the handsets and the answering machine work.  My huband works in cyber-security and has some pretty extensive experience in setting up telecommunications and this phone system really stumped him.  He finally was able to get the system up and running, but it was very frustrating because the instruction manual that came with the phone was no help at all.  It took us 3 days and lots of trial and error, to get the phone system to work.  Although we are very pleased with the base phone, the handsets and the answering system, we would recommend that Motorola rewrite the instructions so that they make sense and are easy to understand.  I would definitely recommend this phone system, especially to anyone who needs 3 handsets, but I would add a word of caution, that setting up the Motorola DECT 6.0 system can be a lengthy, frustrating procedure.
summary: Good phone system, but lousy instruction manual

reviewText: If after reading the pros & cons below, you still feel you would benefit by having a laptop type keyboard, the Belkin is a good offering. However, I found it more limiting than enhancing.Pros* Springy responsive keyboard - Has the same feel and click sound as Apple laptops* Easy to insert tablet including the iPad Mini & doesn't obscure the screen* Offers good protection for the tablet screen* Cover flap is magnetized for secure closure* Great color/quality materialsCons* Instructions included in packaging are basically non existent - must go to the website* Instructions on the website are inconsistent & incomplete* Model compatibility list does NOT list the iPad Mini; but then does provide Bluetooth pairing instructions for the iPad Mini under "Tutorials & Troubleshooting"* The pair button screen shot shown on the website shows the wrong button - it's the corner key in the upper right corner & it doesn't tell you that you must simultaneously hold down the blue function (fn) key to pair correctly* There's NO track pad* Must still use the touch screen in order to select apps, and navigate efficiently* NO way to do "Spell Check" properly through the keyboard* Defeats the ease of using the automatic virtual keyboard that comes up for textboxes such as logins & addresses* The cover is NOT a smart cover* The cover has only one viewing position other than flat, which is almost at a 90 degree angle to the keyboardTips* Place iPad Mini into the cover so the bottom `Home' button is to the right. That way the `On/Off' switch & Headphone connection are accessible. The left hand corner straps/fasteners are designed differently than the right hand side straps/fasteners for this purpose* Charge the keyboard before trying to set it up

reviewText: I ordered this TV on a Monday and it was delivered the next Monday from PA to NJ.  It was delivered by Eagle who were OK...the guy baulked when I asked him to help me move the original 32" CRT that was there, I thought this was white glove delivery...? They put it on the stand for me but did not wait until it was switched on before leaving so I guess that was OK, if I had paid for the white glove delivery I would have been annoyed ($250?) but as it was free I guess it was OK.BTW when I bought the TV white glove delivery was not an option, it came with free standard shipping, which was going to be a problem as I live in a 1st floor apartment and this TV is 120lbs.  But after speaking to Amazon they said that any TV over 27" gets white glove for free!!So to the TV, it came in perfect condition and well packed, the eagle guys took away the packaging as I asked them to.  I switched on the TV and connected it to Cablevision HD via a HDMI cable running through my Onyko AV amp.The picture is excellen in HD and pretty good in SD.  HD from close up is pretty perfect with no ghosting or anything like that.  SD from close up i.e. 5 " away shows the lack of bandwidth on the feed.  But from 6' or more its fine to watch.I was a bit worried about IR with this TV as its a plasma but the only time I ever saw a but of it was when I ran the auto setup for my Onyko 605 which basically puts a very vivid DOS type screen up for around 15 minutes, I saw the lines for the boxes for about 1 miniute after I changed channel but they quickly disappeared.I put this down to being one of the first images I ran on the new TV as I have since run setup several times after around 50 hours of use with no IR.I also have run through my 360 and HDDVD through this TV, its excellent with these.  Great colors and pin sharp picture, no lag at all and no IR with games after hours of play!This TV is great value, I paid $2300 no tax delivered and there is nothing out there to touch it at this orany price under $3000...believe me I looked for over 18months.Buy it and enjoy it!
summary: fantastic Picture, Fantastic quality, fantastic price!!

reviewText: I had a hard time choosing a video card for my new PC and ended up using this one for a couple of reason.  Fist, I read a number of great things about EVGA cards.  I was unable to convince myself to spend the $450+ on the GTX 580, and the color scheme of the 570 series matched the components of my build.I was a little confused on the difference between the GTX 570 Superclock and the GTX 570 Superclock HD, so I decided to call EVGA and ask them.  Ends up that although the HD has an additional port type, and a full size HDMI port (instead of the HDMI mini) it used less precious metal on its board and there for was $20 cheaper.  This didn't make too much sense to me, but if that is what the sales rep was going to tell me, I believed him and went with the cheaper card with more display port options.I was a little concerned about the airflow in this model compared to the normal superclock, as it looked like it had a different fan and smaller exhaust.  To be fair, I have done some modifications to my NZXT Gamma case so the air flow might not be optimal  When running Battlefield 3 on Ultra settings on a 25" 1080p Monitor I took the card to full ram capacity and around 80 to 90 Celsius. Since then I have added a few new fans and attempted to improve the airflow.  I'm still seeing high temps when playing playing battlefield 3 on ultra settings, but I'm playing battlefield 3 on ultra settings... and getting 60 frames... is there more I could ask for?For the price of this card, it's hard to go wrong. It's not the top top of the line, but it's a close second or third.
summary: Great Video Card for the Money

I have five devices constantly connected to this hub - a wireless mouse/keyboard adapter, a Bluetooth adapter, a webcam, a smart card reader and a secondary smart phone which I don't use often. And with 10 ports total, there are still enough space for removable storage devices and other USB gadgets.Pro:USB 3.0 support, fast when working with USB 3.0 external storage devices.Externally powered, makes it stable. My previous USB 2.0 hub doesn't have external power supply and sometimes things disconnect or malfunction because of inadequate power to feed all devices.LED lights indicate port status.It is not ugly on the desk.Con:Sometimes the devices connected to this hub gets a bit too hot than usual (connected directly to the USB 3.0 port exposed by the MB). Not sure if this is because of the external power supply. But so far (a few weeks) none of my constantly connected devices is having problems because of this.

Recording quality is high and setup is straight forward.  Would be better with HDMI In/Out but I suspect that is more difficult due to HDCP issues.If you like to record yourself playing games, this is a good option.  Make sure you run it in "Real-Time" mode (blue light on) to minimize audio lag.

I had two APC UPS (450 and 550) which would not work correctly when running on GENERATOR power for the house.The generator I used was a SPORTSMAN 6000 Watt Continuous/7000 Watt Peak PROPANE Generator. The generatorwe use for back power when the commercial power fails. The generator has a hookup we plug into outside and thenwe throw a 200AMP manual transfer switch located inside the garage to transfer from commercial to generator power.Everything worked great except for our two APC UPS (450VA and 550VA) would not work correctly on generator power. They wouldcontantly switch back and forth to battery power and would eventually become exhausted and shut off. The 550VA APC UPSprovided power for a desktop computer. The 450VA APC UPS provided power for WiFi routers, switches and two internetrooftop antennas (WiFi and WiMax). I used one APC LE600 to feed power to the 550VA APC UPS providing power for the computerand the other APC LE600 to feed power to the 450VA APC UPS providing power for all the routers and antennas). PROBLEM SOLVED!!The UPS units no longer switch back and forth when on generator power. Whatever the UPS units did not like with the generator powerwhether voltage or noise was solved by putting the APC LE600 Voltage regulators BEFORE the UPS.I had actually sent APC a question about this but they never responded (Isn't tech. support for everything getting really bad now..)...I used one more APC Regulator (APC LE1200) to protect all of our TV/Satellite receiver/DVD/MiniStereo) when on generator power justto provide more clean power to those. Total investment was around $140. Money well spent to protect our electronic equipment and provideclean power the UPS units can get along with when on generator power. Recommended.
summary: Solved my UPS Problem when on GENERATOR

I've had my Garmin FR 305 for 6 years and still going strong.  So why did I see a need to go further?  It was prompted by my getting into interval training (run/walk, run/walk, etc.)  I could not hear the transition points with the somewhat muted tone of the 305.  So I figured there was some other way to get the transition message, maybe bluetooth.  I didn't even think about vibration.In my search, I happened upon this Garmin FR 310XT for around $200.  There was an even later release of the 910 for around $450, but that would be overkill for my purposes (I'm not into decathlon-type activities).My primary motivator for the purchase of the 310 was the ability to feel the vibration at the transition points.  Perfect.  I can be running and walking along, listening to my music through earphones, and know exactly when to do the next leg of the workout.OK.  That said, it was worth every bit the price just for the vibration.  But I discovered that almost everything about the 310XT was an improvement over the 305.  Where do I begin?  The chest strap for heart-rate monitoring is vastly improved from a comfort standpoint.  Setting values, such as setting the intervals, is so much easier than it was in the 305.  Many of the other improvements are covered by many other reviews, such as longer battery life and the ability to see remaining battery life (after two days of workouts, I was at 97% capacity remaining), quicker connection to satellites (never was a big deal with 305, but nice to get the connection quicker in order to get going), slightly smaller footprint without sacrificing the 4-readings per page capability, waterproof (not that I will swim with it, but comforting to know that getting stuck in the rain will not harm the watch), etc.  It retains all the great features that are present in the 305, so nothing is sacrificed.One more key point to make about the vibration.  Without vibration, for intervals I was needing to watch the screen count down as it got closer to the transition.  With the vibration, I can be viewing other screens if I want to see other indicators like avg speed, heart rate, etc., and the vibration will let me know it's time.  Or if you want, you can do the entire workout without ever having to look at the GPS watch.I have yet to try it when bicycling.  I know that I'm going to want to do interval training with the bicycle, which would have been difficult without the vibration.Net, net, a must have.
summary: Loved my Garmin FR 305; this one goes way beyond it

I bought this for my 2nd Generation MacBook Air.A few notes: It's very thin and therefore very easy to crack. While trying to gently remove one side of the case, the thing cracked and is now useless to me.The reason I was removing it? Because with both sides of the case on, it made a distinct (and annoying) clicking sound every time I opened the lid. The two pieces of plastic would rub against each other near the hinge. This case is very flimsy, but does work, and is serviceable.  I ordered Navy Blue which looks Very Black.  I should have gotten the Apple version, even though it costs much more, and doesn't get very good ratings either, but at least it's an Apple.You get what you pay for... or do you?

Before I get to the meat of this review, let me say something to Fellowes:  Your packaging is ridiculous. This thing really doesn't need a big cardboard box around it. Find a better way, guys!Okay, now on to the review:  I like it.Want more? Oh, alright...  The I-Spire Tablet Lift does exactly what it is advertised to do: It lets you mount/prop your tablet a little higher than just propping it directly on the tabletop, and it provides a sturdy support that won't leave you with a shattered screen. It handles portrait or landscape mode like a champ on my Galaxy Tab 2 10.1, and the space below gives me a little room to prop up my Bluetooth keyboard. Solid construction and smart planning means it won't slip, either.There are no moving parts. It's a solid piece of plastic-like material. It's relatively lightweight, but doesn't feel flimsy at all.With this tablet lift, a Bluetooth keyboard, and a Bluetooth mouse, you can turn an Android tablet into a nice little desktop computer. Alas, the iPad lacks mouse support so you'll need to tap the screen to make things happen. I'm pretty sure the I-Spire will be fine with exclusively touch-screen input, but just be aware that tapping means potentially pushing the tablet over the back of the I-Spire. The back support it relatively tall, but it might still give way if you're tapping at the top of your iPad screen in portrait mode.Obviously, this is meant to work without a thick case on your tablet. I cannot attest to its usability if you leave your specific case on your tablet. I use mine without a case on this tablet lift, and I am relatively confident that it will come to no harm while nestled in the groove.I really like this thing! It does exactly what I needed a tablet support to do. Five stars for a good idea well-executed.

The keyboard works great except for one thing: After 90 days the letters on the keys are fading. I have two keys without letters and expect to have a nude keyboard in another few months. What's up with that?

I ordered this HDMI cable so I could connect my iPad to my TV. So far it works well and I have had no issue. The image quality is good when using this HDMI cable. I would buy this cable again if needed.

The Marware EcoVue Genuine Leather Standing Case comes with a set of instructions for assembly, although they are hardly needed. All you need to do is just snap in your 7" Kindle Fire HD, that is it. The instructions also show you how to make the case stand your Kindle Fire at a desired angle. I also felt that this was not exactly a challenge to figure out.When you close the case, it puts the Kindle to sleep, thus saving battery life. I have no idea how the Kindle knows to shut off, clearly the case must be slightly magical. It is a bit awkward charging the device though, as it has to be kept open to charge, the charging side basically faces the spine of the cover. However, I didn't find this to be a huge deal as I can always just leave it open to charge overnight. It is really not that huge of an issue.What I particularly like about the case is that it looks very professional. It's leather. The strap does a fine job keeping the case closed. Plus, the case is not bulky at all. It does a nice job protecting my Kindle fire and looks good doing it. In all, a nice case that fits my personal aesthetic while performing a basic function.

First of all, I'm the kind of guy who likes to analyze my picture and sound(sometimes obsessively so) and sit as close as I can to my tv(Samsung 61" LED rear projection)so I may be a bit more geeky than the average blu-ray viewer...but hey, why not?  This unit replaced a Panasonic DMP-BD35k player I've had for almost 2 years.  I wanted something that would allow me to stream netflix and Pandora as well as improve(if possible) the sound and picture.  For an under $200 player, this unit addresses those things (that some $500 players don't) and I'm quite happy with my purchase.I find it very nice to see 24p available on DVD's as well as blu-ray discs.  The jitter reduction(for sound sent via HDMI) is a fantastic idea I haven't even seen mentioned in anyone else's literature with blu-ray players.  This new chroma processer seems to do a good job, detail is excellent with DVD's or blu-ray.Although the tube sound audio seems a bit gimmicky, I prefer it with it on.  It seems to give a subtle(but noticable...my girlfriend could tell) better soundstage with a fatter lower midrange and slightly rolled off highs(in other words tubelike sorta).  I'm not sure I'd go trading in that Conrad-Johnson preamp but it's a nice feature to experiment with.To my eyes and ears, this unit does a beter job than my old unit even if it's evolutionary not revolutionary. It does not play SACD or DVD-Audio discs.They moved the "display" button so it's now smaller in a more crowded area...and I use this alot(esp when switching from watching a blu-ray to a DVD to change the picture type soft, fine, cinema...).  So the remote is a bit smaller and not as well laid out(and it's still not backlit) but for the price, I find it hard to really complain.  It loads a bit faster than my old one but it's still not exactly speedy.  BTW, the quick-start feature means the unit is on all the time so you'll have to decide how green you want to be there.If your looking for a player that loads fast, there are better choices but for those that are picture and sound quality focused(obsessed?), this player is an excellent choice(unless your going to buy the Oppo at 3X the price).PS haven't used the streaming features yet although I did get it to recognize my router and that process was quite easy.Update(literally)...after making the wireless connection the unit did a firmware update that made a significant difference in picture quality with DVD's.  Initially, I noticed some moire patterns around objects during motion sequences.  Afterwords, the picture was free of these artifacts and with 24p engaged it was a definite improvement.Update...having spent time listening to the player in the different sound modes, the better the soundtrack the more I like any sound effect off.  Hi def  soundtracks are a little "dulled" by the tube sound setting.  Poorer soundtracks that sound harsh can be softened by the tube sound setting.
I like the size even though it is almost too small and it is of good quality.  Will buy from this co again

There have been some reviews questioning the quality of construction: I concur. The sound is awesome, when the cord at the connection to the plug is tweaked in the right direction; otherwise, no sound in the right ear. So, there's obviously an open (and probably very thin) wire connecting the plug to the right side. Not a big deal - but not what I paid for.Also - the sound reduction in the headphones with the standard earpiece (pictured) is pretty dang good. I fly a LOT - lots of time crossing the Atlantic, and they never make the inside of my ear sore like so many after a few hours. And they do deaden the ambient noise pretty well. I can hear the captain has come on to deliver his "blah blah blah," but can only hear what he is saying when I pull the  plugs out of my ears. So, no complaints - it's noise reduction, not active noise canceling, after all.

I had been researching so many different TV stands for myPanasonic VIERA TC-P50S30 50-Inch 1080p Plasma HDTVwhich is replacing my older Hitachi rear-projection TV.  Talk about a BIG change and a lot of room found!  I never realized how big that old TV was and how much space it was taking.  This stand, on the other hand, has great lines, is minimalist, and very attractive.  Unlike the zillion particle board stands out there, I did not want something that was going to fall apart  at the seams when moved and something I had to spend a lot of time putting together.  This Techcraft stand is constructed of a metal frame, wood veneer back and legs and smokey colored tempered glass shelves.  The wood is a cherry color and goes well with the black frame and smoked glass.  I love the look of this stand.  Very cool and minimalist.  Putting it together was easy.It fits components nicely.  My DVR, my Blu-Ray player, tinyRoku 2 XS 1080p Streaming Playerand my audio system.  My TV is a 50" and that's perfect.Pay attention to some of the other reviews when building this and remember that the glass pieces do not go in order - the simple algorithm is worth repeating:-- the largest piece of glass is for the top shelf,-- the smallest piece of glass goes in the middle,-- and the medium piece of glass is the bottom shelf.Wonderful price, great looking TV stand.  After researching plenty, I was happy to find this one at such a good price.  I recommend like another reviewer mentioned placing the frame in it's new location and THEN putting the glass in place.  This will ensure it is light as a feather to move around.5 stars and I would buy it again.
summary: Great stand, great price.  Sturdy.  Cherry colored wood.

reviewText: Reviews for this power supply seem to be at either one extreme of the spectrum or the other.  I've bought many Power Supplies and other parts before and I don't have brand loyalty, so my review should land in between all the other reviews.  I bought this because of the low price and I'm upgrading my office computer to do some gaming.  The power supply comes with all the connectors you could possibly need for your computer, although if you have a large case, you might want to look for a few extensions (4square in particular)  There is two fans(bottom and back) so it's noticeably louder than a single fan system.  But for $40 bucks it isn't a bad deal and it's what you expect it to be.Pros;-Abundance of connection types-Unbeatable watt to dollar ratio-Is as advertisedCons;-Very Loud-Too many connectors and cablesBottom Line;For the cheapskates, this is an alright buy.  If you want a quieter machine, look elsewhere.  I also purchased a Logisys 550W power supply in this same price range, and it's dramatically quieter.  I would rather buy that one again over this.Edit;After staying with it a few days, it still runs incredibly loud and will be sending it back for a refund.  That power supply is just too loud.

reviewerName: James B. Kirk "James Bond in the House"
reviewText: Stay far away from any Buffalo products, they don't offer any warranty.  I was in the mood to replace and ultra-reliableD-Link Systems ShareCenter SATA, RAID 0/1, JBOD, 1 TB 2-Bay Network Storage DNS-320-110and selected this one on based on the good reviews.  I ordered an open box unit, figuring that with 30 years of network experience, I could easily make it work.  I was wrong.  I was locked out of my unit (via the web interface) and there is no known was re-setting this unit to default, plus a plastic part rattled inside.So I figured I would call Buffalo Tech. support and they suggested the user forums for tech. support.  After 3 phone calls and their promise of sending me (via email) a reset file, I gave up on these bozos and their tech. support because they never did anything for me or the issue at hand. This unit is going back, and I am keeping my DNS-320-110 and upgrading both hard drives to 6TB.UPDATE:The unit has a continues red-light (the death knell) for this unit, before I could shut it down and send it back to Amazon.com, it died in less than 24 hours.
summary: Just plain buggy, no warranty from Buffalo

Won't keep my tablet fully charged when connected to the docking station. Switched back to the OEM cable, and what do you know? It's charging again.Definitely going to have to find a different cable.EDIT 10/1/2013: Nope, the cable is fine. I do believe I'll be purchasing another Nexus 7 OEM charger in the near future.
summary: Worked for awhile...can't understand how it went bad

I bought the Bamboo Capture about two months ago and so far I have had a pretty good experience with it. I'm using it with Windows 7 x64 right now and have to say that it works really similar to the macbook multi-touch trackpad. The texture isn't as quite as smooth, but it's not a bad texture either. The three finger and four finger gestures serve the same function in windows 7 as they do in Mac OS. However, there are some slight caveats:1. The scroll doesn't do inverse like the Macbook does2. For some reason, windows explorer doesn't work very well with the bamboo capture's scroll... I've turned off the flick gestures and everything I can think of... but for some reason as I drag down quickly at times, the screen goes crazy and it can't decide whether it wants to go up or down. The same thing often happens when I try to scroll up quickly as well.... I think it's a bug in the drivers, but after searching through Google for a while, it doesn't seem anybody else has brought up this issue, so I'm not sure if it's only happening on my computer.

This product has a good number of excellent reviews that give you a general idea of what is good about this lens... so I'll be brief.Reasons I love it:* Very quick to focus* Sharp* Useful in full body portraits to head-shots (on a 1.6x DSLR like a Rebel/450D)* Great low-light lens (I use it all the time in clubs)* Very light weight* Useful focus window (unlike the Rebel XSI/XS/T1i's kit 18-55mm IS lens)* "EF" (Useful on full frame, and "crop" frame sensor camera's... so I'll be keeping it as I upgrade)* Solid build quality (metal lens mount, light, but has a good "solid" heft to it)* About equivalent to a 50mm lens on a full frame sensor or 35mm format camera.* Good "carry around" lens (Light, unobtrusive, small, good focal length, very useful aperature)* Shallow depth of field at f/2, great for soft backgroundsThings that I noticed (which bring it down to "great" and not "amazing"):* My lens tends to over-expose images from what the meter says (add a little -EV and you're golden. On the plus side of this, you get a brighter picture in the dark than you were expecting)* Focus ring is very thin and "plastic-y" (works good though)* No manual over-ride when in AF mode (not that big a deal)* Colors are a little muted for my taste (bumping the saturation up, or post processing clears this right up)* f/2 is shallow... very shallow (good focus is a must at this aperture)* Background "Bokeh" reflects 5 sides of the aperture blades* AF is noisy (in comparison to HSM lenses)At it's price, I have no problem recommending it to anybody who's thinking about buying one. It's an EXCELLENT lens for the money, and much better build quality than the Canon 50mm f/1.8 "fantastic plastic" (as can be seen in the increase in cost, however). It produces better pictures, BY FAR, than the Canon EF-S 18-55mm IS f/3.5-5.6 at an equivalent 35mm length.Yes, you should just buy it and be pleased!
summary: My first dip into the "Prime" pool.

reviewText: While a very amateur, but nevertheless good, photographer I want ease of use, simplicity but quality photos.  I stopped using the pro series at the D2.  I loved the 40X but it's dated now but I still use one.  The D3200 is heavens answer to my photographing desires.  It has tons of features that accommodate different sophisticated needs.  For the average needs of a non pro like me it lets me access the few features I need most of the time fast and easy.  The pictures are great too.  The 24mp are nice although unnecessary,  just filling up the SD card fast.  As a slo mo video lover it gives me 60 fps though I'd prefer 120, but video is relatively easy to activate When in still mode.  It handles very well and has a good balance that is important at my level of photography and age (72).  I loooooove it

A refurbished E900 has got to be a -- if not the -- "best buy" in consumer routers.I bought it for 801.11n support, which my Linksys WRT54G didn't have. * Typical of Cisco/Linksys products, setup is easy and the user manuals are unusually clear and well-organized. This time around, I'd learned enough that I did it all by hand, and had no problems. (I recommend using Alt+PrtScn to copy the router's browser screens, then paste them into a file for a permanent record of the settings.)The E900's antennas are internal and can't be positioned. But they radiate above and below (when the router is sitting "flat"), so I hung the unit vertically on a wooden door near the ceiling, using "industrial strength" Velcro (#90199). Reception throughout my condo -- even near the floor -- is excellent. Reception in the parking lot is somewhat poorer than with the WRT54G, which is fine by me -- the E900 is less "visible".For those unfamiliar with advanced security, I strongly recommend using the Wireless MAC Filter feature to limit access to only your own devices. Combining MAC filtering with WPA2 encryption makes it //almost// impossible for anyone to break into your wireless connections.Note that, contrary to at least one other review, the E900 supports QoS settings.Unless you need the higher output or multi-band operation of a more-expensive model, the E900 is an easy, almost-automatic recommendation.* I repurposed the WRT54G for my AIBO, because the WEP encryption AIBO requires isn't considered strong enough for 801.11n. (If you choose WEP during setup, the router won't let you select auto channel width for 801.11n, and you're stuck at 20MHz.) All I have to do is swap routers to play with AIBO.
