reviewText: I purchased my iPad2 just about two months ago and it's a great toy.  While at the Apple store, I decided I also needed the leather Smart Cover.  At first I was impressed with the quality of the cover.  It smelled like really nice leather, and the smooth leather grain looked like it would age very well (giving a classic leather worn look eventually).  I also think the close/open to lock/unlock is a nifty trick.As others have pointed out though, there are same gaping flaws (I supposed Apple is not immune).  First, the cover is not useful at all as a stand.  Standing up, it is way too unstable, and at a low angle, it's pretty useless.  I tried it on the plane, and I just couldn't stand it up without it wobbling and falling over occasionally.Also, the cover leaves oily residue on the glass screen.  Now, this isn't a "huge flaw" just an annoyance.  I don't think this would cause any type of temporary or permanent damage.Lastly, the magnetic hinge is just not strong enough.  I understand the limitations of magnets and I think it's definitely a cool implementation.  However, they're just not strong enough to hold up to carrying with it unfurled, or reading it in bed trying to prop up the iPad on my stomach.  It's just frustrating since it falls off quite a bit.I'll keep it, since it looks nice (and that's what we pay for, right?)  But I've already purchased an InCase stand cover that actually does a great job of protecting the iPad.  It can also prop up the iPad in a VERY stable position.  The only thing I miss is not having the lock/unlock feature.  It's possible to do with some well placed magnets, but it's going to be a little tougher to have a clean permanent solution.

This is my medium sized bag. I have a Tamrac velocity 7 that i use to carry my d90 and an extra lens and a flash. I also have a backpack that fits all my gear. This one comfortably carries my d90 with my 17-55 f/2.8, my sb600, sigma 30 f/1.4, sigma 10-20 and nikon 85mm. If i carried one less lens, i could put my battery grip in the case. If i removed two lenses, i could easily put the grip on the camera and and store it in the bag.This new version has a nice feature which allows you to cover the velcro closures and rely on the two plastic pinch locks.as far as weight goes, packed completely, it is not to heavy, as i would imagine the 7MDH would be. It's not too wide,although, make no mistake, this does not really look like a messenger bag. It looks like a portable soft cooler. My wife thought it was a lunch container/cooler.I like it though, i think it's less conspicous than other camera bags, although not stealthy as others emphasize.Construction seems very nice, the bag seems pretty sturdy and supported throughout.UPDATE 4/4/2011So i've had this bag for almost 2 years. Still looks great. There was a few months here where i swtiched to a messenger bag and/or just carried my camera in a diaper bag...but then i tried this as a diaper bag...Has some padding which is sort of like insulation and dividers...so i would carry a diaper, wipes, bottle and food and still have room for my camera with a small lens (nikon 50 1.8 or sigma 30-lens down). I truly appreciate the how i can hang a lens carrier on the outside, which functions as a lens carrier or baby food carrier.In addition...Now that i have a d7k and nikon f100, i can actually carry both bodies with a 24 1.4 on one and a 135 dc on the other. perfect.

I bought these to replace a pair of Celestion Ditton 100s that I'd had since the mid 80s which I thought were still the best small speakers ever.  But, one of those fell off it's wall mounting breaking the cabinet and since the Ditton 100s are no longer made, I had to look for something else.  I have to say, despite the reviews I'd read, I was still very surprised by what I heard when I hooked these MB42s up.  I use them as satellite speakers downstairs in my game room and they are mounted about 7 feet high just a few inches under a hung ceiling.  They are a little over half the size of my old 100s and less than half as heavy.  The MB42s are significantly more efficient than the 100s and have a very deep and stable stereo image.  The bass is clean and accurate, but only down to 60hz, so you wouldn't want to listen to organ music with these.  But they don't have any inserted hump in the bass response either that many small speaker manufacturers use to give the illusion of deep bass response which almost always gives an artificial weight to male voices.  The midrange of the MB42s isn't at all colored and the high end is crisp and clean without being sibilant.  To think that I paid about twice as much for my 100s almost 30 years ago is amazing.  I can recommend the MB42s to anyone looking for a small pair of satellite speakers from which they need all the fidelity of their main pair without the deep bass response.

The only thing that I didn't know about was that it had a built in scanner, or whatever it's called that allows you to pick up the channels if you don't have cable or satlilite. My dad is the one that figured out that I didn't need the box and now I get more channels that I didn't before with my old tv and the box. We purchased 2 of these for the holiday season when they first came out.  After looking at the Zune HD in a retail location, I was fairly amazed at the how beautiful the hardware was and how sleek and simple the user interface performed.  As I have no religious affiliation with Apple or any other consumer electronics manufacturer, the Zune HD seemed like a terrific value at its price point compared to the (uhum) competition.  I like Apple just fine, but their prices are no longer in my personal zone of reality, especially for commodity hardware that just about any one can make.  Please don't troll my reviews and slam me for having an open mind as far as consumer electronics goes.  It is not interesting.  Caveat:  I am a engineer in the computer industry, and have been for 25 years....I proceeded to purchase 2 of them for 2 of my teenage daughters (the other was perfectly happy with her Sansa).  The Zune HDs looked so innocent and happy under the tree, and my children were both truly happy to receive the latest cool gadget as a gift.  Of course, the fact that it wasn't an iPod made them even more intrigued, as they actually have something that is NOT the same as all the other kids.  So far so good.They unwrapped the boxes and removed the Zunes from their packaging.  Whats not to love about the device and its fantastic design and interface.  Nothing....  a truly wondrous gadget.Now for the bad part of the review.....So I like Microsoft just fine.  Their stuff works well, just like most stuff from the major manufacturers out there, if you spend enough time with it, you can usually get as much out of it as the engineers put into it.My kids use everything from Winamp to iTunes to Windows media player to listen to music from our huge music library (over 40,000 songs, thank you Amazon for no DRM).  What I was not prepared for, and I should have known better, was that Microsoft in their infinite wisdom, would require YET ANOTHER piece of media software to make their beautiful new hardware work properly.  Enter the Zune software for the PC.Now then, Windows Media Player has been around forever, and it works fine (not my fave, but it does work fine).  It is mature, well developed, and reliable.  I had stupidly assumed that it would work fine with the Zune, but NOOOO.  I felt my stomach starting to turn.Well, I swallowed hard, and installed the Zune software on the my kids PCs.  Another massive blob of software...  a painful start down the path of Zuneland...After installing the Zune software, I spent another several hours trying to get it to run, with lots of error messages, service settings, and other dumb and silly "security" configurations to make.  We have successfully used Vista for several years (no, its not that bad once you tame it) and I foolishly assumed that it would just accept Zuneware:  WRONG.  In order to tame Vista, you need to shut off lots of "features" and "security" things that have zero value.  Well, the Zuneware likes many of these things, so it took some time to arrange everything so Zuneware would run.  Eventually, it ran and only crashed the system every few hours (FYI, we have had exceptional reliability from Vista, across over a dozen machines, both laptops and desktops, as well as home theater PCs), so the Zuneware introduced unreliability, which really turned my already turning stomach.Now to try the first sync, or whatever was supposed to happen.  It took another 4 hours to get the machine and the Zuneware to actually see the Zune HD.  Copious reboots, uninstalls, reinstalls, USB port swapping, etc, etc, and finally, the stars aligned and the Zune was seen by the Zuneware.  Success... at least I thought so.Now I read the ramblings of a forthcoming Microsoft product manager from the Zune group about why they felt they needed yet more software for the Zune.  Something to do with the "customer experience", yeah, whatever.  Mine is terrible.Now to try and use the tooty fruity Zuneware, was yet another adventure.  For some reason, some genius at Microsoft decided that they would make the Zuneware work COMPLETELY differently from any other media software out there.  Cudos for trying to be different, but the Zuneware is just plain BAAAAD, no make the AWFUL.  It took nearly a day to load our music (stored on a windows home server), and then, trying to arrange it so you could move it onto the Zune, well that was another unnatural act.Suffice it to say, I could spend another 1000 words describing the absolutely delightful (NOT) experience interacting with Zuneware, but I'll spare you, the innocent reader, from more of my diatribe.  In short, the Zuneware is yet another insidious virus like software that weaves its way into your system and won't let go.  It is incredibly painful to organize your media, and then even worse to move it back and forth to the Zune.  Basically, it just sucks.And to add insult to injury, our genius friends at Microsoft do not allow Mass Storage mode for the Zune, it doesn't appear as a flash memory device, like every other phone, MP3 player, USB device, etc on the PLANET (ie, you can't just load it with YOUR music, you MUST use the Zuneware)What is the most tragic thing here, is that the Zune HD device itself, is absolutely BRILLIANT, but is ruined by the ludicrous Zuneware.Finally, the biggest barometer.. my teenage daughters.  Now these kids are pretty self sufficient with technology.  But the $200 Zune HDs just sit there.  They don't use them.  Ever.  The Zuneware is just so annoying, unnecessary, and horrible, that they just don't care anymore to engage in the wrestling match to try and get it to work with the Zune.  For the record, its NOT the Zune device itself, but the Zuneware on the PC that my kids just HATE HATE HATE.  They just won't bother with it any more.In conclusion, if you've made it this far in my maniacal rantings, you probably have a decent idea of our experience with the glorious yet stillborn Zune HD.  I am now selling our Zune HDs, and will seek out another device for my teenagers.If Microsoft would enable regular mass storage mode, so we could use ANY media player software, then I'm sure the teenagers would have loved the Zune HDs, but as it stands now, the Zuneware ruined a perfectly good device.  And to all, a good night
summary: Stunning device, ruined by awful Zune software and no mass storage mode

reviewText: I found a DX3700 in a thrift store and paid 2 dollars for it.  I didn't expect it to work, especially for that price.  Anyway, it didn't work, and it didn't have a  memory card installed. Since I was away from home, I didn't have access to the computer to look for a manual.  But, I put a couple of cheap batteries in it to see if it would work.  It didn't.Then, when I got home, against Kodak's recommendations, I installed some good quality alkaline batteries, and tried it. It worked! So, then I stuck an SD card in it, and it still worked.  Down loading the manual from the Kodak website was easy.  The manual said not to use alkaline batteries, or any other cheap battery.  It said to use LI or NIMH batteries. But, mine continues to work with good quality alkaline batteries.  Also, the Kodak site has a "firmwear update" for this camera, and instructions on how to download it. That update is said to fix several issues with the DX3700. I downloaded that firmwear but haven't tried it yet.)I didn't get any cables with this camera; after all, I fished it out of a pile of old point and shoot film cameras.  Whenever I see a digital camera for 5 dollars or less, I buy it to play with.  More than half of the 15 or 20 cameras I've bought were discarded by people that didn't know what they were doing, and refused to read the instructions.  I haven't yet found a good cellphone camera, so I'll continue to keep an inexpensive digital in each of my vehicles.  The NX3700 works just great for that, and it's fun.Kodak DX3700 EasyShare 3MP Digital Camera
summary: What do you mean this camera is no good?

Update - I am adding a star to this review as over time, this has proven to be a very reliable and easy to use product that excels over previous versions.At first blush, I may have been a bit biased from my experience with previous Pinnacle Studio versions.---Windows Movie Maker and OS X iMovie are very, very solid and easy to use video editors that can do 90% of what consumer need to do with them.Adobe Premiere is an expensive high-end video production tool.In the middle is stuff like Pinnacle - which can cobble alot of new and advanced features together into a somewhat awkward interface .The main thing I use Pinnacle for is Chromakey, as you wont find that in iMovie or WMM.Of course, it also comes with a bazillion crappy transitions you should never use, many of them with 3d objects which look like they were rendered in Second Life. That doesn't distract from the fact that Pinnacle is a competant NLE which shouldn't be difficult to pick up and work with for anyone experienced with other NLE software.One strike I noticed is that it couldn't import some mov files.Annoying, but I try to make it a point to not save or use mov files anyway.If you have tried iMovie and/or WMM, don't move to Pinnacle unless you know what it is it has you need. Otherwise, stick to those, because they are cheap, solid, and work great.
summary: Value competitor to Premiere et al

reviewText: My first experience was the Sony Noise Canceling Headphones MDR-NC6.  They worked modestly well a half dozen times.  Then they failed to turn on and stopped working.  I text messaged a technician on the Sony website about the problem.  Zachery said that it was mandatory to use a Sony brand AAA battery replacement.  This is hogwash because all AAA batteries have the same dimensions, amps and voltage.  The MDR-NC6 was a waste of money.So, like a fool, I bought Sony Noise Canceling Headphones Model MDRNC8/BSAM at Wal-Mart for $49 plus tax.  They are a $49 pair of ear muffs.  It produced zero noise reduction in a variety of environments.  Yes, the LED light was on, indicating the instrument worked.  But no, it didn't work, so I got a refund.  The only thing they do is keep your ears warm.Perhaps it was a fluke and I got a bad set, so I found the same Sony model at Radio Shack.  The salesman worked with me on the issue.  We took another brand new MDRNC8 out of a sealed package, inserted a battery, made sure it worked and tried to hear if the thing actually cancelled noise.  And since I have a slight hearing deficit, it was good to have a young man with great hearing confirm my findings.  It didn't work.  It is supposed to reduce ambient noise 90%.  It doesn't.  I was glad not to have to return another set.  (BTW, Radio Shack's price as $39.)Finally I tried on a set of Audio-Technica ATH-ANC27 Headphones.  They cost $107 with tax.  They worked!  Excellent.  There was a very clear difference when the headphones are on and working.  It's an expensive price to pay for a simple audio fix but there is a difference between headsets, and the deplorable conditions of modern air travel almost demand some relief.
summary: An Expensive Fix, But They Work

My old car charger had trouble keeping my HTC Evo charged when in GPS navigation mode, and was worthless with a tablet.  This charger will handle both at the same time.

I have been using the Squeezebox Boom box in my kitchen for 8 months now - and love it.  I was looking to replace my failed Roku Soundbridge with an all in one solution (The Roku required a separate amplifier), and decided that I wanted to try the newest Squeezebox radio.  The good: Easy to set-up and use (Particularly as I already had the Squeezebox account), and a great user interface.  The bad: Sound, no remote (can be added as an option), and no user documentation.This sounds like a tabletop clock radio with virtualy no stereo imaging. It is advertised as a stereo radio, but I'm not hearing it.  Even my older Alurateck internet radio has better imaging. What bass there is is muddy and the radio sounds rather tinny.  There are NO TONE adjustments, so there is not real solution.  There are no Line-out connections to hook it up to an external amplifier, though there is an earphone jack.  The audio is clear (it is still digital), but it is a major step down from the Boombox.The user inteface is a major step-up from the boombox.  The separate volume know is a definite improvement - the use of the large know on the boombox leads to inadvertent menu selections when you were trying to change the volume.  The inclusion of presets is a great plus - you press a preset and it turns the radio on to the source (channel) you selected whether it be a playlist from your personal music collection, a Pandora station, or an internet radio station.  The alarm is a little more complex with at least three levels of menus, but you can have multiple alrms for different times on different days, and individually enable them (if you dig through the menus) or just turn them all on/off at the top alarm menu level. One disappointment is that there is no way to select different stations or presets for the different alarms.  The radio comes on and plays whatever you were last listening to.  Having the graphic display is really nice.  It is bright and generally easy to read, though it does auto dim - to much if you want to read the clock in the dark.  I haven't found a way to adjust it.In summary, if you want a great clock radio that will play Pandora, internet radio or stream music from your library this is a great solution, but it will sound like a mono clock radio. If you are looking for beter sound, the boom box is well worth the extra money.  Hopefully, Logitech will update the boombox with the user interface from the Squeezebox Radio ... soon.
summary: Great user interface - but tinny sound falls well short of BoomBox

reviewText: Great product for the price! I have added many files to this device and have had no problems at all. Still have a lot of room left.
Easy to operate I can control it from my kindle fire or my smart phone  good sound very happy with it so far
summary: Plays all my music from my server

reviewText: Super high quality. Status lights are very imformative. Works great with my iPhone 4. Very satisfied!

If you're looking for an inexpensive set of speakers for your computer or multimedia system (I use them to monitor video tape transfers in conjunction with a speakerless computer monitor), look no further.These speakers have it where it counts--quality construction, magnetic shielding, and decent sound. In listening tests, I found them detailed with excellent dynamics and realistic mids and highs.  The only drawback (as others have pointed out) is a lack of bass, but that's to be expected in this design.  For my purposes deep bass isn't necessary.  Dialog is readily intelligible and even music sounds surprisingly good.  I was impressed listening to jazz saxophone through these.I measured the frequency response at 160Hz to 17kHz with peaks at 300Hz and 3kHz.  The high frequency bump probably explains the crisp quality of the sound, but don't misunderstand--while the sound is crisp it isn't overly bright.  I found extended listening quite non-fatiguing.  Also, there is no apparent noise even when the volume is cranked up.  Very nice.  Some lesser speakers pick up AC hum or add amplifier hiss.Overall you can't ask for more in a basic, low cost speaker.  Highly recommended.
summary: Look no further for speakers at this price point

reviewText: I own a pair of the JVC XTREME Xplodes (HA-FX1X) and lost a bud when taking them out of my pocket.  I needed a fast replacement due to using them when in the office.  These are just as good if not better than the stock ones that came with them and outstanding for a replacement bud especially at this price point.  The fit on the ear pieces is great and they are comfortable. Isolation is also very good. Comes with a velcro (arm-band?) of some sort.  Shipping was fast and they were here within 24 hrs.  Definitely recommended.
summary: Fits two pairs of JVC's I own perfectly

reviewText: The AmazonBasics Universal Camera Case is about as basic as you can get for a camera case. It has a long Velcro flap in front, a Velcro belt loop on the back, and a very thin strap above the belt loop. Under the main flap in front, there is a zippered pocket which is very narrow. Can't hold much more than a memory card or two, and the flap doesn't feel super secure.The main compartment can hold a decent-sized camera. This is overkill if you have a Canon ELPH or other slim model. Fits my old Canon A540 with room to spare, but disappointed that the front pocket won't hold spare batteries (the Canon A540 uses AA batteries).It would be nice if there was a thicker shoulder strap which connects to the sides of the case. The flimsy strap it comes with (it's like the ones that you put on your actual point-and-shoot... kind of like a Wiimote strap) doesn't give you a sense of security when dangling from your wrist.Remember the old saying... you get what you pay for. I wouldn't recommend this case if you plan on carrying it around a lot. If you're using it to store a camera in a drawer, then it's a good deal.
This adapter is OK. I wouldn't really consider it 'high gain,' but as an adapter it works just fine. Having the extra USB extension cable is also handy.

Did not work at all, complete waste of time and money! No blown fuses as others have described, just nothing, tried various appliances and no good...ended up throwing the thing in the garbage out of sheer frustration!.

I like this mouse a lot. I use it in my laptop case. However if you put it in a case, like a travel case, leave the batteries out. The movement inside the bag keeps the mouse "awake" thus draining the batteries.A lot of people complained about the jittery movement and I dont see it. I do perform a lot of graphical work and it seems to be ok. So I am unsure where that comes from. To make my review simpler, let me just list some pros and cons.PRO: Comfortable rubber grip, decent performance for a wireless mouse, good price, runs on standard AA batteries, so you can go ANYWHERE to get batteries for it. (Unlike some which use odd ball battery packs).CONS: Software (Had some issues, read below), the amount of time it takes the mouse to be "discovered" by the USB receiver, succeptible to RF interference. (In strong RF fields, like those near a directional AM station, it can hiccup, but thats rare).Software. DO NOT INSTALL THE SOFTWARE THAT COMES WITH THE MOUSE IF YOU USE A LAPTOP. The software is clumsy, but even worse, it overrites some DLL files in a laptop needed to control the touchpad. If you don't mind not having loony features like one click ctrl+alt , etc., just install the USB reader and let Windows discover and install the mouse. Windows XP and 2000 should do this with no problem. You will still have scroll bar capabilities, etc.
Used this power supply for a very small HTPC. The plug fit the PC perfectly and powered the PC correctly.

THE COST IS MINIMAL AND I BELIEVE IN THE PRODUCT. WHILE TO DATE I'VE NEVER HAD TO USE ONE, I KNOW IT WOULD PROTECT THE DEVICE FOR WHICH IT WAS PURCHASED. THE COST CAN'T BE BEAT EITHER SO IT'S DEFINITELY A WIN-WIN DEAL.
summary: I ALWAYS BUY THESE FOR ANY ITEM FOR WHICH THEY ARE AVAILABLE

reviewText: I ordered this product for my MP3 player which is not an IPOD Nano.  The product is beautiful but it didn't fit my device.  I couldn't return it because I cut it trying to make it fit.

My daughter has been using these with her gaming system and loves them to pieces.  She said they have wonderful sound as well as noise reduction from outside sources.  The only thing she would have different is the cord going to the controller as it just makes it with her arm length.  Poor girl has very long arms so she's always looking for longer reach items. I purchased this last year after a hurricane that left us with out power for 6 days and when hurricane Sandy rolled through and was out for 2 weeks it was just wonderful, the tuning, ease of use, no complaints.

I purchased this product as a bias light because the specs say "professionally calibrated" to 6500K.  That's the standard color temperature digital cinema displays and properly calibrated TVs use, and it's ideal for watching movies, etc.However, when measured with a color meter, I found that this product is actually more like 8500K, and has a great deal of red/green shift between LEDs.  Not usable for any kind of professional color work, and even for watching movies in my living room it's distracting because it looks so blue compared to the screen.The response I got from Antec customer support is that none of their units are calibrated or tested with color meters, and they ended up closing my case without helping.Physically, it's a good size for my 50" TV, although it's slightly too dim.

These sound fantastic. Great bass without sacrificing highs and mids. For in-ear speakers that are made of metal, they are surprisingly comfortable with the right ear tip. If you get these, you should also get the Monster Super Tips, which are sold separately. I was able to find the perfect fit with a medium foam tip. The only complaint I have with these is the cord is prone to tangle. Other than that, they are great and worth every penny.

Really, without this stud (or spigot as some call it) many light stands would be useless, as most studio lights are designed to attach to this type of connection.The low spots ensure a safe connection, as lights will not fall off even if they loosen with time, vibration, heat expansion, cooling, etc.If your stands or booms use this type of connection, purchase an extra and tape (or cable tie-even better as it is stronger and neater) it to something you always have available. You will lose one someplace and without one, you may not be able to set up the lighting you want.One solid, machined piece of brass, with 1/4" and 3/8" screw connections that allow you to attach other things, even cameras, to stands.

Purchased this computer for my elderly parents and it was the right computer for them.  Very reliable and the DVD movies played on this systemm are crystal clear.  Ease of use is one of the best features of this system given they have never used a computer before. It fits perfectly in any small space.  I would recommend that you purchase a logitech key board and a basic logitech mouse with it ($12.00 and $8.00). The keyboard that comes with it is way too small for anyone who is visually challenged.  The mouse is ok but I recommend you spend the extra money on logitec products...I did get the logitech speakers with it and the system rocks.If its just the internet and movies and basic features you are looking for, look no futher.............
It works like a charm, great stuff.  I use it with my 580 ex flash and everything just works.  ThankS

Wow! This thing is small! The only problem you might have with it's tiny size is that you'll either lose it or it won't stay put. With 4 USB cables coming out of the front, it won't sit flat on the ground and is easily tossed around. I didn't really care... that just meant I could plug all my cables into and hang it over the side of my desk! It's been working perfectly for over 2 months now (OS X 10.5). I'm tempted to buy another one for my PS3 since it only has two USB ports on it.

I have serious issues with the speakers on my MacBook.  For one, I can't even figure out where exactly the speakers are since there are no standard speaker holes like you see with other laptops.  Perhaps, that simple fact is the reason why I typically have to have the volume all the way up to hear things on my laptop.  The sound quality really doesn't drive me batty until I'm doing something several feet away from the laptop, like cooking dinner while listening to music or a pod cast, and I can't hear what's playing.  The Logitech z305 Clip-on Laptop Speaker solves this problem and delivers great sound quality and volume. (Yay!)At times I can be technically impaired when it comes to installing new electronic devices.  Thankfully, Logitech makes their instructions crystal clear and easy to follow.  Installing this speaker on your laptop is very simple.  You just have to clip it on the monitor portion of the laptop and plug it into your USB port.  After that I just needed to enable the speaker with a few clicks in my Mac settings and I was set.  From start to finish installation and configuration took me about 30 seconds.  Since the speaker is powered by the laptop, there's no need to worry about batteries.  The clip is nicely padded so you won't have to worry that it will damage your laptop.When the speaker is not in use you can store it in the nice little drawstring storage bag that was included.  I could live with or without the storage bag, but I certainly think it was a nice touch.Overall, I think this is a great product that is  easy to use and thoughtfully designed.
summary: Finally I can listen to things on my MacBook!

reviewText: GENERAL BACKGROUND INFO:  Computer power supplies.  Is there really a good one?  These are almost a normal wear and tear item anymore.  Almost all of them are rather cheaply made with a limited life span.  They are subject to heat and dust.  The cooling fans seem to fail on a regular basis, which causes the power supply to overheat and fail.  They are prone to lightning strikes and other power surges; and sometimes the internal components simply fail without warning.  Over the years, I have replaced dozens for myself and clients.  How long will yours last?  No telling.  You could take a power surge tomorrow and it's gone.  That being said, I leave my computer running 24/7 so power supply failure after so many hours is more common for me.  When they go, I just replace the power supply.  An exception is when they take a power surge or an internal component other than the fan fails.  In all instances where this has happened to me, damage was done to other components of my computer and professional service is required for most users.That being said, how good will this one be?  Probably as good as any and maybe better given the ball bearing fan.  Logisys is a known brand name.  Use power surge protection as much as possible.  Hope for the best as far as internal component failure (other than the fan) is concerned.  If you turn your computer off and on, your success rate may be better than mine although there are other issues connected to turning a computer off and on which are beyond this review.So basically, what can you expect for a $20 component subjected to a lot of heat, dust, and power variations?  Buy it, install it, and hope that it doesn't damage a bunch of other components when it eventually goes bad.
summary: Logisys Corp 550W 120mm Ball Bearing Fan ATX PSU

reviewText: At the moment there are very few portfolios available for the Xoom. This one, by Motorola, looks nice and provides good all around protection for the tablet.However, it's next to useless as a 'stand'. Upon opening, you can put the Xoom in one of two 'tilt' positions -- sort of upright, and sort of reclined. However, the ridges on the case aren't deep enough and don' have enough grip to hold the tablet. Consequently, as you're swiping, tapping, or typing on the Xoom, the thing continually collapses down into the flat position. Annoying, and the repeated thumping down is likely to damage the tablet at some stage.Also, when the tablet is in the case, you cannot access any of the ports (e.g. charging) on the bottom of the tablet because there are no cutouts there. A quick session with a Dremel took care of that. However, that only helps when the tablet is flat or the case is closed due to the design of the Xoom itself and the location of the bottom ports.Two stars because the portfolio is well built and provides good protection when closed. Otherwise useless and not recommended.
These are pretty amazing for the price. The construction is super solid and they fit very snugly. I'm using 14 gauge wire with no issues at all.

I don't use my 2007 MacBook Pro much and have always hated the tiny trackpad on there, so I was not hopeful when I got a Trackpad with a new Mac. I made the switch that day! It is so easy to use. I order additonal ones for each of my computers (sure wish they were lower cost).You don't need to clear off desk space to make sure you can scroll or move from one side of the screen to the other.The trackpad is nice and compact without any need to move it while using. I have been using computers since 1980 and have repetitive stress issues with my hand. With the trackpad, I don't need to move my hand around as much, so I have less pain.
summary: Bought one for each my Macs

reviewText: A tad on the loud side when at max speed. I have this on my Corsair H60. Moves a good amount of air and has good static pressure. I found this product to be overrated.  Few services included.  Need to have iTunes running somewhere to really make it work.  Had trouble getting it to pick up my iTunes NAS library.  Returned it.

The cases are fine enough for the price.  They'll work to protect the iPOD from general wear and tear, but would not survive a fall of more than a foot onto a hard surface.  Cover appears to be meant for the iPhone as there's a hole for a speaker in it.

The good: it snaps on to the Nexus 7 and uses the 7 as a top cover so it is fairly compact and pairing is simple and quick.The bad: the keyboard is about the same size as the virtual keyboard on the 7.  It is much too small to touch type on. I tried several times and it just not work.  Resorted to just picking it up and thumbing it like the virtual keyboard.  As a stand for the 7, it lacks adjustability; one angle fits all sort of speak.  Additionally, while the back is a kind of rubber material, the keyboard actually sits on 4 small tab like projections that are slippery on a hard surface like a wooden desktop causing the keyboard to slide around when you try and type on it.As keyboard option I can not recommend it.

reviewText: As mentioned with other reviews - this product conflicts with position of RAM.Other then that keeps it 10-15 degrees less then stock fan! Not bad.

I was relying on a class 4 SD card by SanDisk when I received my Canon Rebel T2i. I could not record HD videos without it pausing, trying to record the file fast enough.I went ahead and purchased this after reading some great reviews. It came in a simple box. As soon as I popped it in my camera, I could detect the difference immediately. 1080p video at 30fps recorded without a hitch though the card began to run warm after a six minutes and a warning came up on the camera. You can snap pictures all day without any worrying that something will happen. It transfers photos to the computer (a Mac in this case) extremely quickly.Absolutely worth the price for speed, convenience, and reliability.
everyone knows verbatim makes the best media.  i have bought these many times and they all work, everytime. highly highly recommended. buy verbatim media.

The left side of the keyboard on my HP DV7-4272 gets hotter than the surface of the sun when playing online games.  This thing is so hot, even Paris Hilton couldn't say, "That's hot."  I'd fry eggs on it but the keys keep getting in the way of the spatula.The single large fan in the center of this product pushes air up to the bottom of the laptop.  I'd prefer to be able to direct it to the bottom LEFT side where the nuclear core is, but no re-positioning possible.  It took a minute to find the speed control, it's a small thumb wheel on the right side.  Thinking the fan was not spinning very fast, I went to turn up the speed, only to realize it was already on it's highest setting.  Dang.One major drawback is the USB plug that powers it.  Standard USB plugs are about 1 1/2 long of plug, plastic, and wire protector before it turns into plain cable.  The USB ports on the HP DV7 are on the sides, nearer to the front of the laptop.  That means if I plug in the fan to the USB port on the right side, I have this long USB plug sticking out near my hand.  I quickly found out that transitioning from mouse handling to keyboard typing, I was knocking this plug sticking out.Why do USB plugs have to stick straight out from the computer like porcupine quills?  Why aren't there L-shaped plugs that can follow the contour?I decided to move the plug to the left side of the laptop, only to realize the supplied cord is a few inches too short.  The USB on the fan unit connects at the top-right corner, near the power switch.  I could not run the cable around the back of the laptop and up into the left side.  I finally settled on having to run the cable UNDER unit, which made it awkward when sitting on a flat surface.  I finally ran the USB cable BETWEEN the fan and the laptop, and that seems to work out.The product says it can accommodate a 17" laptop.  Mine is a 17" laptop and I'll tell you that this fan barely fits underneath.  The laptop overhangs the fan about 3/4" on left/right sides.  That means I have to keep my legs closer together to keep the fan unit on my lap.  Additionally, there are 2 nice rubber feet on the backside of the fan to keep it from slipping off a table.  But when placed on your lap, you can feel them slightly digging into your legs.The blue LED on the fan does not really light anything up and not noticeable when your sitting at your laptop, even in a dark room.Overall:Heat control: averageStability: goodLap Compatible: poor
It was as expected and works well to take unit into the military field and protect unit from harm. Happy with case and should last for the lifetime of the tablet.

I have a Thermaltake case that's about 5yo so some of the pictures were a bit vague in the instructions. I would have appreciated the instructions being on a larger format page to increase legibility and expanded for clarity. My eyes are not those of a 20yo anymore. It would also have been nice if they explained if there are is functionality available over the USB port for Linux, aka, the lm-sensors or mbmon package. Anyhow, everything fit together and it is nice to see a product with only two parts left over. This case was a great purchase.  It is much better than the previous stand up case.One con is that there is no way to prop the case in portrait orientation
