reviewText: I bought these for a family friend who needed both English and Korean keyboard layouts - after spending awhile sticking these all on, they worked wonderfully!
like the title says it works and looks pretty good although it doesn't look as vibrant as the original its still a great display with no dead pixels

Wanted to buy another soft box but didnt want to spend a whole lot of money.  Saw a friend using a similar product but it was still too expensive so I scanned Amazon and saw this umbrella soft box.  Bought it and was pleasantly surprised at its performance.It was delivered very quickly.  The product itself was easy to setup.  Just open it like an umbrella.  Inside is a silver reflective material pretty much like that used in reflectors.  I set it up and boosted my flash power up and was surprised by the quality of output.  I used to shoot through an umbrella so I dont need to boost up flash power.  So I expected that I need to boost my flash power a lot higher but I saw that I don't need to go 1/1 power as long as the light was not very far from the subject.Its size made a surprisingly big surface even larger than my current softbox.  For its price and performance, I would definitely recommend this product.

If this is the size you want ... get it. If you want to use it for panoramas ... get the 488. Which I did too. But as a good quality general ball head ... hey it's a Manfrotto and it is good. No complaints, no issues ... I love it.

I'm not very demanding when it comes to monitors. I just wanted something high value and with plenty of screen real estate. Cyber Monday $110 for 24" 1080p (1920x1080), can't be beat. If I wanted more pixels I needed to go up to 27" (not a problem), but the price skyrockets (triple or more) for 2560x1440 monitors.Anyway, these are bright and crisp. They come in a few pieces and assemble as easy as anything I've ever seen (attach the base with one thumb twistable screw to the back mount, then snap the back mount to the screen; no tools needed at all). The monitors are light weight, but don't feel flimsy. They have a VGA and a DVI port for convenience (no HDMI). This version came with VGA cables, oh well. I connected two to my laptop dock so I have 3 screens. Worked right off the bat and I used the default Win 7 tools to arrange their positions so that my laptop screen was logically in the middle and they extend left and right.Haven't had any issues with flicker or refresh rates or anything else. Love them. They do make my 14" laptop screen look puny though...

Speed is decent without being incredible, but reasonable for the price. I don't like the flip-cover design though, as the cover soon got loose and simply flips open in my pocket. Overall though, not a bad drive. I do wish there was an indication that this was mounted/in-operation though.

This is an extremely well made product with a lot of attention to detail. There are several different options for controlling the external noise. Most of all is the wear ability - that is how they feel after an hour or more of use, these remain very comfortable. The sound quality is outstanding and is very easy to Bluetooth pair. The volume could be a little louder but for most - it is pleasingly loud. There is one option that will improve the sound and that is the apt-x adapter which is sold separately. This significantly ups the audio quality.
summary: Great sound and lots of features.

reviewText: I found some bad reviews on this amp, so it took me a while to purchase it, but glad I did...at least so far. I had installed an in-ceiling surround (speakers) system, including two-channel rear speakers...not the surround rear speakers, but two additional speakers. However, the speakers sounded lauder than the two front speakers...perhaps due to their different impedance. Because of the way the room is designed, I needed to correct this issue to ensure better sound from my old JVC receiver...had it for about 18 years.Anyway, I hooked the two front speakers to the amp and then used a cable to connect the phones receivers output to the amp's CD input. This worked wonderfully. I get to change the volume to the front speakers and adjust bass and travel directly through the amp. The JVC receiver stills deliver power to the rear speakers, but I can lower the volume down while using the amp to raise the volume to the front speakers.It also has a mic input. I hooked a mic and can sing along while playing my favorite tune...the mic has separate volume. I have not tried the USB port, but if it works is just another extra bonus. As other reviewers mentioned, the lights are quiet bright...you don't want this amp in your bedroom. Another thing is that it needs plenty of good ventilation as it can get very hot. So far, however, it has worked great. Can't tell you whether or not is pulling 120 watts, but it's loud enough.
Arrived OK, as described. I'd buy another. Why do I have to put so many words into my ratings? one more

Firstly – I am NOT an audiophile. I can’t tell you about the subtleties of the clarity/pitch/etc.  What I CAN say is that this receiver does an EXCELLENT job at delivering what, to me, is a very clear, clean sound, and does it WAY better than the Sony receiver it replaced which was 3x the cost.  It was as easy to set up as any receiver, and its controls are similarly consistent / straightforward. I even find the radio to be above average – it’s very sensitive (almost too much so!).  I am quite impressed by this product.  It does everything it should, and it does it very well.  It’s also pretty stylish too – I have absolutely no qualms with the build of it; it’s ‘clean’ and simple, and I like the brushed looked of it (I think that’s what it’s called).  All in all, if someone were to ask me for a recommendation for an inexpensive but quality receiver, I would feel perfectly OK recommending this unit to them.  I’m very pleased with it.
summary: Good receiver. Packs a clean punch.

reviewText: After researching many tripods, I decided on this one based on price, and other reviews. I have not been disappointed!! This product sets up quickly and easily, the easy mount system works flawlessly. The bag it comes with is durable, and doubles as a backpack, making it a cinch to carry around.
Nothing much to say.  It is what it says it is. I just needed a case that would fit in my larger bag of goodies.  And it works nicely.
summary: Needed a generic case for camera and got one

reviewText: We have a large home, and conventional WiFi access points just simply didn't work well enough.I am fairly skilled in setting this stuff up (I work for a few schools as a network technician), so setup was about as complicated as a standard enterprise AP.I haven't had to reboot the device yet, its worked perfectly and remained stable for months now.The system software on the device has a frequency scanner so you can see non-WiFi 2.4 GHz interference, this helped when finding the best channel - it also informed us that our microwave is leaking radiation.The area we live in has severe channel congestion and interference in the 2.4 ghz range, however I have a good signal to this access point from anywhere in our home, even outside and down the driveway (900ft). Its more reliable and easier to connect to than the 5.8ghz 802.11a  Sony location-free LF-PK1 access point half the distance away and on a clear channel.I get about 18-24 mbps (about 2.25 to 3 MB/sec) with a good signal (which is pretty much everywhere).The transmit power is capped to 29dB - this is due to regulations that prevent the device from transmitting at 30dB, however with third party firmware, I am sure you can push the radio to 1000

It's simple and functional. It's not one of those cases that will blow you away with amazing cooling or silence, but for the price you pay it does a good enough job in both those departments. The blue LED in front adds a bit of character to it, separating it from just being a normal black box. More than enough room on the inside. For the price, you can't really beat it.
summary: Fine tower for first time PC builder

reviewText: This is an okay gooseneck, but it has a few stiff areas where it hangs up and won't work right, and it's honestly too short to be really usable for anything other than a desk where you're sitting right in front of it anyway. If you clamp it to a bed or the back of a desk, the arm just won't reach far enough to make a difference. The frame for the iPad mount had no instructions, either, and it took me almost an hour to figure out how to click it in place because I didn't want to force it and break it.Wouldn't buy it again.
Very good case. Exceptional quality, the fit is very snug. The color choices are mind-boggling and I am very satisfied with the color I have chosen. Overall an amazingly good quality case.

First of all, I think Amazon.com site is great! This is the first place I look to see customer reviews before plunking down a chunk of change for electronics.** Thanks to the many users of the site!!!! **Just got mine's today (at "Wally World" for 94 bucks, no sales tax in Anchorage, Alaska). Can't think of any easier way to operate the player.1. DO NOT NEED TO INSTALL THE LYRA SOFTWARE WITH WINDOWS XP unless you need to "rip" your CD's and don't already have a program that does that.2. Once you plug in the USB cable, Windows treats the Lyra player as another drive. All you have to do is cut and paste MP3 and WMA files.3. Can set up a playlist right on the player.Thought about getting the newer "Combo memory/MP3 players", but problem is that they are not expandable. Also with Rio players, you need to have another program/patch for Media player to transfer the music onto the player itself.
summary: Can't be any easier to use! Great price.

reviewText: I ordered this case on the basis of other reviews and I'm not disappointed.  The exterior looks like leather, the stitching is clean, straight and well done, the interior of the front cover/stand is a soft, suede-like fabric, the back cover holds the iPad securely without interfering with any of the ports/buttons/camera and the elastic does a great job of holding the cover closed (the elastic covers the camera when closed, which provides extra protection for the lens).  Most importantly, it works perfectly--it holds the iPad in all three positions, both horizontally and vertically and sleeps/wakes the iPad as it should.  It does have a bit of a textile smell, but I think this will dissipate over time.  The included stylus also works well and has a pen on the opposite end, which is convenient.  Even without the stylus, this is a great cover for the price and I highly recommend it.  The shipping was very fast and the cover arrived in good condition.  I don't know how well it'll hold up with daily use, but really, for the price, it's worth a shot.UPDATE, 1/28/13:  I've had this case for just over a week now, and I've used it every day. I still think it's a great bargain, and I wouldn't hesitate to buy another one, but I wanted to note that the first slot no longer holds the iPad as it did initially. I had folded the front cover all the way back behind the back cover, and after that, the "joint" was no longer stiff enough to hold the weight of the iPad in the first slot. This doesn't really bother me since I find that I'm using the second and third slots 99% of the time, but if yours works initially on the first slot and you want to maintain its integrity, don't bend the front cover all the way back. On a positive note, the smell I noticed when I first took it out of the packaging has since disappeared.
I purchased this jump drive because I wanted a high-capacity, very fast USB drive.  This works as advertised; it flies when copying small or large files.

Couldn't be happier with this monitor.  The price was great for an LED Backlit monitor and the picture is amazing.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the factory settings are abysmal, but really... who the heck cares? They are factory settings.  Once you get the brightness, contrast, tone, and all that set up right it's really fantastic.
summary: Great monitor and a great price

reviewText: This backpack is superb. Plenty of room for my new Nikon D3200, along with telephoto lens & hood plus all my accessories (cables, wi-fi adapter, etc).  Great padding offers great protection for the gear and I love the versatility to change the configuration. The hammock system for holding the camera is terrific. Highly recommed this backpack for your DSLR.

I lost my original charger and needed a cheap replacement. Well, thanks to BargainCell, I got it for one penny (plus $4.98 S&H;). So, $4.99 total was better than I could expect. So, take the advice from the other users' reviews and purchase this product while it is still cheap!Update: I recieved this product and it works great. It is also more convienient than the one that came with the iPod. This is a great product.
Boogie Board for someone who likes to draw and can keep lists on.  Easy to use and comes in handy.

Bought this to replace an old vizio Blu-ray player. This thing works great seems to load up pretty fast. The menu is similar to my PS3 so it was easy to figure everything out. It connected to the WiFi really easily. I saw some people were complaining about making a sony entertainment account, but it only took a few minutes and as soon as i finished all the apps loaded up,  i honestly didnt even know there were that many apps for watching movies and tv shows, not to mention the music apps to. Also it came with a few month trial of hulu and a few other things.

i've used about a dozen stereo bluetooth headsets.  my stupid dog eats them somewhat regularly.  these were ok, but subpar and not worth the price.this was my favorite of the 4 motorola stereo BT headsets i purchased over the years, although i found off-brand options that were better:Kinivo BTH240 Bluetooth Stereo Headphonei also used the s9, s9hd, and s10 headsets from motorola.  these were all ok, above average sound quality, but they would constantly come out my ears enough to lose all the bass response: plus if you're wearing those in-ear designs while out walking you're as good as deaf: at least with these over the ear ones you can hear the outside world if you keep the volume at a reasonable level.
summary: motorola stereo bluetooth headsets aren't worth the cost.

reviewText: When you just don't have enough with just one.  Buy a second one, just in case.  I've never run out of juice on first one, so I cannot honestly say how good one is.  Better to have an extra and not need it then not have one at all.  Taking an extended trip in April, will must assuredly be thankful for it then.

works with normal bare SATA drives, not necessary to have the Seagate goflex drives, but you need to find a way to stabilize the bare drive or lay it flat.  I've made a little shim with cardboard and it works just fine. For the price, this is great.

Kensington is the #1 producer of Laptop Locks and most Laptops are designed to accommodate a Kensington lock. This lock is Great! It has sturdy solid metal parts and I expect it will do a great job for a long time. That said you would expect this nearly exclusive Laptop lock maker to provide better installation directions. The directions that came with my keyed Kensington Laptop lock were the briefest of generic directions applicable to most keys & Laptops. But they were missing a very important step in the installation. The directions simply say, "Insert the lock and turn it 90 degrees " to secure it. However the Lock, as packaged requires  preparation before installation that is not noted in the directions. What they fail to tell you is that the lock must be lengthened using the most miniscule and fragile  Allen wrench that I have ever used in my life. The directions only mention the Allen wrench as a means to tighten the lock after you have inserted & turned the lock in the lock port. Nowhere is it mentioned that the lock must be lengthened  to its longest point before it can be turned those 90 degrees in the Laptop. I wasted 45 minutes trying manipulation and experimentation with the only result being that I became more & more frustrated. It was pure luck that I managed to get the lock installed on my Laptop after trying numerous possible solutions.Kensington needs to add the simple but necessary instructions to, "lengthen the stem of the lock"  before inserting it into the lock port. That will save folks like me a lot of heartburn.
summary: Lock  works Great if you can figure out how to install it with the limited directions provided

reviewText: Great product very very bright and the installation for a noob was a breeze! Am considering to buy more in the future thanks again.
This product arrived on time and works great and is a full Class 10 card.  I use it on my android asus transformer tablet and it is a very noticeable improvement over the class 4 I had been using.
summary: Great Product for an even better price!!!

reviewText: I like being able to organize all of the little things.  Only drawback is you lose the top padding in the case.
Has all the basic functions I need in a surround sound receiver, and the automatic room calibration feature is nice.  I wish it had an extra HDMI port, but it's a great unit for the price.

Amazingly easy to install, very solid signal, and software works like a champ.  Unlike my previous wireless card for the office network (cable to that computer is just impossible) this one installed and worked within 10 minutes!  The software was easy, and the signal is so much stronger that the throughput is incredible.  Very nice unit for not too much money.  Highly recommend it.
Love it.  Does what I need.  Protects the Mini and shines like a beacon so it can not get lost.

I've been going through a lot of CD players in the past few years.  Either I don't like the way they sound or they have a problem with durability.  I bought this Yamaha to solve those problems.  In short it faithfully reproduces sound and I hope it lasts.  I  bought this at a brick and mortar store and although I didn't pay list you could probably do better on the internet than I did.  Even at a discount you could still pay close to twice the price of other changers.  But you get what you pay for.EDIT:  Did I mention this player has great SPECS.  I guess I just did and the sound you would expect for those kind of specs.
Bought for a relative to run a TV, Cable Box, and DVD player from. Works, no interference or issues. Saved the equipment a few times during bad storms too.
This cable is just right for connecting my iPhone to the car radio, 3' is just not enough, and 6' gets tangled and is a pain.

I knew this was a cheap tripod when I purchased it but I didn't think it would be this cheap. The legs seem decent and lock into place correctly but the giant black handle you can see in the picture that raises and lowers the center bar will just fall on its own. There is a lock nut that is supposed to keep it at whatever level you set it at but it only worked for about a month, which for me was about a half dozen uses.The locking mechanism on the tilt where you attach your camera also doesn't lock down tight, so you're camera will slowly start to fall forward in time. Forget about using heavier lenses or any extra gear on this tripod, it will just tilt forward immediately and the center bar will fall to the lowest position. Using a Canon t3i with a stock lens and the additional extra weight of a tascam dr07mkii attached to the top, this tripod just doesn't cut it.I've since decided to just use it for the tascam dr07mkii when I record my band's practice. The tascam recorder is really like and that seems to be all this tripod is good for.
summary: Fairly low quality and doesn't lock into place well

reviewText: adequately fit my needs. nothing to complain about. the protective rubber is exactly what would be expected given the price. 50ft was overkill for me but better to have surplus length than too little.

Setup of the Harmony One is simple and user-friendly.  The package includes the control unit, a rechargeable battery, charging station, USB cable, and a programming CD.  If you're not familiar with the programming of the remote, you'll wonder why they didn't think of this function sooner.  You synch the remote with a computer that has the catalog information loaded on it and search for your products in the database.  Once you locate your items, the computer programs the remote to operate those devices.  I'm not as tech savvy as your average middle school kid, so it took me almost an hour to program, but I'd guess most people can do it in 30 minutes.Like I said, I am not on the cutting edge of technology; I did not know such an item existed and really don't have any idea what Bluetooth means, but I know there's now one remote on my coffee table, where once  I had six.  Is it worth the price?  I'm not sure, but I think the kind of people who can consider paying two hundred bucks for a remote control probably don't concern themselves with prices.

It works in Steamboat Springs,CO. I tried  and failed to use it on a trip to NY 1. frequncy #'s not visable in many cars, Very poor reception where a lot of stations exist. It worked but poorly in Denver. for a few dollars more they could have placed station display in a better location or even put a flexible neck on it.
summary: bad design , will not work in cities

reviewText: I have a relatively simple setup, my Panasonic TC-P46ST30 plasma TV and Yamaha RX-V371 receiver. I just wanted to be able to turn both devices on/off with one button, and control both devices with one remote.I bought this knowing nothing about how to set up a Harmony One remote, and was so pleasantly surprised with how easy it was to set up and customize exactly how I wanted. It does everything without even ever having to press the CABLE or DVD buttons! the software is easy to use and once you pick out your devices within the software you can select from the complete list of commands each device has.Once I press "Watch TV", both my TV and receiver power on and everything is mapped to my TV except for the volume which is mapped to my receiver, which is perfect. I set 3 of the 4 colored buttons to go directly to my HDMI 1, 2, and 3 inputs and the last colored button to bring up Viera Cast, which utilizes the Internet functionality of my TV. I have absolutely no need to use my original TV or receiver remote for anything... I can bring up and navigate through all of my TV's menus just like I can with the original remote.In the rare times that I need it, I also set it up so that if I hit the DVD button the first 2 colored buttons are then tied to the 2 inputs I use on my receiver. The first one is what I use 99% of the time for watching TV or playing games, but then the other is for the AUX port if I ever plug in my iPod.I really really wish I would have gotten this sooner! I was going to get a much more expensive Harmony One remote a couple of years ago (but that was when I had Dish as well) and now I'm completely content with this remote. I can't recommend it enough if you have a similar setup. I've read that it can work pretty well for Dish, too, but you could also look into the 300 model since it might make DVR functionality a bit more intuitive. (e.g. not tying colored buttons to DVR skip)
summary: The only problem is that I didn't get one sooner!

reviewText: Belkin's iPad-Mini 'Dot Cover with Stand' is a superb housing case that offers all the basic functionality that you'd expect along with a nice, grippy feel that is very comfortable in your hands.  The cover itself is relatively light-weight so the Mini itself still feels 'mini' even after enclosing it within the case.  There is a proper camera lens cutout that allows you to maintain camera functionality while enclosed and the stand function (in landscape mode) gives you several angles to set for your viewing/usage pleasure.My favorite aspect of this case is the overall look.  If you're fine with the muted color tones this a very handsome case that looks high-quality in design and construction.
summary: Stylish with a great tactile feel

reviewText: Love this product - got it from a local store when on sale. The idea is transmitting signal at FM 88.8 while regular radio channel are at odd decimal (such as 88.7 or 88.9). So no interference with radio. Range is much longer than 8m as it claims, works in 40m radius in fact. Using provided cable easily convert to a regular wired headphone.Design looks fragile. It makes absolutely no sense not to include the 4.5v DC charger. However give 5 star for its price.Follow-up after 3 months use: Sound quality is acceptable, but not orchestra type. Best for watch regular TV; it is very annoying when your batteries (base or headphone) are about to run out. Other channels would interfere, and often lost the original signals.

I have had this product for only a short time and it is invaluable. The Anker requires recharging more often than I had expected which is the reason for the four stars. Also, it does not indicate when the device has been completely recharged. The compactness is nice.
summary: Easy to carry, easy to use!

reviewText: Very nice headphones - sound quality was great for such a low price but they didn't fit well (as a smaller female). The headband is unpadded so having it shift around was annoying and uncomfortable. The ear pads were ok for a short time but also became uncomfortable after extended periods of use. Nice headphones at a very reasonable price, just not for me.
summary: Good sound quality, didn't fit well

reviewText: Nothing matches the power of a Neutral Density (ND) filter for a simple means to introduce dynamic elements into an otherwise static scene. For those who don't know, neutral density filters reduce the amount of light coming through the lens. With an ND filter, you cn reduce the light, so you can use a slower exposure and blur that waterfall you're photographing. It looks a like more like a waterfall if the falling water isn't frozen in time and space. Likewise, let's say you're photographing a street scene - use a ND filter and the shoppers hurrying along become blurred, adding a dynamic element to the scene. By the way, you'll generally want to use a tripod or monopod when shooting with ND filters.This ND filter is adjustable through a range of NF number 2 through 400, which is quite remarkable. That's a range of 8 f-stops.  It sure beats having to carry several ND filters and fumbling for the one you want.There is no question that these are inexpensive filters. The nearest competitor is twice as costly. These filters are multi-coated instead of single-coated.I've only been able to put them to limited use so far, because it is winter in Chicago and I am not doing much outdoor photography.But so far, my limited tests have been encouraging. The adjustment ring slides smoothly and stays in place. I've noticed no color shifts (something that would be typical with inexpensive filters). Vignetting on a 28mm digital camera lens is moderately severe at 28mm, but disappears between 35 - 50mm. For landscape photography, this could be a killer unless you are willing to crop your photos.Overall, I am very pleased with this ND filter. It seems to do the job without breaking the bank.Jerry

Let me start off this review by stating that I have many years of experience with electronic devices, computers and cameras under my belt.  I was working in multimedia before the phrase "multimedia" was coined.  That said, I feel I am more than qualified to review the GoPro Hero3.  But I'm not going to focus on what has already been covered in countless reviews.  You've also likely already seen footage shot with a GoPro, so you know what kind of camera this is and what it's geared towards.  120 FPS in 720p, etc.  So I'm going to focus in on some details I feel that GoPro got wrong.  Very wrong.I'll start off with the packaging.  I've had experience unpacking many, many, many, many electronic and computer devices in my life.  It took me literally a half an hour to fully, carefully de-box this thing.  The package itself is clearly geared towards a retail point-of-sales display, with the camera packaged in its own tough, clear plastic display case atop an almost empty photo laden cardboard box tower.  I discovered that the plastic box is attached to the cardboard box with four points of black, double-sided, sticky, rubber-foot-like-feet and clear tape round the perimeter.  Not only is this entire display case design completely excessive and wasteful, there is no clue given as to how to de-box the thing on the package itself.  So you're left to figure out how the camera that resides in the plastic display on top is attached to the rest of the box without it accidentially falling or flying out onto the floor or across the room in a fit of rage since all you want to do is get your shiny new camera out of this ridiculous box.  Then, once you manage to get the plastic box open, the camera is attached to the bottom of that plastic box with wires.  Not plastic ties.  Not thin, twisty ties covered in black plastic.  Wires.  Threaded through holes.  Get out the pliers.  This all seems very excessive if not downright stupid for what could have been accomplished with a small cardboard box and cardboard packing inserts, especially considering that the vast majority of these cameras will likely be sold online.For $400, there is no manual in the big, stupid box.  Just four squares of useless printed material directing you to update the firmware and download the pdf manual.  The pdf manual that exists online is horrible.  It is not at all comprehensive.  It does not walk you through your initial setup.  It is not much of anything except reference material.  Also included are some basic mounts, the wireless remote and a short mini usb cable.So, being the good little tech nerd that I am, I decided to go ahead and update the firmware as advised by one of those four pieces of paper generously included in the box which explains how crucial it is to update the firmware immediately, or apparently the world may in fact end if you try to use the Hero3 before updating.  This begins the waste of the next two hours of my life.  There is a step-by-step guide online for updating the firmware.  This is great except in my case, it didn't work.  A quick Google search will reveal that many, many people have issues with the GoPro update system.  So I had to do the "manual" update, which wasn't really described or documented well at all and it involves copying the contents of a zip file generated only after you answer an online questionnaire to the root of the microsd card you're using and restarting the camera.  After all the hub-bub and a few tries at the automatic update and then a few tries of the manual update, including one extremely fun point where the camera completely froze up during a manual update attempt and I had to physically remove the battery to continue - which risked bricking the thing, it turns out that my GoPro Hero3 already had the current firmware.  A fact that could have easily been figured out had GoPro simply listed the current firmware version prominently on their website.  But they don't.  See, when you turn the Hero3 on, it displays the current firmware version it has right on it's little LCD screen.  On the website, they just give a firmware date, but no version number.  Nice.  Thank you GoPro for that thoughtful insight.Onto the hardware.  First of all, it is a seemingly well made little device.  It has to be to survive all of the stunts people attempt with it!  But there are a few obvious design misses.  For one thing, it has a mini-usb port instead of a micro-usb port.  I haven't seen a new device that uses a mini-usb port for about two years.  How in heck could they go with a mini instead of a micro?  Everything is using micro usb nowadays.  But not the Hero3.  Nope.  The Hero3 will require you to carry around another cable or adapter to charge it or attach it to your computer.  Also the interface on this thing is reminiscent of early 1990's era pagers.  It is not user friendly at all.  It is very confusing and I can see that it would be very easy to set it up incorrectly.  I'm sure there have been many miserable people who do crazy things on camera after they thought they had it set up a certain way only to find it wasn't set up that way at all and the footage didn't come out right or at all as a result.Luckily, there is an app for that.  Since the GoPro Hero3 Black Edition acts as its own Wi-Fi source, once you set the Wi-Fi source name and security up on the Hero3, you simply add it to your iOS or Android device as another Wi-Fi network and point your device to it.  There is a GoPro app for both iOS and Android.  I have an Android phone - A most excellentLG Optimus G.  The app is definitely not the slickest, but it does allow you to change most settings without having to use the pager interface on the GoPro Hero3 itself.  It also has the ability to preview some (but not all) of the live video modes directly to the phone on about a two or three second delay (in my case, I suppose that may vary with different hardware or in different conditions).  This is great for aiming the device or making sure certain settings are set the way you want them.  You can also use it to start and stop recording.  It does not allow you to playback recorded video.  It does not allow you to preview any of the high-framerate modes, which I can understand, but I don't see why it couldn't just send every other frame when in that mode, or every fourth frame, for instance, and still give you a preview.  However, I recommend that once you have the camera set up and aimed, that you turn off the Wi-Fi completely on the Hero3 for a serious recording run as the Wi-Fi eats battery so you'll have to start/stop recording manually.And speaking of batteries, if you do go with a Hero3, I highly recommend that you also pick up aWasabi battery pack and charger.  The Hero3 does eat batteries if you're recording a lot, especially if you use the Wi-Fi, and charging the battery in camera, sucks.  The Wasabi pack gives you two high-quality, Japanese cell, essentially OEM spec batteries and an external charger which charges via AC or cigarette lighter in vehicle.  All for a very fair price.BTW, I'm using aSamsung Pro 64GB Micro SDXC UHS-Icard in mine.  I've had no problems recording anything.  I have heard that some people have had issues with Sandisk cards in their Hero3.  Most of the Sandisk cards are slower than the Samsung Pro card, so that may be the reason.Other thoughts...I think for the money, they could have included more mounts in the box.  They sell separate kits for mounts.  The mounts are very cheap and flimsy (compared to professional camera mounts), so IMO, they could have included them all.  Especially annoying is the lack of a simple suction cup mount in the box.  Nope.  Gotta buy it separately.IMO, the remote control they include with the black edition is rudimentary and really only useful if you're not planning on using an Android or iOS device to control the unit with.  For a lot of people, like myself, I would rather have had more mounts included instead.  Maybe the remote would be useful in extreme conditions.Believe it or not, I do like the unit.  It does take great video!  From what I've been told by a professional cinematographer friend who has used previous generation GoPro units in the past, the GoPro Hero3 is a vast improvement.  But it is definitely not perfect.  And for $400, I expect more sensible packaging, a better manual, a better firmware update system, a better user interface and more mounts in the box.
summary: Very good, but could be a lot better

reviewText: My granddaughter wanted this for her phone so she could put songs on it.  She loved the card and its capacity.

I bought this to replace my old Grace Digital internet radio. That one was a GDI-IRD4400M. I had it for 3.5 years before it broke. It was slightly more expensive than this model.The transition to the new radio was easy with the grace reciva website. I just took off the old radio and put on the new one. Updated my stations and pandora etc. Very quick and easy. Then unplugged the radio, plugged it back in and it's updated.I have not had trouble with wifi connection on this one. The old one would lose connection and i'd just turn it off and back on and it would be ok.My biggest issue is the small clock display on this one. I'm really unhappy with that.These grace internet radios are great for NPR live and the podcasts. BBC and other international stations.
summary: Really really really small clock display

reviewText: This purchase was an important addition to my photo supplies.  An extra battery and a charger that will work in the car have been very helpful.  No more "I can't take that picture because I ran out of battery" and "the battery is going and I don't have a way to charge it."

Purchased specifically to record AM radio as it is the only device which will do timed recordings of AM radio.  STAY AWAY FROM THIS UNIT.  It has a loud buzzing / hissing noise in all recordings - especially on AM.  The manual even says to turn the display off to reduce noise during recording.  It helps but it is still there and still quite loud.  Additionally, the built in speaker is so small that it sounds horrible.  It shouldn't even be there it is so bad.  If Pogo releases an updated version without the noise, a better speaker and preferably AA batteries, I will be first in line to purchase.  I regreatably had to return this unit and am now using another MP-3 player / recorder and seperate radio with timer.Update:  Recently purchased another one of these.  Have a need to do multiple recordings which I could not do as described abouve.  Either I got 2 bad ones before or the manufacturer has made changes.  This one hardly has any buzz.
summary: 0 stars updated to 3.5 stars with (updated?) unit

reviewText: Got this keyboard after my 1.5 year old Logitech "Slim illuminated keyboard" broke.  Much better key travel and comfort than the chiclet keys on most keyboards today (even the ThinkPads have gone chiclet...sad).  The construction seems sturdy and can take quite a pounding from my fingers....we shall see what happens after a few months.  Love the programmable Hot Keys and F-keys and the large palmrest.  I don't use the included mouse but use my own Performance MX Mouse instead.... to me these two make a winning combo!
summary: More sturdy and comfortable than the Slim "illuminated Keyboard"

reviewText: This is not an audiophile-quality subwoofer, but it is a great supplement to similarly priced/similar quality main speakers.  It puts out some serious low frequency energy and fills in the bottom end nicely, but it is not super fast or tight and it gets a little sloppy especially at higher volumes.  With our high-end system it adds bass but it muddies up the sound, in our other system it makes a huge improvement.  The cabinet is ok looking, not a  fine piece of furniture, but it looks fine, with or without the grill.  Definitely worth the money.
summary: It is what it is, which is not bad

reviewText: These splitters work good but be warned! Don't apply too much pressure because this material is just a powder formed plastic! Otherwise they don't come loose which is nice.
summary: Works good, needs to be made from not so brittle materials!

reviewText: wonderful product! nice weight so you don't have to press down as hard when writing.  Precision is good and I use to take notes in school with iAnnotate app.  I suggested this product to all my friends and they all love it.  The tip does break, because it is soft.  they do sell replacement tips and the prices are going up.  I am still using the original tips even though I bought extra replacements for just in case.Overall, good design, good item, must have for students who use iPad for notes!

I'm currently running a HTC Sensation with Android 2.3.4 and (almost) all the current updates, which brings me to T-MOUS Firmware 1.50.somethingorother. I've read that this card has no problems working in said device, so I decided to give it a try. Worst case, I could put it in the laptop and use it as some extra storage.The card arrived in real retail packaging, and as far as I can tell, is a genuine Sandisk product. Included were some coupons for music downloads (in the trash) and an SD-to-microSD adapter. No problems there.This card won't work as-is. It comes formatted with a new version of FAT, called exFAT. This allows the OS to take advantage of the card's size while providing an across the board file system for devices. To the best of my knowledge, the only difference between XC and HC is the file system - the card itself has the same electrical interface.To make this card work, you'll need a couple of things. A machine with either a SD card reader, or an external dongle device, and some programs. Windows will no longer format drives larger than 32GB, even with the command line trick. So, search for a fat32 formatter program. I used fat32format from Ridgecrop Consultants, Ltd. It's a free command line program, and only does one thing. Search for it and you'll find it on the first page of results.After the card was formatted, I installed it into the phone and booted, and checked the SD card. 59.4GB! Yes! I formatted it again on the phone to make sure everything was good, and copied the files from my old card over. No problems, and I have something like 40GB left.If you're lucky, your phone will format this card direct. Mine wouldn't. I keep the fat32format program on the card now, just in case.So, in conclusion:Works fine on a Sensation with Gingerbread 2.3.4, firmware 1.50.Format it on a computer first, use a fat32 formatterSeems legit, running for a week now with no issues.Speed? Don't know. No noticeable difference between this and the last device.Music downloads? Yawn.Included SD adapter works with all microSD cards.
summary: Format it first, and Android 2.3.4 say no problem!

First of all, I wanted something smaller to download caches to my gps. Took me awhile, it did not work for delorme as it wants to send the info to the sd card. Delorme only uses the SD card for maps, it did however download caches to my Garmin Oregon. Exactly what I wanted. A way to travel without having to either load up my big ole laptop or having to preload everything to my gps. I haven't tried it with my nuvi, but I'm pretty sure it won't work since the SD slot on the nuvi is read only for the maps. The other thing is to watch movies. REad several reviews on this lock before purchasing 2 of them. They work PERFECT and as expected. Yes, you could easily cut them off ( as with any of the laptop locks ) but the idea is to slow the bad guys down and stop the NOT SO BAD ones. Small, light, easy to use. Both this camera and the photo storage system it requires you to download "PlayMemories"  are not as easy to use for me personally as they have been for others.  I can't currently find the pictures I downloaded  into PlayMemories but there are a lot of previous pictures that are now handily stored in one central location.  Not the drive I wanted it on but hopefully it will switch easily.I was just getting started with this camera and I asked my teenager a question.  Within seconds he'd already set up the time, language and who knows what all else before I could stop him and do it myself.This camera really needs a small case to keep it safe and dust free.  I was able to use a small zip pouch I already keep in my purse- like a small makeup bag.  I'd prefer a harder case but this works for now.The pictures I've taken so far aren't amazing and I wish I'd sat closer to the front of the auditorium for graduation night.  It took great close ups of my garden from the upstairs window so it will just take some practice to figure out the best distances for pictures for different situations.I love the size.  Just like all cameras these days you'll have to buy a memory card- shop around so you'll know what's a deal and what's not.  I got an 8GB? card from Walgreens originally marked around $40 down to around $13. I just saw a 16 GB? card on Amazon for around $15.  We have 4 similar small cameras in our family so I'll have to compare pictures when we're all together.

I use this cover with my Kindle Fire which I take with me most of the time.  I've been using this cover for a few weeks.  It replaces a 3-sided zip cover purchased from Amazon basics that also fits my Kindle 3 SO with 3G.Pros:~Good quality.  Well-made materials and craftsmanship.~Very Functional.  The design allows easy access to the controls, has a built-in stand for hands-free reading/viewing, and solid protection for the touch screen.  I use the stand quite a bit so, for me, that's a definite plus.~The elastic-strap closure is very convenient.~Nice looking.Cons:~As other reviewers have noted, the corner elastic straps that secure the device inside the cover do partially block the speakers.  For those who use headphones or an external speaker all the time this won't be an issue.  I'm not sure how the design could be changed to avoid this drawback.  It may be a necessary trade-off but perhaps the designers can come up with an alternative system for future generations of the product.~Adds weight and bulk to the device.  The cover makes the device heavier and bulkier to carry.  Again, this becomes a personal choice as to how much protection you want vs. a lighter-weight cover.  For me, the extra protection, functionality, and appearance are worth it.~The corner straps are difficult to get on the Fire so the case pretty much becomes a permanent part of the device.  This has not been a problem for me but that's a personal consideration.In summary, I find the case provides the screen protection I was wanting with only some very minor trade-offs. If you want good quality, good looks, and good protection and weight/bulk is not an issue, then this case should be at the top of your list.
AM function is worthless - cause it picks up computer (required) noise.  Use caution with the replacement model.Clever, but a breakthrough in 2001, not 2007.

reviewText: My first impression was that this was way too heavy. I had owned the Ram strip mount attachment, which is about a third of the weight. The downside to that was, it slipped back and forth with every bump. Not so with this mount.While installing, I tightened the bolts to the point where I was worried that my handlebar tube would collapse under the pressure. This is a truly bulletproof mount.This thing will not move even with a tablet and heavy bumps. I tried it with the X-grip and the Finger grip mount, both by RAM. It should be noted that this ball mount is not the same as some of RAM's other ball mounts, which are sometimes so small the won't tighten with this mount.This is one of RAM's best products.
summary: A bit heavy, but it's bullet proof.

reviewText: I am writing this review because I have read a few reviews that talk about these headphones lacking in bass.  I disagree that this is a problem; it actually seems to be the exact thing that I think is great about them, and I love bass!  I listen to a lot of jazz and some rock and various other types of music, and all of the instruments sound very crisp and lifelike (Yes, even the bass!).  Regarding the power of the headphones, I have to actually turn down the volume considerably to be able to listen to anything, and that is still at a pretty loud volume.  Bottom line, these headphones amplify music very well (including the bass!), regardless of genre!
summary: Very good headphones at a very good price

reviewText: Pictures this lens produces are worth keeping. I see pictures posted from other zoom setups on photography forums and really they don't come close.The variable zoom is an advantage. So many times birds fly right on top of my head or come too close. If I was sitting there with fixed 500mm, I would have to just sit there and wait and hope the bird goes where I can get focus. For this lens, everything is in range.I combine it with 7D crop-sensor body and I get 400x1.6 = 640mm. I loose not one thing in picture quality with crop sensor. If anything because subjects move closer my pictures average 5-8 MB after cropping. Without the crop sensor I was averaging 1-2MB. So in fact I have picked up 240mm of reach and paid NOTHING for it in terms of picture quality  or sacrificing auto focus etc.The BOKEH is beautiful. It is only 5.6f with 400mm however even that produces beautiful creamy backgrounds. For any photography the background is important but it is even more important for wildlife. If you get too many details in background it gives you a headache to look at that picture. Even at f5.6 this produces good bokeh.The size is manageable too. I can not wait to save 8K for my 500mm f4 lens. However, I know its limitations. Almost twice as heavy and twice as big. Guys walking around with it are limited to how much hand held shooting they can do. Yeah reach is there, but if you are in spots where it is not needed as much it becomes a huge hassle.I have even taken landscape shots with it, and gotten nothing but good results. Essentially sometimes the interesting light is far from you and this gives you the reach you need for landscapes as well.ONLY time I felt I was let down is that I love to create Sun Stars. I tried to stop down for a landscape scene to try and achieve sun-star but it couldn't don it. Just gave a blob.I can live without it. This lens has produced images for me that life my spirit every time and I can't express how awesome it really is and how any wildlife photographer must have it, even if you can afford the bigger lenses.BRAVO CANON!

If you have more money, get the bigger brother. Also, no bluetooth. BOO! But I didn't know it had a bluetooth brother till after I bought it. I have an early-2008 Mac Pro and I recently suffered a power outage while Time Machine was doing a backup to an internal disk, and as a result my backup disk got irreparably corrupted.  So my purpose for getting a UPS is to be able to gracefully shutdown in the event of a power outage.  APC's web site made it sound easy... OS-X 10.5+ have built in support for USB UPS's... it just works!  Not quite.  It only appears to work until tested further.When I plugged the USB into my Mac I was initially quite impressed that the UPS controls immediately showed up in the Energy Saver preferences.  I was a little disappointed that some of the functionality was lacking, such as the remaining run time, but I could live with that since the percentage of batter left seemed accurate.Next I began simulating events by pulling the UPS plug out of the wall.  Next issue was the Mac Pro's power supply buzzed on battery power.  This is because these non-Smart UPS's simulate the AC waveform in low-resolution steps.  I didn't want to pay twice as much for a true since wave, so this was just another annoyance I could live with.  However, I've read that some newer power supplies don't work at all with the stepped output, so be sure to do your own research on that.Next I timed a shutdown in the middle of a Time Machine backup to make sure it was graceful.  It wasn't graceful.  OS-X does a hard shutdown and my backup disk got irreparably corrupted again.  I verified this repeatedly on both Leopard and Snow Leopard.  This was upsetting since this was the whole point of the UPS.  This isn't a problem with the UPS, though, so not ready to return it yet, and began researching software alternatives.However, in my repeated testing I find another major issue.  OS-X and UPS stop communicating after only a couple events (1-4).  Rebooting the computer or unplugging and replugging the USB cable gets it going again.  Since most power events would probably result in the computer being restarted anyway, this issue could go unnoticed in practice.  However, if folks have brown-outs or outages under a few minutes then this could again defeat one of the main reasons to have a UPS.In trying to determine if this was an Apple problem or an APC problem, I connected the UPS to a Windows XP machine I have and installed the PowerChute software.  Verdict: it's an Apple problem.  I simulated over a dozen events on the Windows machine and it kept going like a champ.  The PowerChute software also reports all the status information accurately and seems to work really well.  For the first time ever I was a bit envious of the PC.But that didn't last long because I found some better software for the Mac... apcupsd.  This is not for the faint of heart as it's a complicated unix program designed for IT pros.  However, there's a nice binary installation package for OS-X on the [...] website and it works pretty well right out of the box.  It has a GUI agent that has all the status info reported by the UPS (a lot more than even PowerChute had).  To make modifications to the settings, such as when to shutdown you have to edit a text file as root.  This means you have to be familiar with sudo and vi commands.  You can also customize what happens on any of a large number of events by editing files with names equal to the event.  I modified each one to send mail to my Blackberry.  I also made a simple modification to unmount my backup disks when going on battery.  I did this, because even though apcupsd does a graceful shutdown command, Time Machine still created some minor corruption.  Although the corruption was easily reparable with Disk Utility, I felt this still wasn't good enough, and Time Machine does seem robust against disk unmounts/ejects in the middle of a backup.  I also verified that apcupds never lost communication with UPS over many simulated events and time.  And if it did lose communication, there's an event for that, so it will send me mail, and not just silently ignore the UPS like OS-X.I should mention I also investigated a piece of software called PowerSaveUPS.  It's pretty full-featured and very nice, including 2-level shutdown (graceful, then emergency).  However, 1) it's expensive, and 2) it still had the same communication problem as OS-X.So now I am pretty happy with this UPS since I can do everything I want to do, and don't think there is anything better for the money.  And even though the 2 main gripes I had with it seem to be OS-X and Time Machine faults, I'm still deducting stars from APC for claiming Mac compatibility when in reality it was extremely difficult to get it set up to be as reliable and graceful as it ought to be.  I think they have a responsibility to put more effort on that.On another note, this UPS has a feature where it will cut power to some sockets based on the current draw of a master socket.  The idea is when your computer is asleep it will cut power to peripherals.  This sounds nice in theory, and is how they get away with slapping a big sticker on that says it will save you $150/yr in energy costs.  However, in practice it doesn't make much sense to plug much in there.  I can't plug my monitor there because these sockets are not battery backed, so I wouldn't be able to see to close my files in an outage.  I also don't want to put my printer there, because when my office computer is sleeping, we still may want to print over wifi from laptops.  In the end, then only thing I found I could put there is my powered speakers.  And I don't think that's going to save me anywhere near $150/yr.For your reference, my 8-core Mac Pro with 30" monitor draws 320W at idle, as such this UPS supplies 17 min. of backup power.

I have purchased two of these units from Best Buy to go along with a Belkin PF60 I use for my primary home theater (I have 3 home theater setups).  The performance on the Rocketfish is actually pretty impressive.  The picture quality is better and the sound through both the TV and stereos are improved as well.  The surge protection on the Rocketfish is actually better than what you get with a low end Monster system and it costs quite a bit less money.  I like the ability to have a master item and various other items that turn off when I shut the master item off (my TV on both of my Rocketfish).  I am seeing power savings by using the energy saving features.  Long story short, if you have a home theater, get a power conditioner.  If you are on a budget or are using lower end equipment, get the Rocketfish.

This drive piqued my interest when it became available for free on the Vine list because of its big hole design. When looking at it I was thinking, ah nice and slim to play nice with other USB stuff plugged in. In fact, that is true if the other device plugged in has the normal form factor, as opposed to something likethis one,  or is one of the micro adapters like bluetooth or Logitech's keyboard/mouse adapters.I have one of those laptop coolers with a fan that is plugged into a USB port - like the plug onthis oneI think - and this drive plugs in just fine beside it. But they are snug against each other so if your only available port has a bigger thing plugged in you will have to rearrange things or, really, solve the problem completely by getting a good hub:Cable Matters 4-Port SuperSpeed USB 3.0 Portable Compact Hub in Black - Bus Powered- look for a design like this in your hub with the ports not spaced too closely together because that just relocates the problem six inches away instead of solving the problem.If you are concerned about speed get a 3.0 drive. This one has the normal 2.0 performance and speed limitations.I'm on the fence about the exposed connector. The drive's cover does sort of snap into position but if you are carrying it around in your pocket with loose change and keys I can see how it might move out of position and the connectors could get damaged. If you are keeping it in your backpack or in your laptop case I don't think that'd be a problem.

My experience matches most of the others - this is a useful, effective item.  I typically wear an over-the-ear noise-blocking headset while recording consulting sessions.  I put the ear-bud in and my headset over it.  Worked just fine and was comfortable.  I especially like the hint in another review to use this as a microphone.

I moved from stock iPhone headphones to these beautiful things and I will never use non-wireless headphones to workout with again. I use the clip-around-the-ear attachment thing because my ears are a weird shape and the other in-ear attachments won't fit. They do NOT fall out. They do not lose signal easy either. I use these around my cube farm and I've got to walk a full 40+ feet way for them to lose signal from my Galaxy S4. One charge lasts me a full 8 hour day. Sound quality wise, they have a strong bass with precise highs and mids. At high volumes, the mids can get kind of lost, but it's hard to notice unless you're really listening for it. I've owned these for 2 years now and they have pretty much stayed the same. No deterioration of the cord, ear buds, sounds quality, signal strength, battery life, NOTHING! They've gotten pulled out of my ears by weights and other people but they stick together, unlike other wireless headphones *cough cough* Planetronics... *cough cough*, that fall apart when you look at them. The only gripe I have is that the chargin cord that they come with it only 6 inches long, making it pretty much impossible to listen while charging.

Since I have DirecTV, this tuner-less recorder was the answer to my needs.  I use DVD+RW disks and can record things to watch, then erase and re-use the disks.  The only advantage to using tapes is the ease of retrieving parts of a recording to transfer to a more permanent medium, but that problem can be resolved.  What's interesting is that the Toshiba and the Magnavox DVD-VHS combination recorder use virtually the same remote, and the on-screen displays are also identical.  I suspect they're both made by the Funai Corporation, who make the Magnavox.  But the recorder is fine, elegantly designed and very neat.

I own 3 powerbags, none of which I bought at the full retail price. I purchased a blue one during a Black Friday sale for roughly $35 and two red ones for about $30 each. At those prices, they were a great bargain.When you first get your powerbag, it is important to open the battery pouch and remove the small plastic on the battery pack. You can easily remove the battery by shifting a button that locks the battery in. Upon removing the plastic, your powerbag will now be able to charge through a small port located on the external front side of the powerbag. The powerbag charger is also located inside the battery pouch (I usually store the the AC adapter in the left pouch). The instructions provided within the powerbag are great and you shouldn't have a problem setting it up.When the battery is being charged, you will see blinking LED lights on the front surface of the powerbag. A single click of the powerbag button will indicate the battery level. A long press press (2-3 seconds) will begin charging your device or stop charging your device.The backpack itself is very spacious. There is a pouch that faces the back for laptops (or other flat things that can rest comfortably on your back). My 15-inch MacBook Pro fits nicely inside this pouch. There is also another pouch for storage of regular items. I am able to fit 9 different MCAT books of various sizes and still have empty space for additional storage. There is also a pouch that contains the battery as well as slots for tablet storage, pencils, erasers, flash cards, and more.During the school year, I use my powerbag on a daily basis. The battery is sufficient to provide my iPhone with a more than substantial charge to last the whole day. There are various USB cables to charge your device as well as a USB port on the battery to connect your own.Lastly, the powerbag fits comfortably on my back. I had issues in the beginning because the straps were held too tightly but there has been no problem after loosening them.Please feel free to ask me any questions about the powerbag and I will answer them in a timely fashion.
summary: Excellent backpack with the added bonus of a portable battery.

reviewText: These are good quality earphones and work well.  The cord length is sufficient for our needs too.We use Amazon for most of our purchases and I update my reviews if anything changes with the products. I do this so other Amazon users can get a real feel for the life of the product.  I am not associated with any company and all opinions are my very own.

It is not often that Microsoft releases a new product.  But when they do, you can almost always expect that it will bring a lot of discussion, criticism, and praise.  The big question is if these devices are actually as good as they are made out to be.The Zune HD, released on September 15, 2009, was one of Microsoft's most recently anticipated devices.  It brought many new features to distinguish itself from the competition.  A few of those include Nvidia's Tegra chip and an OLED screen.  All of these sound good on paper, but how well are they implemented in the Zune HD.Appearance - The Zune is a very appealing device.  Contrary to many devices that go for a smooth vibe, the HD takes on a design that involves many lines and gives off a boxy feel but also sleek at the same time.  It also has some subtle accents, like the silver screws in the back, or the brushed chrome back that make it look different than any other device on the market.Ease of Use - The user interface of the Zune is fairly straightforward.  It uses gestures to navigate its menu system, and they work very well.  When you start it up, you are presented with a list of choices, including Music, Videos, Pictures, and others.  Also, if you flick your finger to the side, you can see a list of items that you have marked as your favorite, or the newest thing you added to your device.  A very useful feature when you want something fast.  But there are some downsides.  Occasionally, the Zune will not recognize button presses.  This does not usually hinder you, but it does get annoying really fast.Features - Another place where the Zune stands out and shines.  One of the biggest and most obvious features of the Zune HD is its OLED screen.  It makes colors pop and images displayed on it look flawless, especially in low light.  The only problem I have with the OLED is that it gets washed out in sunlight.  But if you can get past that small weakness, you will have one of the best screens in your hand.  Also, the Tegra chip in the Zune is impressive.  It can run a full 3D racing game with nice looking textures and many objects on screen without any sign of a choppy picture.  The HD radio is nice, too, because with it, you can access many new stations that you would not normally be able to listen to without it.  But there always must also be some weak points.  One of those would be the Zune's selection of apps.  There is no app store that includes user made apps, and the ones that are in the store are all free but boot up with an add.  But the Zune was made as to be a media player, and it excels at that in every aspect.As you may have recognized by now, the Zune is one of the best devices for your personal media.  But if you are a person that needs apps, and lots of them, you have the wrong device.  For almost any other media needs, the Zune will meet and even surpass your expectations.  And with all of the features you get in such a small package, you won't find a better looking device anywhere.
A most for my Jornada. My screen will last very, very long now. Character recognition is just fine. This thing works... as long as you remove BOTH plastic covers. I highly recomend it.

I just bought a Zumo 220 and will be sending it back.The unit itself works wonderfully and the pricepoint is great, but the bluetooth support has been crippled because it does not support A2DP like the 660 and 665.  I'm not certain how well the 550 supports bluetooth, but I do not think it supports A2DP either, at least its not listed as such on the Garmin web page like the 660 and 665 are.Anyhow the reason this really matters and why I'm taking the time to post this is because I bought a new Schuberth C3 and the integrated Cardo headphones.  The purpose of the Zumo 220 was to act as a central hub for it all.  This does not work though as the 220 will not pair with a phone.  If you want such functionality it works if A2DP is supported.  To get that, you need to go for the zumo 660, or 665.  The zumo 550 might work, but Garmin does not list it as A2DP compliant like they do with the others.

First, I do need to qualify this.  I have Verizon FiOS, which allows self-installation of CableCARDs, and they documented it very well.  There's even a web page where YOU get to type the HostID and DeviceID...so you'll know it's right.  Other CableCos require truck-rolls ($40+) for installation, and the technicians know nothing.  Often, they will use a default HostID at the central office, meaning it won't work, so you have to become a literal cable expert to get it working, and do the cable company's job...on your dime.  So, with that out of the way...I had started with the ATI CableCARD tuner, which was state-of-the-art when it came out in 2006.  There were so many restrictions with it, though.  For example, you had to buy a complete CableLabs certified computer to even legally obtain one.  Eventually, bootloaders to spoof the BIOS key came out, and you could get these ATI tuners on Ebay and use them.  Legal?  Grey area.  Immoral?  Nope, as long as you pay for cable and the channels you get.  When Windows7 came out, the whole "CableLabs certified computer" requirement was thrown out, and Microsoft added support for Switched Digital Video.  If your Cableco uses SDV, you need another box, and it is another minor headache to set up.  But, if you successfully set up your CableCARD already, it's not hard.  FiOS doesn't use SDV, which is good.Now, with the advent of Windows7, the environment was open enough to where other companies could have a viable business developing CableCARD tuners.  ATI sold off that business as the market wasn't viable in the Vista days, but 3 more entrants have come in, including SiliconDust with this product.The setup of the HDHomeRun was really simple.  The directions were excellent, and short.  Verizon did well with the CableCARD activation, and when that was done, the setup was easy.  I'd recommend just downloading the updated software from SiliconDust...something I've just always done for the last decade.  Windows Media Center recognized the 3 tuners without a hitch (plus 2 more ClearQAM tuners I have), and my literal first attempt at tuning an alternate Showtime channel was successful.If you have to use SDV, the SDV box can plug into the HDHomeRun.  This means it's "always active" which is a good thing.  With the other solutions, but the tuner and SDV adapter are plugged into your computer's ports (internal or external), and that means the SDV adapter is not directly connected to the tuner.  While it works, I had found that first-time SDV-channel tuning wasn't always trouble-free; I often had to change channels and change back to get a SDV channel working.  This made the Sunday HBO/Showtime recording a question-mark, and often it had to record the program on another day.  With the HDHomeRun, this should occur less often as the SDV Adapter is connected at all times.  Word of warning...make sure your CableCo's SDV box will support 4 channels.  If your cableCo uses a Cisco box, it may be limited to 2 channels...and your HDHomeRun will be, too.The HDHomeRun also uses Gigabit ethernet.  I highly recommend you use a gigabit switch.  While each channel is only 20Mbps or so, that means that 3 will fit into a 100Mbps connection.  But, if you are using this to record 3 channels and watch recordings on other devices (such as an Xbox360) or other computers at the same time, a 100Mbps connection could be overwhelmed causing quality loss at best or corrupted recodings at worst.  Good gigabit switches are cheap.  My Cisco/Linksys 8-port handles this well.  I would not recommend using this with WiFi.  At best you could record 1 channel or watch one program...and not at the same time.  Perhaps if you use 5Ghz Wifi, you may get away with more, but WiFi isn't very good for streaming HD video.In conclusion, this device is a great buy!  I have a 7TB DVR that can record 5 (3 from this plus 2 ClearQAM) channels at one time, and support TVs in other rooms via Xbox360 extenders.  This thing can replace multiple cable boxes.  If you have a 3 TV household, it could save you almost $50 per MONTH in rental fees (assuming 3 DVRs).
summary: Very easy setup!  This thing is wonderful

I bought one of these TVs back in 2008 when 120Hz was the new thing and I am happy to report I have no desire to replace this TV anytime soon.The TV is light and pretty slim. If it weren't for the sheer size of it, I'd say one person could easily move this TV on their own. The swivel stand is a nice touch, allowing you to turn the TV easily.I could go into all of the specs for this TV but it's rather pointless. I've read that most TVs, if they do experience problems, experience them in the first year. I've had none with this TV. When I bought it, I also bought the screen calibration service from a Geek Squad type entity. They have a special device that attaches to the front of the TV and that device relays information to the laptop its connected to, which then tells the technician what to adjust to make the picture as good as possible. A few tweaks and it was done and the colors were much more vibrant.3 years later and this TV is still going strong. Samsung makes great displays at competitive prices and I couldn't be happier, nor do I have any envy for those with 240Hz 3D LED TVs. This suits everyone in the house just fine. I'd recommend this TV if it can be had on the cheap but otherwise I'd recommend Samsung as a trusted TV brand.
summary: Owned one of these for over 3 years -- no issues

Works great, stores very easily in a laptop case, great battery life, etc.  I love it and am very happy I purchased it.

I install HD TVs for a living. I tried this mount in the while sampling new products. Look closely at the picture. The back plate that mounts to the wall is split down the middle. Not a problem if there was a plate to join them like other mounts have. There is no hardware supplied to join the two plates together. Worst design ever. To install it you have to level and install the two halves separately. The parts themselves were sturdy unlike most of the other mounts in this price range but I would strongly recommend you look at other alternatives. There is a mount by Dayton Audio that I continue to use but its not eligible for Prime :( . Hope this info was helpful.

I did my research based on my requirement that the width of TV can not exceed 34.5 inches. Because of the thin frame, the width of this 37" TV is 34.1".  Other 37" HDTV have a wide frame and the width can be as much as 35.8". It fits on my large Ikea desk from my home office. It replaces a 19" Sony LCD TV, which from 4 ft away looked a post office stamp. I could not watch a game or movie on a phone or tablet. I want a big image. If you are like me, and not a teenager, you know what I mean. I like big screens. So 37" is the size to have even in small rooms, as 32" is not as immersible into the actionThe Samsung UN37EH5000 37-Inch 1080p 120Hz LED HDTV is not really 120Hz, but 60Hz. It has a metric invented by Samsung about the subjective impression that it behaves as if it were a 120Hz refresh rate. I was watching the Olympics London 2012 and the soccer games was clear. The movement was never blurred. This TV is not "smart, but after buying a BDP-S185 Blu-Ray Disc PlayerSony BDP-S185 Blu-Ray Disc Playerwhich is 2D (not 3D) and it the least expensive, voila!, I have a full feature "smart" HDTV with Netflix, Amazon, etc available. I connected via Ethernet cables (not WiFi)and the reception is stunning. However, 90% of the time I watch soccer. I am an Internet guy and read news on line at my own speedThe 37" TV (I keep repeating the size, as Amazon mixes and matches all models reviews, irrespective of size, in the same category) -  shares the huge desk with my HP 27" computer monitor and desktop, so I have the TV on at low volume. The sound is too good for me. The LED in model Samsung UN37EH5000 is back-lit, so the TV is lightly thicker than models with side LED (The code for side lit LED in Samsung, just replace the letter "H" with the letter "S"). Other than that, the picture is equally stunning in both back and side lit models.Finally the price for the Samsung 37" is way lower than almost all other 37" TVs on the market. This may be the reason why this TV does not rotate left and right on the base, a feature I would have liked, but I can live without it.

Update: I bought another DB2 for my mother's house outside of Baltimore. I pointed it at a corner in her living room, and it got 100% of all her available channels + Public TV from Annapolis + all of the Washington, DC channels -- good signals with very little break up. In less than 5 minutes, she went from being frustrated and disappointed with the crappy new HDTV signals to being totally impressed with the quality and number of signals available.I had lowered my expectations for this antenna, but it does work. I saw that it had a lot of 5-star reviews, but focused on all the negative ones instead. Every other attempt I've tried till now has been frustrating and partially successful part of the time. My boyfriend's complaining that we need cable to get good reception (I'm trying to skip yet another monthly fee).We're in the middle of Washington, DC -- on the first floor of a condo building that's surrounded by other tall condo buildings, and we needed something interior because there's no way to hook an antenna outside. You might think that reception would always be clear and easy in the city, but no -- not even close with all the other antennas I'd tried. This DB2 Antenna gets all 17 channels currently available in this area -- totally clear, no skipping, no digital noise, no dropping of the sound. All the channels, no need to swivel it around at all. (I wish it got the Maryland Public TV stations, but inside the District it's always been a snowy stretch.)It is not stylish or impressive in visual design. And there's no pole to clamp it to (I'm using a floor lamp temporarily). But the best thing is, you don't need to plug it in to an electrical socket for this super signal. I was going to spend twice as much at the "BigBox" store for the Terk desktop model. But this really does a super job for us and deserves all 5 stars for a clear signal.
summary: It works! It works! Indoors, even surrounded by tall buildings
